business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI inform the Senate that Senator Richard Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, will be absent from the Senate chamber for question time today. Senator Alston is in Melbourne to attend the funeral of Mr Bob Santamaria. In his absence, Senator Ellison will take questions relating to Communications and the Arts. Senator Kemp will take questions on the Information Economyâ

speech.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âVery ably, I would think, Madam President, and I will take questions relating to the portfolios of Transport and Regional Development and Workplace Relations and Small Business.

âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust, when did your office direct your department to reassess the applications which had been rejected by the Victorian regional assessment panels? Who issued that direction? Was that direction cleared with you? What representations were made to your office, and by whom, prior to that direction being issued?

âI will start by saying how proud we are of the Natural Heritage Trust and its achievements in a very short period of time. Madam President, the comparison is there: 13 years of Labor and what did they do in this vital areaâvital in the interests of all Australians? Very, very little. How often were we told about the state of land and water degradation in this country or the state of sustainable forestry? Do we remember the forestry issues that we were experiencing when Senator Faulkner went out to lead the charge for the Greens, battled Mr Beddall, who was acting on behalf of the industry, and made such a mess of it that Senator Collins had to be called in to the rescue? Do we remember the decline in biodiversity as demonstrated by the State of the environment report?

answer.para: Do we remember the pitiful record of Labor in relation to feral weeds and animals? Do we know what they failed to do in relation to the Murray-Darling Basinâan area that all Australians know needed substantial investment? Do we know their areas of failure in relation to air pollution? And so I could go on. We make no apology that we committed ourselves to setting up a $1.1 billionâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam President: obviously the feral weeds have got in the way of Senator Hill's answer to the question, which I thought was a specific one directed to him in relation to when his office directed the department to reassess the applications rejected by the Victorian RAP process; who did it; whether it was cleared by him; and what representations were made. I thought it was a clear question. I ask you, given that Senator Hill has had a couple of minutes now, to direct the minister to answer the question that was actually asked of him.
âSenator Hill, you are aware of the question and I am sure you will get to the substance.

âMadam President, I was getting to it but I was laying the base first that that was clearly a pitiful failure of Labor in this area. The contrast is with what the coalition is doing and will continue to do. Over $360 million is being invested in restoring our native bushland and preserving remnantsâthe subject overlooked by Senator Faulkner yesterday. An extra $150 million from the federal government is going into the Murray-Darling Basin; over $160 million to protect biodiversity; $440 million to assist farmers and communities to redress the extent of land and water degradation; and $120 million to address coastal pollution.

answer.para: I said yesterday in this place that there were difficulties in relation to the Victorian experience at both the RAP and the SAP level. I said that my departmentâand I will take responsibility for the instructionâhad a look at grants that were unsuccessful either at the RAP level or at the SAP level. I set out why we did that yesterday. They looked at a further 199 grants, as I understand it. They found there were three that they believed should have been funded. They made that recommendation to me and I accepted it.

With regard to the one that you were preoccupied with yesterday, they found that there had been an error made, a misunderstanding of what the rules were at the RAP level. Why should the environment suffer simply because there was an error made at the regional assessment level? Of course it should not, Madam President.

What is the objection to the federal government, which is responsible for the vast proportion of the funds, having a look at all the applications? In actual fact, the shadow minister for the environment has asked for the full 6,000 applicationsâall of those rejected. He wants to look at all of those rejected. That is fine, apart from all the work that is involved in putting it together. If Labor wants to trawl through all 6,000 applications in an attempt to gain some political mileage, so be it. But if Labor concentrated on doing something for the environment rather than that, then we would all be better off. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister did not answer the specific questions I asked. I direct his attention to them. If he cannot answer them now, perhaps he could provide the Senate with an answer to them by the end of question time. Further, Minister Hill, could you tell us: were there any discussions between your office and your department about the Baillieu grant prior to the department's recommendation that it be approved? Who was present in the room when you made the decision to approve that grant and will you table the record of that decision and the reasons for the variation?

âI do not believe that my office knew of the, as you describe it, `Baillieu grant' at all. I certainly did not know of it. Until yesterday, I had never heard of Mr Antony Baillieu, as I said to you.
âYou forgot!

âNo. It is not a question of forgetting it. I had never heard of him. And certainly I did not know who his relatives were, Senator Cook. What I do know is that it was a damn good application and that is what all the experts said. They said it was an excellent application. If you ask me another question, I will detail why it was excellent.
âWho was present in the room?
âMy memory is that officials brought over the supplementary list, took me through the supplementary list, the three that they recommended, and I approved them.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, the Labor government attempted to convince the Australian public that they had a social security system with world's leading standards in respect of fraud and compliance. As revealed last year, Australian taxpayers were saved $28 million per week because of some commonsense accountability action taken by this government. As there is nothing that infuriates Australians more than somebody receiving a benefit to which they are not entitled, will you inform the Senate of additional savings in the social security system and further measures designed to combat fraud?

âI thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for his question. It is very timely. It is interesting to note that the opposition are never interested in asking this question, just as they were never interested in being tough on cheats.

answer.para: Madam President, let me remind you of some of the statements that were made in past years under the previous government. `Measures have been implemented which have effectively solved the compliance problem.' Who said that? That was Labor's expert, Professor Weatherly, in 1993. In 1994 the minister, Peter Baldwin, said, `We have got a system which is at the cutting edge in terms of its effectiveness in combating fraud and compliance.' Again, in 1995, the minister Mr Baldwin said, `We have very effective compliance measures and measures to counter fraud.'

They were utterly wasted years. The Labor government were not prepared to deal with cheats; they would not put the resources in; they were complacent; they were soft. Last financial year our compliance efforts picked up a lot of people that Labor had been soft on. We cancelled or reduced payments to 330,000 people because they were getting payments to which they were not entitled. That is how we saved the taxpayer $28 million every week.

talk.start.para: âEvery week?

âEvery week of the financial yearâover $1 billion. It is almost unbelievable. What a mockery that makes of Labor's claims that the system was as tight as a drum. Trim, taut and terrific was what Richo seemed to think it was. But sadly, once we came into government, we saw the grim reality. Only the other day, a man went to gaol for four years for defrauding the taxpayer of $305,000 over 14 years of consistent cheating. All the years that Labor was in government, this man was cheating the battler, cheating the taxpayer; $305,000 looks like quite an industry to me. Those are the very years when Labor was skiting about how trim, taut and terrific the system was. He is not the only long-term cheat that we have caught so far.

answer.para: During January, I provided the President with the fraud and compliance report for the first quarter of 1997-98 and I now formally table it. This report indicates a significant increase in our compliance activity over and above what we did in the previous financial year. There were more reviews undertaken, more payment variations made, more debts identified and more debts recovered. In three months, 668 people were convicted under either the Social Security Act or the Crimes Act. Those people were cheating their fellow Australians.

talk.start.para: âThe greedy, not the needy.

âThe greedy, not the needy, as Senator Patterson says so rightly. Compliance reviewsâchecking on whether people are doing what they are required to doâwent up by nearly 22 per cent. Fifty-four thousand customers had their payments cancelled in those three months and over 40,000 had their benefits reduced. There were nearly $88 million in new debts identified. Fourteen thousand reviews came as a result of the public knowing that this government is serious and that we will take action. They want us to take action. The increase in tip-offs from the public is very heartening because they know that we mean business.

answer.para: We are also undertaking covert surveillance of cases which have been particularly difficult. We have brought in the private sector there. So far, out of 20 cases that were given to the private sector, 11 have been finalised. All 11 customers have had their payments cancelled, they had debts to repay and some have been referred to the Federal Police and to the DPP. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, can you confirm that John Madden Baillieu, one of the four current directors of Woodhouse Pastoral Co., the beneficiary of $52,900 from your natural heritage slush fund, is also Chairman of EL&C Baillieu which donated $50,500 to the Liberal Party in the last two years? Minister, how do you justify repaying that donation with interest from taxpayers' dollars from the Natural Heritage Trust?

âThat is yet another disgraceful slur upon the Baillieus. If you had concentrated a little more when you were minister for the environment on achieving some decent environmental outcomes for this country, then you may be better qualified to attack the current government. But with your record, I am surprised that you have the gall to even ask a question on this matter, Senator Faulkner. Do you remember how your record was recorded as environment minister? Do you remember what was said in the Bulletin on your efforts over forests? If you do not, I will remind you. It said:

answer.para: Faulkner made a mess of thingsâcomprehensively, as the commentators say. The extent of his mishandling of the issue is only now becoming apparent. Faulkner clearly intended to make himself a hero to the environmental movement. The result though, will be a setback for the cause, disillusionment for Faulkner and his department . . . Faulkner wanted to be a Graham Richardson. He emerges from this episode more like a Ros Kelly.

That was Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin . The point is, Senator Faulkner, you left an appalling record. The alternative was the coalition that recognised the failures of the past and put in place a Natural Heritage Trust to invest more money than ever before in the major land and water degradation of our nation. We are proud of that and we have set up a comprehensive process to determine the best projects to get the best outcomes on the ground.

In relation to the details of the question, I have no knowledge, as I said, of the relatives or the composition of directors. There was no suggestion, as I recall it, from the application that it was even an incorporated body. Anyway, you seem to have trawled that out.

talk.start.para: âAccording to the application? You've never met the Baillieus?

âI have never met this Tony Baillieu. I do not know whether he or a member of his family have given a donation to anyone. Furthermore, it is totally irrelevant to the issue as to whether this was a meritorious application. The point is that this application was supported by the Trust for Nature, Victoria, who have been seeking for years to put in place covenants on valuable natural assets on private land, where the valuable asset is given up for the benefit of the community.
âWas it the same mob who donated fifty grand to the Libs? Tell us that. The same mob?

âThis is the point that Senator Faulkner either does not understand or fails to acknowledge. What this pastoral company is doing here is giving up a right to use a resource for its economic advantage for the benefit of the total community. It is prepared to covenant for the benefit of the community to achieve that outcome in the long term. That should be applauded.

answer.para: Anybody who has been interested in these issues would have known for a long time that the old recipe of national parks simply locking up these resources in public ownership is not working. The big challenge has been to find ways in which the resources on private land can be properly protected in the community's interest, and that is exactly what this project was all about. That is why the Trust for Nature, Victoria, has been working on a covenant on this particular land, I understand, since the early 1990s. I understand that it was the trust that first approached the family. It is the conservation interests out there who have recognised the value and applaud the fact that finally there is a government that is prepared to support them in what they are seeking to do. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is the Liberal Party interests not the conservation interests that are at issue here. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it just a coincidence that the registered address of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co., the recipient of $52,900 of Natural Heritage Trust funds, is 360 Collins Street, Melbourne, which is also the registered address of EL&C Baillieu, donor of $50,500 to the Liberal Party?
âThis is astonishing. Did you read what Tony Baillieu said about it? Did you listen to the radio and hear what he said?
âI am asking you a question about the Liberal Party donation. That is what I asked.
âNo. When he was asked about his alleged family connections and interests with the Liberal Party, what did he say?
âI am asking you whether he is a director of the company at this address.

âYou will slur anyone to try and advance your political interests. You have got no interest in the environmental outcome at all. The opposition have attacked the grants because they said they were in Liberal seats. This one is in a Labor seat, so they attack the proponent. You move from side to side, any way to win a political point and forget the benefits for the environment. In the Sydney Morning Herald article, Mr Baillieu said, `I have no connection at all, no influence and nothing whatsoever to do with the Liberal Party hierarchy.'

âMy question is to the Minister for Justice. We all know that the Labor government failed in its attempt to extradite Mr Christopher Skase from Spain. Senator Bolkus has recently said that the government should start the extradition proceedings again in Spain. Is the government able to reopen extradition hearings in Spain?

âI thank Senator Abetz for his question. Yes, Senator Abetz, on 5 January this year on 3AW Senator Bolkusâthe shadow Attorney-Generalâconfidently said, `This bloke,' referring to Skase, `is not sick. We're going to start the extradition proceedings again. There's nothing to stop that if we have evidence that the guy is healthy.' So there he was, the shadow Attorney-General, the would-be first law officer of the Commonwealth, telling the world at large, `We're going to reopen all of this and we're just going to bring him back. We're going to be heroes and bring him back.' All of this is out of the mouths of the people who, when in government, were the people who let him go. You were the people who let him go.

answer.para: I had occasion to reflect on this so I had a quick look at what Michael Lavarch said in 1995. Despite being a Labor attorney, he nonetheless had some respect in the community. He said:
Extradition cannot be sought from Spainâ
`cannot', negativeâ

for the relevant offences because the court has conclusively determined that Skase may not be returned to Australia and that issue cannot be reopened even in the face of further evidence that Skase was medically fit to travel.

talk.start.para: âThere's a lot of new evidence about.

âThat is what Michael Lavarch, the then Attorney-General, said in 1995. Despite all of that sort of comment from his attorney, Senator Bolkus goes out now because he is the shadow attorney and says, `Don't worry about that. We'll just reopen it all. We'll just bring him back. Forget the fact that we let him go. We'll bring him back.' That shows you something, Senator Bolkus. I had occasion to reflect on just who your party values. Who will they make Attorney-General? I had a bit of a look at it and, in March 1983, they had a chance to appoint an attorney. Did they appoint you, Senator Bolkus?
âNo!
âNo, they appointed Gareth Evans. Then in 1984 they had a chance to reconsider. Did they appoint you?
âNo!
âNo. In July 1987, Senator Bolkus, they had another opportunity to appoint you. Did they appoint you then?
âNo!
âOrder!
âNo. On 18 September 1997, they had a chance to appoint you to the new ministry for justice. Did they appoint you to that?
âNo!
âNo, they did not, and so it goes on.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIn April 1990, in December 1991, in May 1992, in March 1993 and in April 1993, your party had a chance to appoint you and they rejected you.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The level of noise in the chamber is totally unacceptable on all sides.

âIt would be a lot easier to answer the question if I did not have to raise my voice above the cacophony of rubbish over there. So there we have it, Senator Abetz. On 10, 11 or 12 occasions, Labor had a chance to make that man Attorney-General or Minister for Justice, and on every occasion they chose somebody else. What do you think that tells you about what they think of him? It shows you they think he is an incompetent.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The level of noise is absolutely unacceptable.

âSenator Bolkus was caught touting around with in-chamber hearings from the Federal Court, undermining the national interest, undermining the government's genuine attempts to get at Skase's assets. That should show that he is an incompetent fool. Yesterday, he was quoting from model rules of professional conduct and practice urging people to be honestâthis is the same bloke who was quoting from a stolen document in January. You don't have double standards, Senator Bolkus; you have no standards. Your party will never make you Attorney-General. Never. You have been referred to the Privileges Committee because all your colleagues think you are a leaker. They think you have no respect.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. We can all play the game of saying who has been referred to the Privileges Committee. Senator Alston has been, and so has a whole range of people. We do not refer to it in the chamber until the Privileges Committee brings down a finding.
âThere is no point of order.

âThe bottom line is this: you have no respect for the institution you are a part of, no respect for committee procedures, none for the parties you work with and you have got none from the Australian people. (Time expired)

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I was wondering if the Minister for Justice might comment in relation to the obstacles in the Skase case as to whether the call to reopen the extradition hearings is as helpful as Senator Bolkus's contribution to the debate when he sought to leak confidential Federal Court documents to the media?

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. The question should be struck out as being out of order because it is based on a wrongful assumption. The docu ments were already with the media. The Minister for Justice knows that full well. The former shadow Attorney-General who never made it to Attorney-General knows full well that it is based on the wrong premise.
âSenator Bolkus, you are debating the issue; there is no point of order. I call Senator Vanstone.

âThank you, Madam President. Senator Abetz, you have just seen another example that Senator Bolkus is one of the greatest impediments to pursuing Skase. He seeks to say that the documents he leaked were already in the hands of the media. We have no evidence of that whatsoever, but we have got a video of you reading them out to the public, Senator Bolkus. Oh, yes. The bottom line is that, in any of these matters, when you are pursuing someone with top class legal advice, you need to have some sort of secrecy about your proceedings and, when you go to in-chamber hearings, you would hope that someone who purports to be the alternative first law officer would respect that and would give the government a chance to get at the assets that Labor let go.

âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, can you confirm your statement to the estimates committees last week that Senator Crane was present in your office when you made NHT funding decisions regarding Western Australian projects? In light of Senator Crane's astounding revelation that his own property in Western Australia received grant funding from the NHT and that he continues to hold a full share in the property, I ask: what is the name of Senator Crane's project? What was the purpose of the grant? How much was the grant for? Was this grant approved at a meeting when Senator Crane was present? Minister, was the Crane property identified in the project application? I ask that you table a copy of the application for that project and grant, as you did last night for the Baillieu grant.
âI will just complete the answer to the last question because I ran out of time.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. You know that is out of order. It is not competent for the minister to complete any other answers. He will be able to do so after question time, if he has misled the Senate or has to correct the record. You should direct him to answer the question I have asked on this occasion.
âThere is an appropriate time to add to other answers, Senator Hill.

âIt is just that the attempt was made again to slur the Baillieu family and I thought Senator Faulkner would appreciate another quote from Mr Baillieu to demonstrate that in fact he has no apparent connection with the Liberal Party.
âSenator Hill, I draw your attention to the question.

âOkay, Madam President. I must say that I did see reference to a matter in the Canberra Times this morning that caused me to make some inquiries. What I found out is that there is a catchment group of some 27 families that has been operating, I think for about 10 yearsâanyway for some considerable yearsâin Western Australia. It is called theâ
â`Crane Family Farm'.

âNo. I will find it in a minute. It is the Yallobup Creek Catchment Group. I found out that it applied for funding assistance for reclamation workâfor damage that has been caused through loss of vegetation and the likeâthat it has been doing for many years. I found out that it takes off a corner of Senator Crane's property which makes up about one per cent of the catchment.

answer.para: I understand that the process is that the families within the catchment who wish to seek funding join together and do so. I made inquiries and found that Senator Crane, even though he has got a little slice of his property taken off in this catchment, made no such application. So it is not true to say that any benefit was going to Senator Crane from this particular project. I have now received written confirmation of that from the project managers, Madam President. As to whether Senator Crane was present when the matter was discussed, the answer is no. In fact, I understand that Senator Crane did not know that this application had been made until after Christmas.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. We assume then from your answer, Senator Hill, that as apparently Senator Crane was providing you with information on a whole range of landcare groupsâwhich is evidence that you gave to the estimates committeeâdo you believe that if you have a government backbencher, a coalition backbencher, in a room when you are making decisions about such projects and grants, that represents a clear conflict of interest?

âI thought I just said to the honourable senator that in fact Senator Crane did not become aware that an application had been made by this group until after Christmas. And I have just said it is of no benefit to his property and to him at all. But, apart from that, the issue of seeking advice from those who are well informed on the background to land management and natural resource management issues in this country is something that I would suggest is very sensible.

answer.para: When I look around on this side of the chamber, Madam President, I see lots of well informed senators on the issues of landcare, soil degradation and dry land salinityâall the major land and water resource problems that this country is facing. But, of course, there is no interest in the subject on the other side of the chamber. These people are committed to a better environmental outcome for this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, my question is directed to you. It follows on from the questions that Senator Faulkner has just raised. I think the matter is of sufficient importance that I ask, Madam Presidentâif what we have just heard is correct, and if there is a question over the involvement of Senator Crane's property in the Natural Heritage Trust grantâare you aware of standing order of the Senate No. 27 which states:

question.para: A senator shall not sit on a committee if the senator has a conflict of interest in relation to the inquiry of the committee.

Is it true that Senator Crane is chair of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee which dealt with the Natural Heritage Trust fund in estimates in 1997 and 1998? If this is the case, Madam President, and there is an interest, what is the appropriate action? Should Senator Crane resign from that committee?
Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. There is an element in thatâ

answer.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. There is an element in that which is hypothetical, and there are matters of substance about which I will take advice and report to the Senate.

âI thank you Madam President, but I think this is an important issue, and it is one that has been long overlooked in this chamber. If it is found that Senator Crane is in breach of standing orders, can you please advise the Senate on the appropriate action, on whether or not he should stand down? Also, can we have your ruling on whether or not this matter should be referred to the Privileges Committee?
âI shall look into the matter, as I have indicated, and report to the Senate.

âMadam President, I ask Senator Hill, in light of his comments on Senator Crane's direct or indirect involvement in one of these grants, whether he can give the Senate an unequivocal assurance that no other coalition MP or senator has received Natural Heritage Trust funds, either directly or indirectly, through family trusts or other company structures.
âI am not too sure what the reference to `no other senator' means, Madam President, because I know of no senator who has received any funds through the Natural Heritage Trust.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Hill whether he intends to continue the practice of having coalition senators in the room when he is acting as a decision maker, or whether he is in fact going to desist from this particular practice in future.

âI think what has to be understood is that this was the start of a long process. It was the start to a basis where this country had not done well in this area of natural resource management. We inherited a real mess, and we were determined to put in place a process that was going to deliver the best outcomes on the ground. That is what the Australian people wanted. We put the details of this program to the Australian people at the election. We described how we would fund it. We got the funding base through this parliament, despite your opposition. We set it up under a legislative framework. We set in so many checks and balances to the extent that I have described it as not only exhausting but at times exhaustive. Part of the challenge is to build that information base upon which we can make better decisions for the future than were made in the past. (Time expired)

âMadam President, on a point of order: I ask that the comments made by Senator Schacht when he said, `Giving Winston money,' be withdrawn. I make the point that we did not apply for any money. Nor did we receive any money. This is a fabrication and it is a lie.
âSenator Schacht, I did not hear those remarks, but if they were made in that fashion, they ought to be withdrawn.
âIf that is your direction, Madam President, I withdraw.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of recent demonstrated high levels of public disquiet in relation to the Jervoise Bay dockyard project in Western Australia to be partially funded by the so-called Federation Fund, I ask: what steps has the federal government taken to ensure that the Federation Fund is used for projects which are environmentally sustainable and have a positive social impact and broad community acceptance? At what point in the decision to commit such funds are these issues assessed? Which federal agencies are involved? Is the Commonwealth government considering using the Federation Fund to subsidise the equally controversial deepwater port at Oakajee near Geraldton?

âIn relation to the last part, obviously I am not at liberty to provide information on what the government might be considering it would do. In relation to the announcement that was made in Jervoise Bay, this is a project that is strongly supported within Western Australia and strongly supported by the Commonwealth government, which we believe will help to lay a stronger economic base for Western Australia and therefore Western Australians in the future. It is a project, we believe, to be of great commercial value to the state of Western Australia and therefore of considerable benefit to all Western Australians. We of course operate on the basis that all major developments must be subject to rigorous environmental assessment. That would be our attitude in relation to this particular project.

answer.para: The issue as to whether any Commonwealth action, in this instance the support through funds, triggers the Commonwealth legislation is something that will need to be addressed. You might recall in relation to the Commonwealth funding contribution in Tasmania that it was in fact found to trigger Commonwealth legislation and we became a party to that assessment. Of course this project has not got to that stage. The important thing at the moment is that the commitment we have made is subject to proper environmental assessment and that is what we would expect.

talk.start.para: âAs Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting, considering that the state is already involved in environmental assessment, for the minister to suggest that it is not at that stage when the Commonwealth has indicated that it will provide money. When will we know what will be the role of the Commonwealth in environmental assessments and checking whether the project truly has got community support, as I guess those 1,000 people who turned up at the public meeting on several days notice may contest? Also, what is to stop the heritage fund from becoming a slush fund for environmentally unsustainable projects?

âWe do not do anything that is environmentally unsustainable. That is contrary to our objectives. Stop press: I have just been advised that Senator Parer has `just written' to me designating the Western Australian government as a proponent to that proposal. My department will now advise me therefore as to what level of assessment is appropriate and what should be the role of the Commonwealth in that assessment. That will be announced in due course and the appropriate environmental assessments will take place. I think you can be comforted that not only does the Commonwealth want to see a good environmental outcome but the Commonwealth will use its powers to ensure that there is a good environmental outcome.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, are you aware of claims made by the member for Leichhardt, Mr Warren Entsch, as reported in the Canberra Post on 19 November, that he helped push through many submissions for the Natural Heritage Trust fund for his electorate, including one for $31,000 which had initially been rejected. Is this true?
âWhich paper is the `Canberra Post'?
âI did say the Cairns Post . If so, which were the projects Mr Entsch managed to push through?

âI have not seen that reference in the Cairns Post , but I will pursue the matter. It is not unusual for local members to claim personal credit in the event of successful projects whether they be in the environment sphere or elsewhere. I do not knock them for that. What I do know is that some 6,000-odd community groups Australia wide got behind the Commonwealth government in this program and made applications. I am pleasedâI am thrilled, in factâthat we have been able to support over 2,000 of those programs in the first year. When you add that to the state agency programs and to other regional programs it provides a really positive base for what is going to be an exciting and very worthwhile project for the benefit of the whole country.

answer.para: It is under way. Good projects are being supported. That has been our commitmentâthat we will get good value for every taxpayer's dollar, that we will get the most done on the ground as possible, that we will try to support community groups more than has been the case in the past where these grants have tended to be dominated by state government agencies. I am sure when all these factors are brought together we can contribute something to a long-term environmental outcome that has been badly needed by this country.

talk.start.para: âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I take it, Minister, that you are asserting that Mr Entsch falsely claimed credit for securing these grants. If you are not, can you clarify for us: what did Mr Entsch do in terms of contacting your office? Did he have any contact with your office in relation to submissions to the Natural Heritage Trust funding prior to the final decisions being taken? If so, can you detail the contact he had had and the projects he was pushing?

âI can pursue that. I have to say, Madam President, that I received many submissions from politicians, community groups and all sorts of organisations, pressing their case for particular projects. There is nothing illegitimate in that. The normal process was that I sent them off to my department.
âNot many Labor projects.

âNot many from Labor, I have to say. I did get one last week from the shadow Minister for the Environment about his disappointment in relation to one particular unsuccessful project. That is fine. It goes off to the department for analysis to see if a technical error or something else occurred. If there was a technical error, it might be addressed.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo, in actual fact it seems that, in relation to Tasmania, the Labor seats received double the amount that the Liberal seats got, but so be it. That is where the merit must have been because these were decisions that were based on merit and merit alone. (Time expired)

âMy question to the Minister for the Environment relates to the Australian government's outstanding success at the Kyoto climate change meeting in Japan late last year. Everyone here will recall the dire predictions made by the opposition and other prophets of doom ahead of the meetingâthat Australia's position was flawed and that we would be isolated by the rest of the world community. Now that the Labor Party and other parties have been proved absolutely wrong, will you outline the benefits to the Australian environment and economy as a result of the government's outstanding effort?

âI thank the honourable senator for the question. Again, I am a bit shy about raising this because it does contrast individuals, but I remember what was said about Senator Faulkner in relation to this matter as well. Probably other honourable senators remember the article by Helen Trinka in the Australian of 8 April 1995 when she said Australia could have done with some of the heavy hitters of cabinet in Berlin as it struggled to maintain its image as a sophisticated power. That was the hand that Senator Faulkner passed on to the coalition government and, I have to say, a very difficult brief. Nevertheless, it was taken up by the coalition government which sought to achieve through the Kyoto process an outcome that was fair and achievable to Australia, but an outcome that was good for the environment. I am pleased that we were able to achieve those goals.

answer.para: What has come out of Kyoto is an outcome whereby developed countries will in fact be contributing to a very major reduction of greenhouse gases and that should be applauded by all. Furthermore, it is a start. It will be built upon, as the Kyoto process progresses and ultimately developing countries come on board, because you are not going to get the best overall outcome until you have developing countries within the loop as well as the developed.

In relation to the contribution that Australia is making, it has been agreed that Australia's target by 2010 should be an increase of only eight per cent over 1990 levels. The projected increase without that commitment was about 43 per cent. What is being expected of Australia from an environmental challenge is, in fact, something that is very considerable. In fact, the difference between 43 per cent and eight per cent happens to be a little more than what most other developed countries found that they were to commit during this process. So it is an environmentally challenging result that we have accepted.

But, on the other hand, it is also a fair result. It means that we are not going to put hundreds of thousands of Australians out of work, which was the position that the Labor Party originally took. The Labor Party, of course, before the negotiations at Kyoto, actually said that our starting position should be stabilisation at 1990 levels. The advice of DFAT was that that would cost 90,000 Australian jobs. The starting point! They wanted something better than that. I am not sure how many Australian jobs they were prepared to sacrifice, but we know that it was in excess of 90,000. By the time they got to Kyoto, the position had changed slightly, but with each step they criticised our efforts to achieve the fairest outcome for Australia that was consistent with a good environmental goal.

I am pleased, Madam President, that we have achieved a good outcome for the environment. But I am also particularly pleased that we have been able to achieve a good outcome for Australian workers, particularly workers in the areas that would have been hit the hardest: in the Hunter Valley, for example; in theâ

talk.start.para: âWollongong.

âIn the Wollongong areaâall of those coal areas of Australia that have found it difficult in recent times. There is no doubt about that. Their jobs were going to be sacrificed by Labor. The coalition took a position that has meant that their jobs can be saved, yet we can hold our heads high that we have achieved a good environmental outcome and that Australia is making a fair and worthwhile contribution.

âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you are to be congratulated for your fine effort, and I have written to you about that. But could you tell the Senate what the environmental and economic consequences for Australia would have been if the views of the opposition had prevailed?

âI have said that the original position of the Labor Party would have cost 90,000 jobs. They were prepared to sacrifice 90,000 jobs to try to win the favour of certain international green groups. By the time they got to the Kyoto they always took a position that was on the green side of the government's negotiations. It did not help, I might say, being prepared to go out and brief the media to that effect. In fact, it got to the stage where they said we had been offered a five per cent opportunity and our failure to take that would be recorded as the greatest diplomatic failure in Australia's history. Of course, in the end we got eight per centâa better outcome for Australian jobs.

answer.para: It is not surprising that they were the party that resulted in a million Australians being out of work. When it came to the crunch, the green interest groups prevailed over Australian workers' future. Contrast it to the position of the union leadersâColley, for example, who went to Kyoto, who took a much more sensible and pragmatic position. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, my question is in reference to your decision to fund a Natural Heritage Trust project in New South Wales, a project ranked at only 195 and located in the seat of Warringah, which is represented by Mr Tony Abbott. How many of the 60 higher ranking rejected projects were located in Labor-held electorates? Will you table the notes of your departmental officials as to why this variation occurred? Have you finally checked the records to determine if Mr Abbott made any representations to you or your office regarding this project?

âI think the information that was required to be tabled after the estimates committee will provide the information base that the honourable senator is seeking. It is no secretâand I have said it beforeâthat the applications from metropolitan Australia were somewhat disappointing, and I think, in contrastâ

answer.para: Senator Robert Ray interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThey were disappointing in number and they were disappointing in quality. I think the explanation for that is that, not surprisingly, the community understood this to be a program that was being primarily directed at rural and regional Australia, which was true.
âWhat about the Labor electorates? What about the Labor electorates ahead of it?
âFurthermore, within rural and regional Australia you have well structured, well organised and these days really quite professional landcare groups that tended to put in quality applications.
âHow did it get on the list?
âSenator Conroy!

âThat is a problem because it is my view that a proportion of the money being invested in revegetation should be invested within metropolitan areas. That might be part of the explanation that the honourable senator is seeking.
âHow did you move it up the list?

âI don't think you are listening, Senator. That might be part of the explanation that you are seeking. When you have the full detail of that list, you will be able to make that assessment, and that is fair enough.
âWhat about your office records?

âWe accept that we must be accountable for this process. We do not shy away from that. We have set up a comprehensive system of accountability. Ultimately, we are accounted for by the Auditor-General and so we should be. That does not embarrass us.
âWhere does Winston fit into that level?
âSenator Conroy, this is your question. You should listen to the answer.

âBut some on the other side are saying that we should not just seek to achieve the outcomes that I have said. We are committed to getting the best value for the taxpayer's dollar. We are committed to getting the best outcome on the ground in terms of environmental achievement. We are prepared to make the decisions that we are responsible to make under the legislation. We are not just a rubber stamp. We are not just going to rubber stamp what the states say or even what the regional groups say. We will stand by the judgments that we make because at the end of the day we know that it will start to address these weaknesses in our natural resource management system that have been evident for so long and that Labor disregarded for 13 years. So we accept our responsibility.

answer.para: We are proud of this program. It will grow and it will be even better in the future. Future generations will look back and say, `We're glad that at least one government, the coalition government under Mr Howard, had the courage to tackle the real problems and to do it in a way that was to provide some long-term benefits.'

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, in the list of successful Natural Heritage Trust fund grants money has gone to projects with very questionable environmental outcomes and often to projects which would normally be funded by other federal and state budgets.
âHow do you know?
âAccording to whom?
âOrder! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. Please continue, Senator Allison.

âFor example, the grant for the 1993 spring floods program for urban areas of Melbourne and the numerous NHT grants for levee banks and other flood mitigation schemes. Minister, how about the $46,000 for expanding cane production in Queensland? Isn't it the case that there is $10.5 million available in the sugar industry infrastructure program of which, as I understand it, only one-third has been spent? Minister, aren't you misleading Australians when you say that the NHT is new money for the environment when so much is going to programs which should be funded by Commonwealth and state budgets?

âThere is a number of parts to that, but it is true that we have made a real effort to avoid filling the gap of other state or Commonwealth responsibilities. Basically, we have said that the Natural Heritage Trust is to build upon existing programs and, as I have said, we have made real effort to avoid cost shiftingâI think greater effort to avoid cost shifting than has ever occurred in the pastâand it has not pleased everyone.

answer.para: It is possible to analyse every application and every grant. If honourable senators want to do that, they can do it. As I said, the Labor Party has asked for details of all 6,000 applications. They will, no doubt, seek to do what Senator Allison has done in shorthand in this question.

The honourable senator must appreciate also that this program is a partnership between good environmental outcomes and sustainable agriculture. We have brought together the objectives of seeking to build productive Australia from an economic point of view with productive Australia from an ecological point of view. We have done that because we say that the distinction is really artificial. If you eat into the capital of your natural resources, you will ultimately eat into your capacity to maximise your economic outcome. So we have drawn both streams together to achieve that goal.

I can understand that, when the honourable senator refers to landcare projects and some of the rivercare projects, for example, as opposed to bushcare projects, she will see the traditional emphasis on the sustainable agri culture. Over time that distinction will disappear as the two strains of thought, the two different cultures and the two different administrations both at the Commonwealth level, where we are making great progress, and at the state level, where less progress is being made, are finally brought together. It is only when they are finally brought together that we will, in fact, maximise the benefit from both an ecological point of view and from an economic point of view of our great natural resources in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you referred to landcare and bushcare projects, but how do you explain funding going to treated waste water on the Bright golf course? Isn't it a state or a local government responsibility to fund the disposal of sewage waste water? Aren't there already plenty of other golf courses doing much the same thing? Minister, how can you possibly stretch watering a golf course to the Natural Heritage Trust fund? Minister, can I suggest that we should rename the NHT the `green cost shifting scheme', or will you keep your promise to Australians that this is new money for the environment?

âIt is a $1.1 billion fund which is new money. We have had to sell part of a Commonwealth asset to achieve that fund. It is a reinvestment of national capitalâin that instance, capital that was obtained through the part sale of Telstraâtowards the dual objectives that I said of better environmental outcomes and sustainable primary production. That is what this is all about. So clearly that is new money.

answer.para: As I said, we are making every endeavour to avoid substitution for previous programs. That is what we want to do because we would actually like to see this fund grow to something that is larger. We want to see greater non-government contributions. We want to see greater contributions from the states. We were pleased with what we were able to encourage the states to contribute in the first year, but they should know that we will be going back to them in the future and looking for them to contribute even more. Out of that we have achieved the objectives that we so clearly set out for the Australian people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âYesterday in question time, Senator Bolkus asked me what day I had asked Mr Callinan QC for advice. I checked my diaries and it was 6 November 1996. I can confirm that the advice was given pro bono.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âSenator Ray asked me a question yesterday, which I said I would check, about an apparent inconsistency between the answer on 4 February to question No. 1050 from Senator Collins on 19 December and the evidence given to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee last week in relation to some focus group testing of a possible advertisement recently undertaken by Brian Sweeney and Associates. The evidence to the committee confirmed that Sweeney and Associates had been engaged in late January to do the focus group testing, whereas the answer on 4 February to Senator Collins's question indicated that no opinion research of any kind on reconciliation or other issues had been undertaken since previous work by Sweeney and Associates in 1996.

answer.para: I would also like to correct yesterday's Hansard. It said I first became aware of it when I was asked this question at estimates. What I had said was `when the question was asked in estimates'. It was not asked of me, as Senator Ray knows, because I was not present at that estimates.

The reason for the apparent inconsistency is that Sweeney and Associates was engaged between the time the proposed answer was submitted for my approval and the time the approved answer was tabled. The agency handling the answer, that is ATSIC, was not the same as the agency handling Sweeney's engagement, that is the Prime Minister and Cabinet. In addition I, like Senator Ray, was a bit concerned that I was not aware of this, and I had forgotten that during January I was on leave. I returned to the office on 27 January. So just to clarify it from Senator Ray's point of view and the Senate's point of view, the relevant dates are as follows.

On 19 December, Senator Collins placed the question on notice. On 23 December, ATSIC commenced its coordination and preparation of the answer. Then on 15 January, ATSIC liaised with PM&C and was advised that no research subsequent to Sweeney and Associates 1996 work had been commissioned by PM&C. Then on 27 January, ATSIC submitted the proposed answer, as finally tabled, for my approval, and I signed it off on 27 January on my return. Then on 30 January, Prime Minister and Cabinet commissioned Sweeney to undertake focus group testing. On 4 February, ATSIC arranged lodgment of the previously approved answer to Senator Collins's question. So I think that clarifies it and it illustrates once again that Senator Ray is constantly at work checking the veracity of all answers given. I commend him for that.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI was asked if I would table the application for grants from the Yallobup Creek catchment, which I will. I do not have it with me, so I have asked for it to be brought in. I saw it for the first time this morning after I called for it when I read that little piece in the Canberra Times .

answer.para: By way of explanation, the secretary of the group, as referred to in the application, was a Dianne Crane. I asked of her. She apparently is a sister-in-law of Senator Winston Crane. She had a different property. She had clearly been involved in the catchment group because she signed as secretary of the group.

talk.start.para: âIt gets murkier and murkier.
âListen. She sold her property, I am instructed, before the application was assessed. So she does not gain any benefit either.

answer.para: Honourable senators will see from the application that there is also a page of signa tories of each of the families that supported the application. These are the families in the catchment group. There is one signatureâN. Crane. I sought further information of that, and I understand that it is believed to be the daughter-in-law of Senator Winston Crane.

As I said in my answer today, Senator Crane in relation to his family did not seek funding and is not getting funding. He did not at all relevant times know that the application had even been made by this longstanding community group. I obtained a brief statement from the Secretary-Treasurer of the Yallobup Creek Catchment Group Inc. which corroborates what I have just said and I will table that in conjunction with the application agreement.

talk.start.para: âMadam Presidentâ
âI call Senator Crane.
âMadam President, I seek leaveâ
âAre you seeking leave on the same matter?
âNo, I am not seeking leave, I am taking note of an answer.
âI have not called to take note of answers yet.

âMadam President, on a point of order: as you are aware, it is normal for you to call for taking note of answers. It is unusual, but not improper, for the leader or for a minister to receive the callâSenator Hill sought leave and it was granted; and that is a normal course of action. But this is a government backbencher, and I really think the Leader of the Opposition ought be accorded the courtesy of receiving the call.

âHe would be in relation to taking note of answers. I do not even know what Senator Crane is seeking the call about at this stage, and he would probably need leave to do it in any event. Senator Crane?
âMadam President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
âIs leave granted?
âAfter taking note.
âLeave is not granted at this time. It will be granted after taking note of answers.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the principals of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co.

It is clear from a search of the company records of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. that at least 17 members of the Baillieu family are involved or have been involved with the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. or associated companies. It is also true that most of those associated companies use the same registered company address as the Woodhouse Pastoral Co., which is 360 Collins Street, Melbourne.

It is also true that Mr John Madden Baillieu is one of the four current directors of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. I might say that Who's Who also identifies him as the Chairman of EL&C Baillieu Ltd which donated $50,500 to the Liberal Party in the past two years. There was a donation of $20,500 to the Victorian division in 1996, a donation of $20,000 nationally in 1996 and a donation of $10,000 to the Victorian division in 1997. A total of $50,500 was donated by the chairman of this company who is one of the four current directors of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co.

Do not forget it is just a coincidence that the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. was one of those successful grants that was accepted after this extraordinary process where, apparently, a member of Senator Hill's office staffâbut Senator Hill today has taken responsibilityâdirected the Department of the Environment to look again at the Victorian regional assessment panel process and, as a result of that, three grants were approved. One of those grants was to the Woodhouse Pastoral Co.

Two other persons associated with the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. also list their individual addresses at 360 Collins Street, Melbourne: Mr Maurice Howard Lawrence Baillieu, a previous director, and Mr Richard Percy Clive Baillieu, the current secretary. Not only was $50,500 donated by EL&C Baillieuâand I have talked about the principals of that companyâto the Liberal Party but also, extraordinarily enough, the same director of the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. made a personal donation, according to the returns we have available from the AEC, of $2,400 in 1995.

You do not have to be a genius mathematician to be able to add $2,400 to $50,500. Lo and behold, what does it add up to? The amount of $52,900. What was the grant given to the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. through Senator Hill's shonky process? What was the value of the grant? It was $52,900. When I found this out, I thought it was just a balancing item for the Liberal Party.

The reason this grant was agreed to by the Commonwealth government is that Senator Hill's office instructed the department to rejig the process. Three grants were approved through that reassessment process directed by Senator Hill's office, and one of them was the Baillieu family Woodhouse Pastoral Co. grant.

We want to know from Senator Hillâhe refused to answer in question time but he has taken responsibilityâwho in his office directed this department to do this and when those particular directions were made. We want to know what the full details are about the Baillieu grant as well as discussions between Senator Hill's office and his department about the Baillieu grant prior to the department's recommendation that it be approved. We want to know about those representations and we want to know as soon as possible. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAnother low point in the Labor Party's smear campaign in this particular chamber. Not only do they continue to smear the Baillieu family but they also smear Senator Crane and then will not even give him permission to reply to those smears. That is the sort of action we get from the Labor Party.

speech.para: The Labor Party are not interested in the environment. They are determined to bring down the Natural Heritage Trust and all the good things that it has done for the environment because, in 13 years, they could not do a thing for it. They judge everyone by the way they act. They remember the Centenary House fiasco. Centenary House, the Labor Party headquarters, was given by their government a guaranteed rental. For how long? Ten years, Senator Ray? It was for ten years with a 15 per cent increase on rentalâand you talk about this sort of smear!

The Labor Party are used to doing this. You know how it is done. Your government was full of this sort of campaign. You transferred money to the Labor Party, transferred money to the union movement and then got them to donate it back to you. Just because you did that, just because that is your way of doing things, that does not mean to say that the Democrats do it that way, the Greens do it that way, the National Party do it that way or the Liberal Party do it that way. You may do it that way, but we do not. Do not judge others by yourselves.

Having said that, I know Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner have received a direct and personal benefit from the Natural Heritage Trustâin fact, so has every senator in this chamber. That is because the Natural Heritage Trust goes about doing things for the ecology, for the environment. It will end up giving us better clean air, better rivers, purer waterâ

talk.start.para: âOh yes; clean air!

âthe sorts of things we all take advantage of. We all take a direct and personal advantage from that. That is what the Natural Heritage Trust is all about: $1.25 billion is being put into the environment to make your air cleaner, Senator Carr. To clean up the air around your mouth would take a lot of money, but we are prepared to do that with $1.25 billion.

speech.para: Every senatorâin fact, every person in Australiaâreceives a direct and personal benefit from the Natural Heritage Trust. There have been all these allegations of favouritism. As has been pointed out, it was the New South Wales government that wanted more money for the Murray-Darling scheme and, I understand, some electorates that are represented very well in this parliament by the Deputy Prime Minister. It was the New South Wales government that asked for that money.

There have been a lot of allegations of a process. The Labor Party were in the chamber when this parliament dealt with the Natural Heritage Trust Bill. That bill requires the ministers or the boardâwhich comprises the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energyâto make decisions on these things. The bill did not say that some group in the north of Queensland or some group in the west of Victoria should make decisions on behalf of this government. Senator Hill and Mr Anderson were given that specific power. On the allegations that there is some want of process, the chairman of the Natural Heritage Trust Board, Sir James Hardy, said:
I can't believe, given the number of assessment panels that applications must pass through, that it can be `green barrelling'.

I will go further and repeat what the conservation groups across Australia said. They released a letter to the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, and Mr Anderson which endorses the intervention of the Commonwealth Natural Heritage Trust Board in the assessment of project applications. They endorsed the decision taken by the Commonwealth and HT board to be a joint decision maker with the states in restructuring the assessment panel. The Queensland Conservation Council also praised Senator Hill and Mr Anderson for their assessment and their choice of projects.

This is just another part of the campaign by the Labor Party. They are not interested in the environment. They are annoyed and enraged by the fact that this coalition government is the only government in history that has been prepared to put such a major financial investment into the environment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis particular matter comes under interest because it did not go through the normal processes; this particular grant we are talking about did not come through the normal processes. We do not even know to this day whether the department had a repre sentative on their regional assessment panel in this case. No-one has told us that. If they did, they were there to give advice about eligibility. But what a great coincidence that Victoria is the main concentration of a reassessment of rejected grants. Who started this process? It was certainly not the department because, if you go to page 56 of Mr Campbell's evidence, it says:

speech.para: The question is: did you give advice to Senator Hill to re-examine the status of these grants prior to him or a staff member asking you to re-examine them?
Mr Campbell's response:
No.

So the initiative came from the minister's office, not on the direct advice of the department. It came from Senator Hill's staff member, apparently without reference to Senator Hill. You do delegate authorityâI understand thatâbut it seems that, for some reason, one of Senator Hill's staffers got the bright idea, `Why don't we reassess all these ones in this particular area?' So they reassessed 147 and, lo and behold, suddenly three make it back onto the list. We do not know what contact there was between Senator Hill's office and the department to discuss this particular process.

It is not smearing to say that a lot of the members of Woodhouse are members of the Liberal Party. It is not smearing to say they share the same office building at 360 Collins Street with a whole range of other integrated companies. It is not smearing to say that the directors of Woodhouse and the company that made the large donation to the Liberal Party are one and the same. So it is of no use for Senator Hill to say that the person that manages this is not in the Liberal PartyâI accept thatâbut a whole range of the others are. Of all the great coincidences in the world, we were very puzzled when we added up the donation. We kept coming up short. It was paid out at poker machine levels only. You put in $20,500 to the Victorian branch, you whacked another $20,000 up to the federal secretariat here, then you plonked another ten grand in the Victorian branch and it comes to $50,500.

Well, what happened to the $2,400? This puzzled us for hours today. How come they did not get a full payout? Mugsâwe are mugs. We forgot to search the individual donations. So we found the person that paid the cheques for the $50,500 in the individual donations. It does not say much for my comments about Senator Calvert the other dayâhe is a nearby neighbour of mine. I will not put the person's address on the record, but I will put his name: and that is J.M. Baillieu. He fronts up for $2,400. When you add that to the $50,500, that is exactly the same amount as the grant this mob got.

What a great payout! You knock off one per cent in blackjack, five per cent in roulette, 13 per cent in poker machines, 15 per cent in the TAB and 41 per cent in Lotto. But the good old Liberal Party pays out at 100 per cent every time. The $52,900 you stick in you get back. You only get it back, provided there has been interference from the minister's office to make sure the particular grant is re-established after it fell at the first hurdle of the raceâwith the regional assessment panel which had ruled it ineligible. But it is put back in by big hitters in the Liberal Party.

No wonder we have got questions about coincidence in this. It is not McCarthyism or smear; all the links are there. They are there for anyone to see who wants to walk down and have a look in 360 Collins Streetâas we had someone have a look this afternoonâat all the interconnected companies there. It was $52,900 into the Liberal Party, $52,900 out. I think they picked that figure for the grant of $52,900 to rub all our noses in it. It was an insider's joke to set it at that particular level because none of us would ever catch on to it. Well, we have caught onto it and you are not going to rub our noses in it. It is a very sick joke to have that exact figure.

talk.start.para: âI wish to take note of the question asked by Senator Faulkner of Senator Hill on the Natural Heritage Trust. The Natural Heritage Trust is the greatest financial commitment that has ever been made by a government to the environment in Australia's history. The $1.25 billion will be used for landcare, for bushcare, for rivercare, a commitment to land and conservation for the Murray-Darling catchment, and for com munity groups that range from very important and large groups right down to schoolchildren. When you consider that only 1.17 per cent of the Australian land mass is now held by the Labor Party it is not surprising that the greatest amount of money under the Natural Heritage Trust has gone to coalition electorates.

speech.para: The key points need to be made that 95 per cent of the funds have gone to 99 per cent of Australia; that the state assessment panels recommended that over 90 per cent of funds should go to rural areas and that is precisely where the money has gone; that close scrutiny given to projects by the ministerial board did not make any difference to the political distribution of grants, but did result in more projects going to community groups for on-ground works and less going to state government bureaucracies; and lastly, that the Australian environment movement has endorsed the ministerial board's close scrutiny given to the projects recommended by the state assessment panel.

As the duty senator for the New South Wales rural seats of Calare and Hunter, I am really pleased with the generous allocation of natural heritage funding to these electorates. I am very proud the government has kept its promise to make that commitment to regional areas in Australia.

In the seat of Calare, which is held by an independent, Peter Andren, over $1.5 million was allocated under the fund, and with more to come. And I do not believe that people in Bathurst and in the regional areas of Lithgowâareas which received $200,000 each for their flood mitigation schemesâwould believe that there was any rort in the allocation of these grants. Far from it: they would agree that this money had been properly spent in the interests of all Australians.

In his recent newspaper column, Joel Fitzgibbon, who holds the Hunter electorate for the Labor Party, alleged that Labor electorates were awarded an average of $94,325. Well, he has very little to complain about, because his electorate received around $330,000 for 11 community projects. He cannot take very much credit for this allocation of funds. They have been granted to very major projects in restoration of mines but also right down to the very lowest level of schoolchildren in primary schools who wished to take an interest in their local stream or community.

It is a terrifically broad-based allocation of funds. It is in the interests of all of us and we are very pleased to be able to do it, because it will be something that goes on, right into the next century and beyond. It is an area of government expenditure which everybody agrees is important.

It really does not stand any question about why the funds are going to regional areas because, as I said before, the Labor Party now hold only three regional seats out of 40 in regional Australia and they cover 1.17 per cent of the Australian land mass. There has not been any whiteboard. It might be very hard for the Labor Party to believe this, because I know the way they operated in government. We have spent the money where it is needed. We do not believe the leafy suburbs of Sydney or the parks of Melbourne are areas where NHT money should be spent. It should be spent in regional Australia, and that is where it has been.

The sale of Telstra has enabled this government to tackle the big environmental problems. No other Australian government has done that. It has done that in a way which has provided a win-win situation for investors who took out a share of Telstra and also for the community at large in the way the money has been spent on the environment. It is in the interests of everybody in the city and in the country to solve the big problems of the environment. Farmers, landcare groups and rural communities have waited years for this money. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âObviously, there are serious problems and questions to be answered surrounding the processes related to the trust fund. Today, the Democrats raise what we think are important questions about how this money is being spent. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) says that it is new money because no-one has spent it before, which is an extraordinarily disingenuous response to my question. Of course, no-one has spent it before. The question is whether it should have been coming out of existing federal and state budgets.

speech.para: The minister says that Landcare and bushcare projects will merge and somehow improve the economy. I am not here today to analyse those projects, as he suggests, or to make any judgments about the value of those individual projects. The questions are: do we have a problem here with cost shifting with the states? Do we have money coming out of the fund and being used for projects when there is other Commonwealth money around which could and should be used for that purpose?

The original proposal for the NHT was for additional money, and that was to be spent on top of existing environmental funding. It is patently clear that this promise of the government's has been broken. This is despite the Democrats asking the government to prove, over the passage of the legislation, that this was the case. Despite our repeated requests for the minister to prove this in estimates over two years, the government has never been able to show that it has spent one extra cent; in fact, it appears to be spending far less than it previously did. It also appears that money is going to pork-barrel coalition seats, which, obviously, can only be called into question.

Returning to those projects which ought to have been funded elsewhere: the purpose of the 1993 spring floods program in my home state of Victoria is to carry out flood strategies for urban areas in Melbourne following the 1993 spring floods. Why is the NHT being used? Why isn't it an urban water program? Why isn't it the responsibility of Melbourne Water, which normally looks after such flood mitigation projects? Why is the Commonwealth involved at all, when its budget statements say that there will be reduced capital works activities in these areas and, in particular, those ones that are supporting the infrastructure and sewage treatment projects? These are the projects which primarily are undertaken by state and territory government agencies.

Why is money going into property management plans like the farmsmart property man agement campaigns to focus on farming as a business, or the Cattlemen's Union with a quarter of a million dollars over four years for the so-called `future profits' program? Isn't it the case that there is other money available for agribusiness programs? I do not question the value of these projects. I am simply saying that there is other money available which should have been used for them.

What about the $46,000 for expanding the cane production areas in Queensland? Isn't it the case that $10Â½ million is available in the sugar industry infrastructure program and that only one-third of that so far has been spent? Why is it, when there are other programs being funded that seem eminently more suitable for these sorts of programs, that money is coming out of the NHT?

Here is another one: water to put waste water on the Bright golf course. This is something I mentioned in my question. How can the government possibly justify that? Is the government going to use NHT to water golf courses right around Australia? Is this what we will be looking at in the future?

The Democrats, including my colleagues Senator John Woodley, Senator Meg Lees and me, have tried and tried to get some sense out of this government over this whole question. We asked hundreds of questions last year and this year in estimates. Those questions, by and large, have gone unanswered. In fact, the minister admitted during estimates that he had no way of knowing what the state governments had spent in the previous year on environment programs and no way of knowing whether their spending had been reduced. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak to the motion to take note of the answers given today on the Natural Heritage Trust by Senator Hill. What has been lost today and also in question time yesterday in the opposition's and, sadly, the Democrats' desperate search for the 1998 equivalent of the Ros Kelly memorial whiteboard and the slush fund that went with it is the coalition's real and genuine concern for issues improving our environment.

speech.para: By any measure, the Labor Party failed disastrously to make any real difference to the major environmental concerns that face Australia. In addressing our continent's land and water degradation crisis, Labor failed. In fixing Australia's rising water tables, salinity, soil erosion and noxious weeds, Labor failed. In preventing the spread of feral animals, Labor failed. In addressing the increasing problem of toxic blue-green algae, Labor failed. In addressing the major environmental issues facing this nation, Labor failedâabsolutely failed.

talk.start.para: âTurn the page!

âI hope you are listening, Senator Evans. We now know there was no memorial whiteboard because, if there had been, it would have been as big as a tennis court to have held all the items that former minister Kelly claimed to have put on it.

speech.para: The Natural Heritage Trust is a genuine attempt to address Australia's real environmental problems. The major environmental groups recognised the quality of the Natural Heritage Trust package when they responded to the policy in the lead-up to the election. When endorsing the coalition's environmental policy, Jim Downey of the Australian Conservation Foundation said, `We welcome the fact that the coalition regards the environment as a core policy issue for Australia.'
