talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 6.50 p.m., I call on the consideration of government documents.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This annual report refers to the Tiwi Land Council, which is a unique and special Aboriginal Land Council situated on the Tiwi Islands just to the north of Darwin. Year after year in this chamber I have drawn attention to the uniqueness of that community and the excellent work that has been undertaken by the Tiwi Land Council on behalf of its constituency members who live on what are generally known as the Bathurst and Melville islands. The Tiwi Land Council is a small organisation. It enjoys a very good accounting process, a very strong accountability, and looks after a wide range of activities on behalf of the people who live on the Tiwi Islands.

There are a number of matters referred to in this report that I would draw to the attention of my colleagues, particularly those that naturally affect issues relating to Aboriginal land, whether they are to do with culture, heritage, sacred sites and the processes that go with them. They extend into other important areas, such as health, training and employment, tourism occupations and freight and pearling. This small community that is so intimately involved and so successful certainly deserves commending.

I will not seek leave to speak at a later time this evening, but I also notice that document No. 4 relates to the annual report for 1996-97 of the Anindilyakwa Land Council, situated on Groote Eylandt. Similar to the Tiwi Land Council, the land council on Groote Eylandt is almost as successful. It concentrates on Aboriginal land management issues and whilst, in my opinion, that community has more social problems than the Tiwi Islands, it is very interesting to note that the business range of activities covers fishing, turtle breeding, involvements with Telstra, mining negotiations and rehabilitation, but they also concentrate on many of the issues relating to the social dimension of that community.

It is interesting to note that the finances of both these organisations are well structured and well maintained. In a moment, when the next report is tabled, I will make some more specific comments with regard to other land councils and current reviews that are being undertaken in the Northern Territory. I would single out for particular commendation and reference the reports of both the Tiwi Land Council and the Anindilyakwa Land Council.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The northern and central land councils, historically, are much longer established community organisations in the Northern Territory. Because of the geographic spread of their area of influence in the Northern Territory, it is very important to look carefully at these accounts.

Many senators will be aware that, for a number of years, I have often been critical of the accountability processes of both the northern and the central land councils, in particular those of the Northern Land Council. I am pleased to note that this financial year there has been a major improvement in the administration and accountability of, in particular, the Northern Land Council. In perusing this particular report, it is interesting to note that it is nowhere near as party political or partisan political as the Northern Land Council has previously been on other reports.

I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate a very important review that is currently under way and commissioned by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herronâthat is, a review by John Reeves QC into a range of matters relating to the administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That particular review is now part heard, and I am certainly very well aware that Mr Reeves has been engaged in a very extensive series of consultations with a range of government agencies, other Aboriginal organisations and Aboriginal communities right throughout the Northern Territory.

In looking at the travel itineraries of Mr Reeves, I certainly would not want to be trying to achieve what he is doing in a six-, eight- or 10-week period. It is a mammoth task, and I know from copies that I have received of much of the material that has been made available to the commissioner that this is a very serious and determined inquiry.

I have had a range of discussions with Aboriginal organisations in the Northern Territory, in particular. Many of them are looking very much at the issues to be raised by Mr Reeves in his final report which relate to the whole impact of the land rights legislation, whether it is social, cultural or economic, whether it relates to exploration and mining or whether it relates to the administration of the royalty trust accounts or the application of the Northern Territory laws. There are a huge number of issues to be addressed. In particular, as I said, I am well aware that the fiefdoms that have previously been maintained by the northern and central land councils may not survive because many Aboriginal communities are saying either on a matter of regionalisation or on a matter of practical administration that there are just so many other areas that ought to be addressed.

In fact, this afternoon I had consultations here in Canberra with representatives of the Jawoyn Association, largely headquartered in the Katherine region or the area just to the north. In those areasâand I am sure that the delegates would not mind my saying thisâthe range of areas that they see as needing regional agreements and priorities relate to law and order, economic development, employment, trade, land management, health, housing, community development, education, local government and sport. These are areas where the Jawoyn certainly see major need for change.

Mr Robert Lee, the Chairman of the Jawoyn Association, left with me a copy of the Jawoyn Association's submission to the review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. It makes very interesting reading because it certainly looks for changes in land rights legislation from an Aboriginal perspective. It canvasses many practical applications. It looks very much at the successful operation of what the Jawoyn have achieved and draws out many parallels for change. I hope that Mr Reeves, in his moving around the Northern Territory, will be able to judge the northern and central land councils against this important criteria of both the wider Northern Territory community and the expectation of Aborigines in the Northern Territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âThe consideration of documents has now concluded, and I put the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak about an article in the Courier-Mail yesterday which I found deeply disturbing. The article detailed a study conducted by the Council to Homeless Persons which revealed that almost 30,000 people in Queensland are homeless. The tragedy is that this figure underestimates the total number of homeless people because it includes only those using homeless services. The study stated that 147,000 people are using homeless services nationwide and found that, in the 1996-97 financial year, there were a further 304,000 requests for assistance from homeless services that were not met. This represents twice as many people who are actually helped by the homeless services.

speech.para: There are several tragic revelations in this report, including that throughout Australia over 38,000 young people between the ages of 15 and 24 used homeless services during the year. A further 69 per cent of homeless youth were not in education at the time of using the homeless service. Moreover, homeless families data include 25,000 adults and 46,000 children. Furthermore, of the 48,500 women using homeless services, just under 50 per cent, which is 21,000 women, were escaping domestic violence. Included in this figure are 8,000 homeless Queensland women, 4,500 of whom cited domestic violence or sexual and emotional abuse as the reasons for their dire situation.

A further feature of concern in the study is the over-representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people amongst the ranks of the homeless. They represent 12 per cent of people using homeless services, despite comprising only two per cent of the entire population of Australia.

The Council to Homeless Persons has rightly identified unemployment as the major impediment to kerbing Australia's homeless numbers. As education is crucial to future employability, the statistic that 69 per cent of homeless youth were not in education or training is of particular concern, in terms of the ability of young homeless people to access employment in the long term when their homeless situation is resolved.

Rather than attempting to assist these people, the Howard government has cut just about every available lifeline they could access, such as the proposal to abolish income support to 16- and 17-year-olds who are not in education and training, and the introduction of a parental income and assets test for unemployed 18- to 20-year-olds. Furthermore, there are the forthcoming changes to employment service provider arrangements whereby Australia's free employment service will give way to large private providers not interested in homeless people who need considerable attention before they are job ready.

While the Commonwealth-state supported accommodation assistance program is obviously working well and covering a number of people in need, it is clear that further support and additional initiatives are needed from governments to attack the causes of homelessness. It has traditionally been Labor governments which have developed these initiatives. Many in this parliament will well remember the coalition parties' politically inspired beat-up when the previous Labor government attempted to initiate welfare payments for homeless youth to ease their circumstances. It is time conservative governments challenged their stereotype reaction to homeless people. The vast majority are not in this predicament solely as a result of their own failings.

The Council to Homeless Persons data reveals that financial difficulties, domestic violence, family and relationship breakdowns are the major reasons people become homeless. The most tragic revelation from this study is that of family homelessness. Due to shortages of affordable housing, high unemployment and increased family poverty, family homelessness in Australia is increasing dramatically. An area of major concern is the data that shows almost half of the 46,000 homeless children nationally are under five years old. Obviously, this impacts enormously on a child's psychological, educational and physical wellbeing.

What is particularly distressingâand we should all be concerned about thisâis that it appears that the cycle of homelessness is being passed on to succeeding generations with little difficulty. Unfortunately, there are too few resources and initiatives to break the cycle. Many families do not know how to make a bed or use kitchen appliances as they have never experienced a home environment.

The Council to Homeless Persons data echoes many of the issues raised in a recent St Vincent de Paul study. As the largest community based provider of services to homeless people in Queensland, the St Vincent de Paul organisation has found that nine out of 10 men were homeless due to financial difficulty, eight out of 10 women were homeless due to domestic violence, and six out of 10 homeless people were aged between 25 and 44 years.

What is clear from the research is that the old image of a homeless person as an elderly male of scruffy appearance and with a bottle of booze in his hands is now ancient history. The average age of the homeless person has dropped to around 30 years. Those people are presenting a raft of problems to community care organisations as they are prone to mental illness, substance abuse, financial problems and relationship breakdowns. These people are regarded as high maintenance by community care organisations that barely have sufficient funds to meet basic shelter needs and are showing signs of buckling under the strain.

My attention has been alerted to one such organisation, the Albert and Logan Community Care Centre, which provides emergency accommodation and housing for sole parents in the Beenleigh and Logan areas south of Brisbane. This organisation has been forced to turn people away on a weekly basis due to the unavailability of resources. I urge the new Queensland Minister for Families and Community Care to focus on providing financial support and creative initiatives for organisations like this one. Hopefully, the new minister will prove more capable in this area than her recently departed predecessorâsacked Minister Kevin Lingard, who was out of his depth in this field.

Coalition governments have one last chance in Queensland and at the federal level to show they now have a commitment to social and community welfare. If they fail to use the great advantages and opportunities incumbent government presents they will forever be branded as political ostriches with their heads in the sand on homelessness and community care issues.

talk.start.para: âAt the start of this parliamentary year one of the recurring issues that is trotted out for public gaze is the level of federal funding for health and the role of the states in delivering health services, especially so in my state of New South Wales. It is an issue which generates a great deal of misinformation. In New South Wales the Carr government is constantly trying to avoid scrutiny of its own mismanagement of health by blaming the Commonwealth for any shortcomings and shortfalls in the New South Wales health budget. This week Labor is at it again.

speech.para: Public hospital waiting lists in New South Wales for elective surgery topped 50,000 for the first time. There were calls, yet again, for the New South Wales health minister, Dr Refshauge, to resign. The only excuse he can think of is that the blame lies with the Commonwealth. It is a pretty lame excuse and it is an excuse that simply does not stand up to scrutiny.

First of all, the states have a great deal of autonomy in how they use Commonwealth funds granted to the states. Under the present arrangements, the states and territory governments determine the total funds available for public hospitals, budgets for individual hospitals, the number and location of hospitals, and the services available for hospitals. They determine the level of service, the areas of service and the needs of their constituents. The Commonwealth provides the funds and the states attend to their distribution.

But much of the argument about health funding relates not to the Commonwealth health distributions but to how state treasuries actually allocate financial assistance grants. These are non-specific purpose grants from the Commonwealth, and it is up to the states to determine how they are actually allocated. But the state health bodies argue their share of these funds should be in the same proportion as the share they get from the state budget. Therefore, if a state health department receives, say, 25 per cent of the budget, it argues it should receive 25 per cent of the financial assistance grants made available by the Commonwealth to that state.

But, not surprisingly, the state treasuries do not always see it that way and in the continuing battle for funds the Commonwealth is often targeted unjustifiably as being responsible for holding back funds to state health bodies. Spats between state bodies are harming health services and nowhere is this sort of harm more evident than in New South Wales.

As I said, latest figures in New South Wales indicate elective surgery waiting lists have now topped 50,000 for the first time. There are now 50,778 people waiting for surgery and, just as alarmingly, 4,602 people have been waiting 12 months or more. Those who do manage to have surgery without waiting the 12 months or more still have to cool their heals for an average of 1Â½ months compared with only 27 days a few months ago. But like an oft repeated mantra, the Carr government has blamed what it claims are Commonwealth funding cuts for this situation.

But the Carr government simply ignores the facts. In 1995 to 1996 Commonwealth outlays on New South Wales hospital services was $1.65 billion, up from $1.3 billion in 1990 to 1991 and just under one-third of the $5 billion national total. The New South Wales slice of the total Commonwealth health services cake was $6.1 billion in 1995 to 1996, up from $4.4 billion in 1990 to 1991. Again, the slice represents almost one-third of the national total of $18.6 billion.

The Commonwealth's contribution has increased every year. Yet Mr Carr and Dr Refshauge continue to claim that these problems are the result of claimed Commonwealth funding cuts. This is totally incorrect, and it is timely to examine the level of funds provided by both the Commonwealth and the states to see where the financial burdens actually lie.

Under the 1988 to 1993 Medicare agreements, total Commonwealth hospital funding grants to states rose to $3.933 million from $3.80 million in 1988-89, a three per cent rise each year in real terms. In 1993 to 1998, Medicare agreements maintained the funding and indexation components of the previous agreements while adding new funding components, the implementation of which resulted in an additional $2 billion in Commonwealth funds for hospitals over five years. It is quite clear already from these figures that the Commonwealth is meeting its commitments and that the Commonwealth has continued to inject funds into the Australian health system.

In the 1992-93 budget, the Commonwealth injected an additional $1.6 billion into hospital funding over six years. Following the Premiers Conference in 1993-94, it was raised to $2 billion as a result of the agreement to pay New South Wales and Victoria Medicare guarantees. These payments honoured the Commonwealth's guarantee to the two states that they would receive increased financial assistance grants. These amounted to $131 million for New South Wales and $112 million for Victoria. The net result of these factors was that Commonwealth funding to the states increased by about $500 million, or 11 per cent, in 1993 to 1994 and a further $216 million, or three per cent, in 1994 to 1995.

In sharp contrast to the Commonwealth's contribution, state funding for public hospitals has failed to show any steady growth. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has researched the funding and found the states contribution to health funding has been maintained at 1990-91 levels over the five years to 1996. On the other side of the coin, the Commonwealth's contribution has risen more than 30 per cent in the same period. Of course hospital funding has fared no better from the states. It, too, has been maintained at 1990-91 levels while the Commonwealth's contribution has risen by about 25 per cent.

This trend is confirmed by analysis published by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare which shows that the Commonwealth share of expenditure on public hospitals rose to 49 per cent in 1994 to 1995 from 42 per cent in 1989 to 1990. In the same period, the states share fell to 42 per cent from 47 per cent. Under the current 1997-98 budget estimate, Commonwealth payments to the states under the Medicare agreement rose $175 million, or 1.5 per cent. Of this, 99.9 per cent was for the states with only $7.2 million being for national projects. The funding then, despite some claims to the contrary, was not reduced but was maintained at the funding levels of the previous budget. I will not go into the problems that the Commonwealth has experienced with cost shifting.

The next round of hospital funding grants will not be finalised until June this year. It gives us some time to review some of the central issues, including the collection of a full year's data to determine the extent of cost shifting, investigation of strategies and devices to monitor the extent of the practice, and it could include measures such as an independent survey of doctors on the subject of cost shifting, a GPs cost shift audit through the accreditation process, and perhaps an investigation of pathology and diagnostic imaging requests.

With all the evidence at hand, it is therefore clear that any assertion that the problems with the New South Wales health system are the result of Commonwealth funding cuts would not pass a basic kindergarten maths test. Perhaps Mr Carr and Dr Refshauge should be looking in their own backyard at the infighting between state government instrumentalities for financial assistance grants from the Commonwealth and their own ineptitude at managing an efficient health service. It is time the Carr government simply stopped blaming everyone else for its problems and started getting its own house in order and giving the people of New South Wales the health service they rightly deserve.

talk.start.para: âBack in November 1996 this government introduced its states grants bill. As we all know, it abolished the new schools policy, paving the way for the expansion of the private school sector and introducing a funding mechanism which would help it to pay for the ensuing increase in the cost to the federal government. The argument went along the lines that students in government schools were funded in two ways: a per capita grant of $400 to $600, depending on whether they were in primary or secondary schools, and untied grants which the states used to fund government schools.

speech.para: The federal government said that when students shifted across to private schools they saved money for the states, which no longer had to spend federal assistance grants moneys on those students. The enrolment benchmark adjustment would see to it that for every student enrolled over and above the 1996 proportion of students in the private sectorâthat is known as the benchmarkâan average of $1,712.50 would be taken away from funding to the states.

That sounded reasonable to many people, especially when the government made the point of saying that the money follows the student. What could be fairer than that? But during the debate we had on the bill Senator Vanstone was very careful to avoid spelling out how the EBA works because, of course, this is not how it works at all. The new minister, last week, mistakenly repeated Dr Kemp's line when he said again, `The funding follows the person.' Either he does not understand how the EBA works or he chooses to mislead people. The funding does not follow the student. The department admitted last week that it did not track students and it does not know whether students are actually exiting government schools or not. The only data that is available to the government is in aggregate figures in each state. And, of course, the aggregate figures show that there was no net loss of students from government schools.

Back in November 1996, the Democrats said that this was a regressive and a punitive mechanism and quite unfair. We said that enrolments were increasing every year and that the proportion in private schools could increase and therefore trigger the EBA, even when there was no reduction in enrolments in government schools, and this is indeed what happened. In January this year the long awaited national schools census came out and it showed that not only did the government sector not lose any students but it actually gained 8,500. There were 8,500 more students in government schools in 1997 than there were in the previous year.

I might add that this compares with the government's projections in 1996 of a reduction of 5,979. So they had actually underestimated government school enrolments by about 14,500 students. Much more accurate were the projections for private schools: 19,789 extra students were expected in private schools and just over 2,000 actually enrolled. By the way, if the government's projections had been accurate, $26.9 million would have been cut from the states using that EBA mechanism. But the national schools census came out and, according to the way the legislation was written, the figures meant that $20.5 million would have to be cut from the states. Remember that government schools have not had a net loss of any studentsâin fact they have increased by 8,500. But, of course, under the EBA this does not stop them from being punished. They have to wear the cost of the private sector just because it is growing at a faster rate.

The figures have been available since January but the silence from the government has been deafening. We had to wait until estimates last week to quiz the minister and the department to extract the exact figures. No doubt the government is feeling the heat and perhaps it is not proud of its action in taking money away from government schools, especially when the rationale for doing so has now gone out the window. The minister says that the $1,712.50 cut per extra student has been re-negotiated with each state according to how much money they spend to educate each child. A state like Victoria now spends less than any other state government, so it is of course rewarded by having a lower amount applied to its EBA calculation.

The new figure means that the EBA liability is $5.21 million from New South Wales, $2.47 million from Victoria, $3.34 million from Queensland, $1.7 million from Western Australia, $2.99 million from South Australia, $690,000 from the Northern Territory, $490,000 from the Australian Capital Territory, and Tasmania will not have to pay anything back. Of course, if the EBA was properly applied to Tasmania, the federal government would actually be the one to have to pay Tasmania back because the proportion of their private school enrolments actually decreased. Unfortunately for Tasmania, however, this is a one-sided deal and they do not get rewarded for keeping their numbers high in relation to private schools.

The government has reduced the per student figure from state to state with the result that the debt reduces from $20.5 million to $16.89 million. Then, according to the department last week, the government has decided to further reduce the debt by introducing a buffer. This buffer is 0.05 per cent of enrolments.

The effect of the buffer is to further reduce the debt to nothing in the Northern Territory and the ACT, but it results in $4.33 million being taken from New South Wales, $1.73 million from Victoria, $2.6 million from Queensland, $960,000 from WA and $2.28 million from South Australia. Overall, the cost of the EBA to all of the states is $11.9 million. Again I remind the Senate that government schools have not lost any enrolmentsâin fact, they have gained 8,500 new students.

On Sunday, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr David Kemp, seemed to have forgotten about the EBA and how it works. He said, `The government is not moving funds from government to non-government schools.' He said in referring to the Australian Education Union, `What we are seeing is a very foolish, misguided and dishonest campaign from the Australian Education Union.'

The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison, said last month that the Democrats were conducting a scare campaign when we did our calculation based on the national school census. At that stage he apparently had not reached finality in negotiations with the states and he had not cooked up the buffer. This is not to say that the Democrats are unhappy with the idea of a buffer. Anything that will reduce that debt to government schools is fine with us.

We need to understand that the EBA is a compounding mechanism. Every year the benchmark returns to that 1996 level. So whereas the projected debt for 1998 back in 1996 was $26.9 million, in 1999 it is expected to be a further $59.5 million. So the EBA was projected to double each year as the proportion of students in private schools continued to climb.

The minister has dismissed our concerns. He says that $16.8 million represents about one-fifth of one per cent of government school budgets and we should not be focusing on this issue. The department says the EBA has caused the states to look at their own systems and see how they can retain students in government school sectors and cites the Tasmanian example. `That state,' it says, `has made its schools more attractive for its students.' What nonsense! To imagine that schools under threat of losing money will make themselves more attractive to students is really quite laughable.

I visit many schools and it is true that they are feeling the competition with private schools, but it is unfair competition. It is competition where government schools do not have enough teachers or enough facilities. They have portable classrooms, inadequate science laboratories and sporting equipment, and class sizes that are too high. They do not have enough specialist teachers and their teachers are stretched to the limitâteachers who are missing out on professional development thanks to this government's last budget cuts.

At the same time, the government schools are seeing their private sector counterparts excluding students who are difficult to teach and difficult to manage. They are seeing them get new classrooms funded by the Commonwealth. They look forward with concern about the influx of students who are forced back to school with the youth allowanceâstudents who do not want to be there in the first place.

The minister says that state governments and government schools should not be concerned about the EBA because it is a small amount of money in the scheme of things. The Democrats say that, if it is so inconsequential, let us support government schools and get rid of it. Our schools are operating under increasingly difficult circumstances and taking money away from them is not justified and nor will it improve education in this country.

talk.start.para: âI would like to associate my colleagues Bill O'Chee and Julian McGauran with my remarks today. Today I was fortunate to be able to attend the state funeral of Bob Santamaria at the St Patrick's Cathedral in Melbourne. I was fortunate because this was a unique event connecting the world of the spiritual with the world of the state. Bob Santamaria was known for his contribution to both worlds.

speech.para: Often controversial, much has been written of the causes he championed and the impact he made. I am not a historian or an intellectual so I will not endeavour to lay down an academic assessment. Instead, I want to note the personal influence Bob Santamaria exerted over so many ordinary Australians who were neither bishops of churches nor ministers of state.

Over 60-odd years from the days of the Catholic Worker, the Movement and then the National Civic Council, tens of thousands of Australians were the foot soldiers of these organisations inspired by Santamaria. Most were ordinary workers looking ahead to safeguard their families. Lest we think of those days as belonging only to the past, the attendance of many at the funeral today is testament to the lasting and continuing personal influence of Santamaria. They came from all around Australia, a loyal and devoted group of followers and admirers. Often Santamaria's influence extended over two or three generations in the one family. Some of those there today were white-haired and stooped, and some were young and spry, but all mourned the passing of an unusually committed and gifted man.

The strongest image in the cathedral was not the presence of the thousands of people crushed to standing room only, nor was it the incredible show of support by the hundreds or so priests and bishops, nor was it the VIPs who were there; the strongest image for me was that created by Bob Santamaria's own family. They occupied row after rowâchildren, grandchildren, great grandchildren and extended family members. They were the pride and joy of his life and his greatest legacy.

Bob used to me tell me how much he enjoyed Sunday nights when there was a family get-together and he would cook a huge feed of spaghetti bolognaise. He was always so kind and encouraging to me and so many others. Since his death I have been amazed by the many and various people who have written about their personal friendships with him. These people have come from all walks of life and all political leanings. It was not necessary to agree with everything Bob said or wrote in order to have a friendship based on understanding and respect.

Bob Santamaria was never diverted by short-term trends on society, state and church. He was there for the long haul and took a long-term strategic view. He was not afraid to go against the tide of opinion propounded by commentators. Yet how hard that struggle must have been at times, how hard and demanding the struggle against organised communism. How hard it must have been to take on the goals and aspirations of the hundreds of thousands of Australian voters left politically homeless following the Labor split.

Someone wrote about Bob that he was born to champion causes and fight evil. Evil is an unfashionable concept today, but nevertheless real. The evil that Bob fought was anything which harmed families. That was the bottom line, and well we would do to remember that more often in this place. Families need champions. The other things that Bob fought for, like small business, need their champions too.

Bob's passing has left a great void. The causes for which he fought have not gone with him. The baton of Bob Santamaria must be passed on. The fight must continue. The pressures on families and small business are still there. The big are getting bigger while the smaller family businesses are getting pushed out.

We will have failed this great man if we allow his motivations to fall fallow. They must be moved forward, reinvigorated for another generation. To do that, Australia needs more people to stand up and be counted, more people brave enough to go against the tide when necessary to fight for what they believe.

Archbishop Pell noted today, `Bob Santamaria did know the attractive force of the principle that the end justifies the means, but he resisted this.' That sort of thinking might well be against the tide in the world of state, but what a better world it would be if more of us could resist that. It was an honour to attend the funeral of this great Australian, to give him a send-off he would never have expected. It was made special by the wonderful family Bob has left with us.

talk.start.para: âUnfortunately, in January this year Mr Roger Shipton, the former member for Higgins, passed away. Roger Shipton held the seat of Higgins for 15 years. His two immediate predecessors were Prime Ministers of AustraliaâMr Harold Holt and Mr John Gorton. His successor, if press reports are to be believed, certainly aspires to the position.

speech.para: Higgins, of course, is a blue-ribbon Liberal seat, although the odd booth in it does vote Labor. So in order to win preselection, Roger Shipton had to beat a quality field. The judgment of his preselectors was in no way misplaced. Within three years of entering parliament, Roger Shipton was elected as Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defenceâthe most prestigious committee in the federal parliament. As chairman, Roger earned the respect and admiration of all members of the committee. He continued to serve on the committee under Labor chairmenâall of whom held him in the highest regard.

Roger Shipton studied law at the University of Melbourne and was president of the student law faculty. His main job prior to entering parliament was as legal officer for ICI. It is probable that Roger's experience as a hammer thrower prompted his administrative involvement in at least three Olympic Games: Melbourne in 1956, Rome in 1960 and Tokyo in 1964. Having joined the Liberal Party, he became a branch activist and may well have been Harold Holt's successor in Higgins but for the necessity to find the then Senator John Gorton a seat in parliament so that he could fulfil the role of Prime Minister.

Too often politicians are judged by the level of office they achieve, but it is not the be-all and end-all. At the very time that it could be expected that Roger Shipton could have become a minister, the coalition lost office. So, like many of his generation, he spent his political prime in opposition. In opposition, Roger served as a shadow minister in several portfolio areasâan indication that he would have made an excellent minister if he had been given the opportunity. Following his departure from federal politics in 1990, Roger established his own consultancy firm. This, together with his involvement with the United Nations Association, allowed him to maintain his interest in politics and international affairs.

Roger was successful in many facets of his life, and this can be attributed to the nature of the man. He was honourable, gentle, urbaneâa Liberal in the true Whig tradition. He was a good listener who provided wise counsel when necessary, and he always thought the best of people. He had much wider interests than just politics and, like many Australians, he enjoyed sportâespecially tennis, cricket, equestrian three-day events, horse racing and football. I suspect he was the only member for Higgins who ever barracked for Footscray! He also enjoyed things such as walking and browsing around at the Prahran market. He was devoted to his family and was very proud of their achievements.
All those who new him, irrespective of their party affiliations, will miss him. To his spouse, Suzie, his son, James, and his daughter, Kate, my condolences.

talk.start.para: âI extend my sympathy to the Santamaria family on the passing of Bob Santamaria. To Paul Santamaria, whom I know best, I wish him grace and strength during this sorrowful time. For while I and so many others attended today's funeral to pay respect to our hero, the Santamaria family were mourning the loss of their father. It was the family man, so well described by his daughter, Mary-Helen Woods, in the Australian newspaper during the week, that they will no doubt miss most, rather than the political mastermind he has been eulogised as this week. It was appreciated by all that the family shared this day of mourning with us.

speech.para: Today's state funeral was magnificent. It was held in the full tradition of the Catholic Church befitting, as Archbishop Pell said, `one of the church's greatest sons'. The Archbishop spoke of a crusade that began in the 1930s when in the Spanish Civil War a communist bullet struck the statue of Christ outside the Madrid Cathedral, continuing through to the 1990s with the internal struggle against the anti-papacy for the soul of the church. The Archbishop's homily concluded with the line: `His legacy lives on.' Looking around at the troops who had turned out to see off their general, the poignancy of the archbishop's comments were felt.

For me, Bob Santamaria's decades of writings influenced the formation of my core political beliefs. The clarity of his intellect and argument was compelling even though I did not agree with him all the timeâjust most of the time. Significantly, it was the switching of the DLP Senate preferences in 1987 towards the National Party that facilitated my election to the parliament. Of all the qualities attributed to B.A. Santamaria in the multitude of articles written this week, two qualities appear over, which for me best identify the man I met: firstly, a lasting courage of his convictions; and, secondly, an honest broker. That is why he had such an influence on political life in Australia, without ever having held office. Santamaria's life example is his most powerful legacy.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Contracts for Public Relations Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 826)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 3 September 1997:

question.para: (1) What contracts for public relations services has the department, or its agencies, signed since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the value of each contract.
(3) Did the value of any contract vary from the original cost; if so, what was the reason for the price variation.
(4) How many of the contracts in (1) were awarded following an open tender process.
(5) Where there was no tender process, what assessment criteria were followed in selecting the contractor and why was the normal practice of calling tenders not followed.
(6) Did the department seek guidance from the Office of Government Information and Advertising before signing the above contracts; if not, why not.
(7) How many journalists were employed by the department as at 3 March 1996.
(8) How many journalists are currently employed by the department.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

entry.para: Phase 2 Airport Salesâthe business adviser to OAS, BZW, sub-contracted Jackson Wells Communications to provide public relations services
$113,400 (plus out of pocket expenses not to exceed 10% of the base consultancy fee)
Contract awarded following a tender process involving a limited number of invited firms
Australian National Railways Saleâthe business advisers to OAS, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, sub-contracted to Cosway Communications to provide public relations services.
Contract awarded following a tender process involving a limited number of invited firms.
The consultant was not engaged directly by OAS
Telstra Sale: Burson-Marsteller as the communications consultant; and
The value of the contract was varied downwards from the estimate of $1.49m, following a reduction in the scope of the work
Contract awarded following a tender process involving a limited number of invited firms.
OAS sought guidance from OGIA throughout the tender process
Cultural Perspectives as the NESB communications consultant.
Contract awarded following a tender process involving a limited number of invited firms.
OAS sought guidance from OGIA throughout the tender process

Increased to include approved additional work, allowed for under the contract, and to meet actual costs of disbursements such as telephone and facsimile costs for which estimates only had been included in the contract
Contract awarded following a tender process involving a limited number of invited firms.
The AEC appointed Michels Warren and Partners for the Constitutional Convention information campaign for the following reasons:
. because of the very tight timeframe there was no time to conduct an open tender;
. they had demonstrated relevant electoral expertise;
. they had been appointed as the AEC's public relations consultants for the 1993 and 1996 federal elections following an extensive open tender process; and
. the AEC had a high level of satisfaction with the services of the consultancy

answer.para: (7) At 3 March 1996 there were 2 Senior Public Affairs Officers and 21 Public Affairs Officers employed by the then Department of Administrative Services and Agencies whose duties included media liaison, general public affairs and photographic activities. The former Department of Finance did not employ any public affairs officers.

(8) At 30 September 1997 there were 2 Senior Public Affairs Officers and 10 Public Affairs Officers employed by the then Department of Administrative Services and Agencies. The former Department of Finance did not employ any public affairs officers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Can details be provided on the proportion of Green Corps (GC) participants who have entered education or training places, or have found employment, upon completion of the GC program.
(2) Can details be provided as to the type of study or employment being undertaken and whether these jobs are related to the environment.
(3) Can details be provided as to: (a) how monitoring of GC participants' outcomes will be undertaken; and (b) to whom this information will be made available.
(4) In relation to the third round of GC participants, what percentage of placements went to: (a) the long term unemployed; and (b) the short term unemployed.
(5) What percentage of the placements in the third round of GC participants went to people already in training or education or to people describing themselves as not unemployed.
(6) In relation to the first, second and third round of GC projects, what level of training differentiates successful and unsuccessful applicants.
(7) Can a breakdown be provided of the educational background of the participants in all three rounds of the GC projects.

(8) With reference to the environmental training provided to GC participants, including accredited training modules in: environmental audit, Workplace Level Two Basic First Aid, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to the Land Conservation and Restoration Industry; and selected modules from the Conservation Traineeship relevant to the particular project:
For each of the three rounds of the GC projects please detail (a) which type of training is being provided; and (b) the precise nature of the project.

(9) (a) Which third round GC projects are in the same area as former Land and Environmental Assistance Program (LEAP) projects; and (b) what are the differences in the LEAP and GC projects which are in the same area.

(10) (a) Can the Minister's office or the department provide details of any complaints they have received or of which they are aware, relating to the GC program; and (b) have any of these complaints related to the level of training provided to GC participants.
(11) (a) Have any participants in GC expressed concerns about workplace safety issues; and (b) what action has been taken in relation to these complaints.
(12) On what grounds has or will the $500 take-up for GC participants not be offered.
(13)How many people applied to participate in the GC program; (a) nationally; and (b) on a state by state basis.
(14) Can a copy be provided of the guidelines used by Environment Australia in determining that each of the projects is assessed as having `environment or heritage benefits'.
(15) Why do Work for Dole participants have reduced activity test requirements, whereas GC participants are not required to fulfil any job search activity at all.
(16) In relation to the third round of GC participants, what percentage of places went to disabled people.

(17) With reference to the GC guidelines which state that projects must reflect the `youth community profile', the department has stated that this means: `in making decisions about the composition of Green Corps teams, the contractor is required to ensure that local demographic factors are taken into consideration':

(a) What do those factors include and how they have been taken into account; and in particular, (b) can an explanation be provided as to how such factors are taken into account in relation to the first, second and third round of GC projects in Western Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Green Corps participants are surveyed three to six months after completion of their projects. This information is expected to be available in March 1998.
(2) As above
(3) (a) As above
(b) The Post Program Monitoring information is collected for Departmental use for future planning. Post Program Monitoring information is not usually publically available.
(4) Of the total group of successful third round applicants;

14% had previously been unemployed for more than twelve months; 21% had previously been unemployed for less than twelve months but more than six months, and 32% had been unemployed for less than six months.
Immediately prior to commencing a Green Corps placement
(5) In the third round of projects 33%, of placements went to participants describing themselves as not unemployed.
(6) Information is not collected centrally on this point. Previous training is one of seven selection criteria, as follows:
. applicant's commitment to environmental issues;
. previous training;
. career aspirations;
. diversity of hobbies;
. age, ie older applicants within the eligible age group are favoured over younger applicants who would later have the chance to participate;
. matching the applicant to the community profile; and
. proximity of applicant to project location.
(8) See attachment
(9) (a) The following areas have had LEAP projects and also have round three Green Corps projects;

(b) The differences in LEAP and Green Corps projects are that Green Corps projects have a much stronger focus on quality environmental outcomes and a higher quality of training. Green Corps projects have a stronger emphasis on linking Green Corps to quality career opportunities in fields such as environmental management, science, conservation and restoration. Green Corps trainees are paid a training allowance based on the Federal National Training Wage Award Structure between $152 to $252 per week. LEAP participants aged 15 to 17 were paid $125 per week and those aged 18 to 20 were paid $150 per week.

(10) (a) I have received a very limited number of complaints about the Green Corps program. The main focus has been on the training allowance, which is based on the Federal National Training Wage Award structure. Other concerns which have been raised are;
. the age restriction;
. the standard of accommodation provided to participants whilst on residential projects;
. screening of sites and work projects and,
. training of supervisors.

All of the above complaints have been addressed by the Department and the Contractor with exception to the complaint on the age restriction, which has not been addressed due to the program being a youth training program.

(b) There has been one complaint about the status of a first aid course provided to participants. This complaint has also been addressed, all participants undertake accredited first aid training at Workplace level 2 or Senior First Aid level.
(11) One complaint was received and subsequently withdrawn when the complainant realised that the facts provided were incorrect.
(12) The $500 incentive payment will not be offered to those participants who have either not successfully completed their project or cannot provide evidence of enrolment with an accredited
education or training provider to undertake further education or training within six months of graduation.
(13) Number of Applications

(14) Assessment of the environment and/or heritage benefits of Green Corps projects is conducted by several areas within Environment Australia. The areas have responsibility for a number of international agreements and legislative responsibilities such as the Register of the National Estate, the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance (Ramsar Convention), the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, and relevant programs of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. The environment and/or heritage benefits of the projects are assessed by these program areas in the context of their responsibilities, and by reference to the attached guidelines.

(15) Work for the Dole is an initiative based on the principle of mutual obligation: that it is fair and just that people be asked to make a contribution in return for payment of unemployment allowance. Work for the Dole is a work experience program, not a training program. Participants are required to attend Work for the Dole projects for two to two and a half days per week. Green Corps is a full time training program for six months. There is no requirement for participants to be unemployed prior to commencing their placement. Unlike Work for the Dole participants, Green Corps participants are not in receipt of unemployment benefits and so therefore are not required to fulfil any job search activity. As Work for the Dole is a work experience program and participants remain in receipt of unemployment benefits, participants are still required to look for work at a reduced requirement of a minimum of two job search contacts per fortnight.
(16) In the third round of projects, 2% of placements went to people with disabilities.

(17) (a) The contractor is required to ensure that there is a balance of young people who are representative of the youth community, such factors may include participants from Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent, women, people with disabilities and unemployed people.
The program is voluntary, and where possible participants will be drawn from the local community, although the program is open to all applicants across Australia.

(b) Demographic factors are taken into account when selecting participants, for example if a project is conducted in an area predominantly Aboriginal it would be expected that the make up of the group would reflect this.
(8) The Contractor has advised the Department that the following training is proposed for each of
the locations listed. Some changes for non core modules may occur due to actual project needs and trainer recommendations.
ROUND 1

entry.para: Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Field Plant Identification and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

To conserve and establish vegetation in Sydney's land and water transport corridors and broader environment prior to the Sydney Olympics. Major project activity will be revegetation, landscaping and erosion control.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to the Propagation of Plants and Eco Skills

Habitat restoration in the Western Plains Zoo, Australian Native Fauna and Flora Sanctuary. Monitoring of released native animals and feral pests and creek bed restoration. Major project activity will be plantings for platypus reintroduction, feral pest management, revegetation in wetlands and creek sites.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

Protection of aboriginal cultural sites. Reduce threat to endangered species of Acacia carnei by reducing rabbit population. Control weeds along lake edges. Major project activity will be fencing, destruction of rabbit warrens, revegetation, invasive flora control.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Furniture Construction, Park Pathway Construction and Weed Control Techniques

Access management of wetlands as outlined in Merimbula Lake Estuary Management Plan. Major project activity will be to construct raised board through sensitive wetlands and Mangroves. Construct walking track links. Revegetation and erosion control.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Hand and Power Tools, Field Plants Identification and Park Pathway Construction

Restoration of historic site extensively damaged by bush fires. Creek rehabilitation be re-establishment of indigenous plant communities. Major project activity will be landscaping, grassing with native plants, tree planting, shrubs and minor plants and ground cover planting. Bank stabilisation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Plant Propagation and Field Plant Identification.

Assist in the development of unique Botanic Garden to act as a repository for endangered flora. Major project activity at the Australian Inland Botanic Gardens will be landscaping, installation of irrigation systems; sorting, propagating, and planting Australian dryland species of flora and maintenance of exhibition areas.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

Assist in the Nature Links Program to re-establish native bushland throughout the city of Port Phillip and specifically along the foreshore. Major project activity will be revegetation, seed collection, bush regeneration and coastal rehabilitation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway construction and Portable Power Tools building.

Restoration of heritage buildings in historical railway site. Revegetation of wetlands area. Major project activity will be landscaping and planting, carpentry, painting, track construction, revegetation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Recognition of Weeds, Weed Control Techniques and Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas

Restoration of zones of the Upper Condamine Catchment as outlined in the Queensland MurrayâDarling Basin Strategic Plan. Major Project Activity will be tree planting, wildlife assessment, weed control, fencing, relocation of watering points and recreational infrastructure.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Weed Control Techniques

Regeneration of Mangroves in significant migratory bird habitat on the Northern perimeter of Brisbane. Major project activity will be revegetation (direct seeding and tube stock), weed removal, track and bank stabilisation, re-establishing salt marsh.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Sourcing Plants for Revegetation and Transplanting Small Trees

Construction of wildlife corridor between Bromfield Swamp and Malanda Falls Environmental Park. Major project activity will be bank stabilisation, access control, walking track construction, seed collection, plant propagation, revegetation. Viewing platform construction.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

Enhancement of significant migratory waterbird habitat through management of estuarine mangroves, wetlands and salt water grasslands. Major project activity will be revegetation, formalisation of walking tracks and control of vehicle access, improvement in water quality, weed control, erosion control and bank stabilisation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to site evaluation and rehabilitation planning and Stone Wall construction

Rehabilitation and protection of natural vegetation and limestone caves associated with World Heritage listing of the site. Major project activity will be stone wall construction, track maintenance, graffiti removal and bush regeneration.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Occupational Health and Safety, Eco Skills, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Koala Management/Catching Skills

Implement management plan for significant Koala population including relocation and population control program. Major project activity will be koala management program, catching koalas, health checks and relocation, site rehabilitation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Occupational Health and Safety Eco Skills and Introduction to Machinery

Assisting `Operation Bounce Back' which aims to protect the Yellow-footed Rock Wallabies by managing feral species. Major project activity will be maintaining a fox free environment for Yellow-footed Rock Wallabies. Mapping and destroying rabbit warrens, removing or destroying weeds. Developing camp grounds and walking tracks and tree planiting.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Site Evaluation and Rehabilitation Planning, Job Seeking Skills, Park Furniture Construction, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas, Levelling and Trenching and Introduction to Hand and Power Tools

Assisting in implementation of strategic plans in the Work Heritage area through rehabilitation of coastal recreation sites and monitoring of threatened flora and fauna. Major project activity will be restoration of historical homestead and develop new interpretation building. Reintroduction and monitoring of threatened fauna. Protect and rehabilitate coastal recreation sites.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Mapping and Survival Skills in Remote Locations and Site Rehabilitation
Implementation of the `Exotic Palm Control' at Millstream Chichester National Park. Major Project activity will be removal of palm trees, collect native seeds and rehabilitate areas.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Eco Skills and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

Transforming island into a unique native conservation reserve through removal of building and revegetation program to provide nesting areas for little penguins and other seabirds. Major project activity will be the removal of two buildings, rehabilitation of sites to provide nesting areas for bird life.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction, Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber and Weed Control Techniques
Visitor access management, clearing vegetation and erosion control. Major project activity will be vegetation and track management. Erosion control.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

Stabilisation of historic structures, vegetation clearance and development of visitor facilities. Major project activity will be rehabilitation, feral animal control, track construction, erosion management, small mammal surveys.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber, Park Pathway Construction and Field Plant Identification

Construct basic outdoor study facility/walking track tohighlight forest ecology, history of the forest and current flora and fauna of the area. Major project activity will be construction of an educational walking track, associated signage and an outdoor study facility (bush classroom).
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction and Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber

Development of walking track along Roper River and high priority soil conservation work at Wabalarr. Major project activity will be management of park accessâtrack construction, erosion control, constructing foot bridges and a viewing platform, removal of fences.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Park Pathway Construction and Park Furniture Construction

Construction of 3km walking track and board walk through mangroves and monsoonal vine thickets along Casuarina foreshore. Major project activity will be track and board walk construction, plant identification and site interpretation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction, Revegetationâincluding brush cutting and Weed Control Techiques.

High priority repair of walking track in Namadgi National Park. Improvement of platypus habitat and reduction of fire threats in Tidbinbilla Nature Reserve. Major project activity will be maintenance of walking tracks and management of erosion. Removal of invasive flora.

answer.para: ROUND 2

entry.para: Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas and Impacts of Introduced Land Practices.

The aim of this projects is to enhance and protect the Macquarie River and Catchment, especially by reducing nutrient levels, planting habitat for native species and controlling erosion. Major project activity will be corridor fencing, bushland regeneration, willow replacement, tree planting, wetland construction and construction of erosion control devices. The project will be based in the Bathurst region
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Field Plant Identification and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

This project will assist with the aims of the Greener Sydney 2000 program to conserve and establish vegetation in transport corridors prior to the Sydney Olympics. The project will also assist with a major revegetation and erosion control program within Sydney Harbour National Park. Major project activity will be seed collection, propagation, site preparation, tree planting, track construction, weed control, erosion control and management of urban bushland. The project may include the use of power tools and working with sandstone.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Field Plant Identification and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

The aim of this project is to revegetate roadside corridors and key environmental sites adjacent to the New England Highway and the villages of Branxton, Greta, Lochinvar and Rutherford. This is a demonstration project within the Hunter Gateway Strategy. Major project activity will be the creation of Corridors of Green along major road reserves, restoration of native vegetation and habitats and the reversal of land degradation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Eco Skills 1, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds and Tools for Plant Recognition

The aim of this project is to undertake urgent restoration work in the Big Scrub, which has been described as the largest area of sub tropical rainforests in Australian at the time of European settlement. The project will focus on six remnants which are recognised as having extremely high conservation value. Major project activity will be weed control, fencing, seed collection, propagation of rainforest species and planting of appropriate indigenous species. The project has been developed in conjunction with the Big Scrub Rainforest Landcare Group.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds, Introduction to the Propagation of Plants and Impacts of Introduced Land Practices

This project will assist the Dorrigo Farm Forestry Project by expanding the number of hectares of trial and demonstration planting's and helping to ascertain the most appropriate species, establishment techniques and planting models for farm forestry in the district. Major project activity will be seed collection, plant propagation, fencing, linking and extending remnant vegetation, labelling species in remnant bush, site surveying and mapping, site monitoring, removal of woody weeds, tree planting and the release of dung beetles.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds, Introduction to Site Evaluation and Rehabilitation Planning, Introduction to the Propagation of Plants and Park Facility ConstructionâPaving

The aim of this project is to assist with the ongoing transformation of a disused mine site into a innovative environmental education centre. This project has been developed in conjunction with InteLife. Major project activity will be wide ranging and will include revegetation, construction and permaculture food gardens, erosion control, weed control and possibly assisting with the development of solar powered facilities.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Site Assessments, Eco Skills 1, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

This project aims to assist the restoration of the environment within the World Heritage Listed Iluka Nature Reserve and adjoining areas in Bundjalung National Park. These high conservation value areas have been impacted by sand mining, burning, grazing and severe weed invasion. Major project activity will be the removal of exotic weed species, regeneration of natural vegetation, plant propagation, tree planting and seed collection. The project fits in with the "Restoration Strategy for Iluka Peninsula".
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

The aim of this project is to protect and restore a unique and sensitive vegetation community at Fingal Heads. Major project activity will be tree planting, seed collection, weed control and other activities to re-establish a littoral rainforest.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction and Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber

The aim of this project is to construct and maintain a walking track along the coast of Ben Boyd National Park near Eden. Major project activity will be track construction, maintenance of existing track and completion of signs and bridges.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Field Plant Identification

The major focus of this project will be revegetation works on conservation reserves in the Wimmera. The majority of the sites involved are classified as High Value Wetlands under Victoria's Wetlands Conservation Program. Major project activity will be planting trees and shrubs, pest plant control, pest animal control, seed collection, removal of old fencing, installation of signs and walking track construction and maintenance. The project will be based in Horsham.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Introduction to Plant Propagation

This project will assist with the creation of a 20Ha Western Basalt Plains exhibit. The exhibit will include key landscape elements of Victoria's threatened Basalt Plains. Major project activity will be tree planting, fencing, minor construction, wildlife surveys and plant propagation. The project will create a sanctuary for wildlife and an educational walking trail which will focus on Aboriginal perspectives of landscape and environment.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Field Plant Identification, Native Fauna Habitat and Workplace Communication

The aim of this project is to assist with the monitoring of the endangered mallee fowl in Murray Sunset, Hattah and Wypefeld National Parks. The project will be based from Mildura. Major project activity will be finding, plotting and describing all new mallee fowl nests in the region. Trainees will also find and plot rabbit warrens and fox dens. The project may include camping in remote areas for extended periods.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Site Assessment, Workplace Communication, Computer Operations Fundamentals and Word Processing Operations

The aim of this project is to help the endangered regent honeyeater of which only 1000â1500 surviving in the wild. The Lurg district provides essential nectar supplies for the birds which arrive each winter to feed on the flowering Ironbarks. Major project activity will be fencing of remnant vegetation, tree planting, Mistletoe removal and direct seeding. The project will also involve trapping arboreal mammals, building and monitoring nest boxes and monitoring water quality.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Plant Propagation and Impacts of Introduced Land Practices

The Sale Green Corps Team will assist in securing substantial and diverse seed stocks for use by landcare groups contributing to revegetation projects under the Lake Wellington Salinity Strategy. Major project activity will be salinity mapping, seed collection and storage, water quality monitoring, erosion control, plantings and wetlands monitoring. Some of the project may involve on site accommodation.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

The Swan Hill Green Corps Team will assist with the protection of remnant vegetation and rehabilitation of degraded wetlands and riparian zones within the Lake Bael Bael to Lodden Corridor Network. Major project activity will be tree planting, weed control, pest and animal control, salinity surveys, water quality testing, seed collection and restoration of heritage buildings.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

This project involves catchment management works and enhancement of wildlife/recreational corridors in three flora and fauna reserves adjacent to the Cardinia and Toomuc Creeks and Bunyip River Catchment. Major project activity will be environmental weed control, track relocation and construction of barrier gates, track erosion control work, walking track construction and construction of a display board/shelter.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction and Introduction to History of Aboriginal Land Management

The aim of this project is to construct a graded walking track within Mt Cook National Park. The track will present the parks diversity of natural, scenic and cultural values to both visitors and locals whilst creating minimal environmental impact. Major project activity will be surveying and constructing a walking track. The project will also include the identification of European and Aboriginal Cultural Sites. This project will be based in Cooktown.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Site Evaluation / Rehabilitation Planting and Vegetation Restoration Techniques
Park Pathway Construction, Introduction to History of Aboriginal Land Management
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The aim of this project is to survey a threatened vine forest remnant which is in public ownership. The data collected will assist with the creation of a management plan for the Glen Rock property. The project was developed in conjunction with the World Wide Fund of Nature. Major project activity will be vegetation and fauna surveys, weed mapping, basic track construction and installation of signage. The project will be based in Lockyer Valley between Ipswich and Toowoomba.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

This project aims to reverse land clearing and degradation in portions of the Upper Mary River Catchment through revegetation programs using a wide mix of native species. The project has been developed in conjunction with the Barung Landcare Association. Major project activity will be removal of woody weeds, tree planting, erosion control, seed collection, propagation and fencing. The project will work along the Obi Obi Creek at the Barung Landcare Nursery and in a bush food demonstration park.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

This project will assist the Mountains to Mangroves Corridor Project which is based on remnant bushland links across North Brisbane to the Mangroves of Moreton Bay. The project aims to link existing walking trails so that a wildlife and passive recreational corridor can co-exist. Major project activity will be seed collection, nursery work, fencing, trail construction, weed control and riparian vegetation. This project will be based in the North Brisbane metropolitan region.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Field Plant Identification

The Green Corps Team will assist the Urban Forest Biodiversity Program which has been developed to co-ordinate revegetation and wildlife habitat protection projects in the Adelaide metropolitan area. Major project activity will be plant identification, seed collection, weed control, fencing and tree planting throughout Australia.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Field Plant Identification

The Green Corps Team will assist with broadscale revegetation projects with local communities within the Broughton Catchment as part of the Corridors of Green Program. Major project activity will be site preparation, seed collection, fencing, direct seeding, propagation and tree planting. The project will be based in the Gladstone region and may also involve nursery work in Quorn.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Introduction to Propagation of Plants, Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1 and Field Plant Identification 1

The aim of this project is to develop community based seed banks across South Australia. Major project activity will be establishing eight seed banks across the state and will therefore involve a significant component of travel and living in remote areas for up to two weeks at a time.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Park Pathway Construction and Park Furniture ConstructionâTimber

The aim of this project is to establish a walking trail to a derelict whaling station in Norwegian Bay within the Ningaloo Marine Park near Exmouth Major project activity will be track construction, establishing interpretive signage and a major clean-up of the whaling station. This project may involve a significant component of remote area camping.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The major focus of this project is to control environmental weeds at a number of sensitive environmental sites in the Kimberleys including Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve, Point Spring Nature Reserve and Mirima National Park.
