Major project activity will be control of environmental weeds in rainforest borders, seasonal wetlands, creeks and flood plains. The project will also involve track construction and access redevelopment. The project may involve a significant component of remote area camping.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Eco Skills

This project will assist with a variety of programs including the development of the Kalgan River Walk Trail, a farm forestry project at Oyster Harbour, the Wilson Inlet Project and working with catchment groups in the Jerramungup Region. Major project activity will be a walkway construction, fencing, tree, planting, direct seeding, tree fertilising and revegetation. The project will be based from Denmark or Albany and may involve a number of residential projects.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Eco Skills

The aim of this project is to assist with the ongoing development of the Bibbulmun Track. Major project activity will be track construction and maintenance. Due to the nature of this project it may involve a substantial amount of remote area camping.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas and Park Pathway Construction

This project involves the upgrading and rerouting of two walking tracks in Wellington Park and assisting the Derwent Valley Corridors of Green Project with the fencing and planting of a number of project sites. Major project activity will be fencing, planting, direct seeding, track maintenance and track construction.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

The aim of this project is to protect the habitat of penguins and shearwaters at Cataraqui Point on King Island. Major project activity will be fencing to exclude cattle, revegetation to stabilise dunes and construction of a walking trail to Sea Rocks.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

The aim of this project is to assist the Tamar Valley Weed Strategy by the comprehensive mapping of weed infestations in the Tamar Valley. Major project activity will be weed mapping including map interpretation, use of GIS System, knowledge of weed plant species and the production of weed maps. The projects will also involve the eradication of weed species.

Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Chainsaw Licence, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas, Transplanting Small Trees, Container Plant Production and Introduction to Hand and Power Tools

The aim of this project is to revegetate the banks of the North Esk River in support of the Hoblers Bridge Reserve Management Plan. Major project activity will be tree planting and weed control along the North Esk River and bushland regeneration in Cataract Gorge.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

This project aims to control and eradicate weed infestations in river and catchment areas. A minor project surveying feral and native animals in the MacDonnell Ranges, including monitoring of feral cats and trapping and habitat surveys of the Central Rock Rat and other native fauna species. In general the project may involve a significant component of remote area camping will also be conducted.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety, Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

The Tennant Creek Green Corps Team will assist in developing methods for sparrow control and eradication in the Tennant Creek and Barkly district. The team will also assist in the management of historic buildings. Major project activity will be identifying nesting sites of sparrows, constructing devices to catch sparrows and restrict access, monitoring and recording sparrow movements and control of Parkinsonia. The project may involve a significant component of remote area camping.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Impacts of Introduced Land Practices and Vegetation Restoration Techniques

The aim of this project is to repair, stabilise, revegetate, enhance and protect areas within the Katherine River Corridor. Major project activity will be erosion control, tree planting, control of noxious weeds and rubbish removal. The project will implement recommendations in the Katherine River Master Plan.
Environmental Audit, First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation, Occupational Health and Safety Recognition of Weeds and Weed Control Techniques

This project will assist with the protection of habitat of the Wingless Grasshopper within the Murrumbidgee River Corridor as well as erosion control on Mt Painter. Major project activity will be Grasshopper surveys, weed control, vegetation mappings and erosion control.

answer.para: ROUND 3

entry.para: First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration, Industry Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Wire Fencing for Conservation Areas

The project will contribute to the Central West Catchment Management Committee's Strategic Plan to restore high priority catchment areas. The project will involve fencing and revegetation of creeks and gullies to stabilise and improve wildlife habitat. It will also provide protection for Aboriginal cultural heritage sites and areas of traditional plant foods. The partner agency for the project is the Gilgandra Adolescent Support Project.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety Park Pathway Construction and Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1

The project will combine on-going commitment to revegetation along Sydney Olympic transport corridors with track construction in Sydney Harbour National Park. Specific activities will include seed collection, propagation, tree planting, track construction and management of urban bushland.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The project aims to secure the existing remnant rainforest community and re-establish the original floristic composition of the Wollomai Point headland. Invasive weeds will be removed and controlled. Planting of native species will be undertaken to protect and extend the rainforest remnant. The training and project bases may be in Wollongong. The Green Corps team will undertake the project in partnership with the Lake Illawarra Authority.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety ,Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas

The project is consistent with local catchment management goals and aims to restore the banks of the Shoalhaven River to their natural vegetated state. Trainees will remove lantana and other introduced weeds, revegetate, survey flora and fauna, erect fences to control stock access and repair historic rock wall fences. The training and project bases may be at Nowra. The partner agency is the Bundanon Trust.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Park Pathway Construction

The project will assist in controlling visitor access to Broken Head Nature Reserve by a rationalisation of walking tracks. The project will also involve weed control and revegetation to restore habitat and control erosion. The training and project bases will be in Byron Bay. The project will be undertaken in consultation with NSW Parks and Wildlife Service.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The project site is based at historic Tocal Homestead. The project will involve regeneration of riverine rainforest and wetlands, construction of post and rail fences and building conservation. The project is consistent with the approved conservation plan for the homestead and will be done in conjunction with the C.B Alexander Agricultural College. The training and project bases may be in Maitland.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The project will protect and improve a range of values related to significant coastal remnant vegetation at Seaford and Grantville foreshore. The trainees will collect seeds, transplant seedlings (including mangroves), control environmental weeds, maintain tracks, erect fences and stabilise sand dunes. The training and project bases may be at Seaford.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Animal Handling, Tree Climbing / Arboriculture, Vegetation Restoration Techniques, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The project will focus on the capture and relocation of koalas from Snake Island to mainland Victoria. Snake Island is massively over-populated by koalas and habitat trees are under great stress. The project will contribute to habitat survival and long-term viability of the koala population. The trainees will be assisting with Parks Victoria officers and reside in accommodation on Snake Island during the weeks the project is there. The training and the mainland project bases may be in the Latrobe Valley area.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas

The project aims to minimise further loss of priority remnant vegetation on the Guildford Plateau fringes. It will involve remnant bush regeneration including creation of wildlife corridors by fencing, tree planting and environment weed control. The Green Corps team may be based in Castlemaine for training. The project will be undertaken in conjunction with the Guildford/Upper Loddon Landcare Group.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The project will implement the City of Ballarat LINCS Strategy to establish linear reserves in the Ballarat region. It will involve establishing the BallaratâSkipton Rail Trail and the rehabilitation of the Yarrowee River by weed control, tree planting and track work.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The Townsville Green Corps project is to be undertaken in conjunction with Queensland Rail. The project involves the rehabilitation of riparian and woodland zones which Queensland Rail has committed to rehabilitate before donating for public use. The project will involve removal of exotic weeds, planting of native species, seed collection, propagation and maintenance of plantings.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Park Pathway Construction

The Yeppoon project is in two partsâIt will undertake extensive rehabilitation to upgrade existing walking tracks so that visitor impact is minimised. The project will also promote the regeneration of foreshore vegetation communities by the removal of invasive weeds. Assistance with the project will be provided by the Department of Environment. The training and project bases may be at Rockhampton.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The Mount Tamborine project involves the rehabilitation of the Cedar Creek riparian corridor, including weed removal, bank stabilisation and revegetation. The project will enhance a major wildlife corridor linking existing remnant vegetation with established National Parks. The Mount Tamborine Natural History Association will work in partnership on the project. Bases for the project and training may be on the Gold Coast.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques Recognition of Weeds, Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas

Cardwell Shire Council will be involved with Tully Green Corps team to focus on the Wet Tropics high conservation value area of Mission Beach / Tully, Murray Catchment. The project will address issues of riparian degradation through revegetation, enhancement of key habitat areas of endangered species (Cassowary), and development of walking tracks.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1 and Field Plant Identification

The project aims to preserve the biodiversity of the Tolga Scrub which contains a number of rare and threatened species. The Green Corps team will be involved in extensive rehabilitation and revegetation tasks as well as on the construction of an interpretive walkway. The project and training bases may be in Atherton. Atherton Shire Council is the partner agency for the project.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Park Pathway Construction

The project will assist in implementation of Purga Wetlands Reserve Concept Plan, specifically by conserving the largest pocket of remnant swamp tea tree in the Ipswich region and facilitating visitor access. The project will involve trail construction, boardwalk construction, weed control, revegetation, fencing, seed collection and propagation. Ipswich City Council is the partner agency.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and wire fencing of Conservation Areas

The Darling Downs Green Corps project and training bases will be in Oakley or Toowoomba. The project will involve management of fifty hectares of remnant vegetation. This will involve fencing, controlling environmental weeds and planting 6,000 trees in association with landcare groups in line with the Condamine Catchment Strategic Plan.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Chainsaw Operation

The project will be undertaken in conjunction with the Gympie and District Landcare Group. The project is a component of a major urban landcare initiative to revegetate the riparian corridor along a permanent creek in Gympie. It will involve eradication of woody weeds and invasive vines, re-establishment of riparian habitat, creek bank stabilisation and walkway construction.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Field Plant Identification and Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1

The project will restore and protect native vegetation associated with the world heritage features of the Naracoorte caves, specifically by planting to reinstate natural hydrologised processes affecting the caves. The project will also assist with seed collection and tree removal and include a major component of interpretive display construction.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Eco Skills 1 and Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1

The Department of Environment and Natural Resources has worked with a Green Corps Round 1 Project Team on Kangaroo Island. The project will provide the Department with continued assistance in the capture, sterilisation and relocation of koalas from Kangaroo Island. The project will also assist with seed collection and fencing for habitat restoration.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Wire Fencing for Conservation Areas

The project will assist with the implementation of the Tookayerta Catchment Plan by revegetation, controlling weeds, seed collection and improvement of habitat. The trainees will research native fish populations, evaluate threats to Black Swamp and construct fences. The project has been established in conjunction with Compass Creek Care Inc. The training may be based at Victor Harbour.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Mammal Surveying Techniques

The project will be undertaken in conjunction with Department of Environment and Natural Resources. The project will restore and protect habitat in coastal reserves near Robe and contribute to the aims of the Little Dip Conservation Management Plan. The project will involve weed survey and control, vermin survey and control, erosion control, revegetation and construction of vehicle barriers. The project and training bases may be in Mount Gambier.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Introduction to Machinery

The partner agency for the Bayswater Project is Regeneration Technology Pty Ltd. Based in Perth, the project will focus on enhancing habitat and water quality in Baigup Reserve, one of only two Western Australian wetland restoration projects listed on the National Register. The project will involve planing, weed control, boardwalk construction and installation of educational signage.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Path Pathway Construction

The project will develop and implement strategic plans for path management in the Fitzgerald River National Park. The major project will concentrate on the coastal route from Point Ann in the wilderness zone to Myllies Beach. The training and project bases may be in Albany.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques 1, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The South Coast Wetlands project will focus on restoring corridor linkages between remnant vegetation associated with wetlands and restoring corridors linking the Stirling Ranges National Park, the Fitzgerald biosphere and protection of Pallinup River Catchment. The project will involve flora and fauna surveys, seed collection and storage, weed control, feral control, fencing and ground water monitoring. The base for the project and the training may be in Denmark.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Vegetation Restoration Techniques and Basic Building / Renovation Skills

The project will focus on protection of endangered fauna by assisting Project Eden in eradicating feral animals from Peron Peninsula and reintroducing native species. Green Corps trainees will assist with threatened fauna captive breeding, reintroduction and monitoring. The project will also help to restore a shearing shed and in collecting seeds for planting. The project and training bases may be in either Geraldton or Carnavon.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Park Pathway Constructions

The N.R. Pierce Memorial Reserve in Glenorchy presents 13 different native plant communities which have high or significantly high conservation values. The project will develop and initiate management practices for the Reserve. It will involve erosion control, weed eradication, rehabilitation, track maintenance and invertebrate surveys. The training and project bases may be in Hobart. Glenorchy City Council will be the partner Agency.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Chainsaw Operation

The project will plan and commence implementation of an environmental weed management strategy encompassing the development of a management plan for Little Penguins in the area. The project will involve removal of environmental weeds, survey of penguins and nesting sites and protection of habitat. The project will be undertaken in conjunction with Burnie City Council.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques and Recognition of Weeds

The Cataract Gorge Green Corps team will be based in Launceston. The project will assist the Cataract Gorge Reserve Management Plan by controlling bushland weeds and willows along South Esk River. Repairs and maintenance on walking tracks throughout the Gorge Reserve will also be undertaken. The partner agency will be Launceston City Council.
First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Vegetation Restoration

The project will assist four Landcare groups with bush regeneration in urban Darwin. The project will involve weed control, site preparation, tree planting in association with Arbor Month and follow-up maintenance.

First Aid, Introduction to Land Conservation and Restoration Industry, Environmental Audit, Occupational Health & Safety, Weed Control Techniques, Recognition of Weeds and Wire Fencing of Conservation Areas

The project will involve revegetation and maintenance of indigenous riparian plants and grasses along the Murrumbidgee river corridor. This will be achieved by planting, fencing to exclude stock and the removal of exotic weeds from revegetation sites. The project will be undertaken in conjunction with ACT Parks and Wildlife Service. The training and project bases may be in Canberra.

subdebateinfo.title: Department for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 906)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

question.para: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The following research has been identified:

para.inline: Film, National Broadcasting And Intellectual Property

answer.para: 1. The Department has provided a grant to Monash University as part of the Performing Arts Multimedia Library (PAML) program.

2. The grant is to cover the cost of appointment of copyright advisers on a project being conducted by Monash University. The project involves supplying audio-visual material from the PAML program across an experimental broadband network within the University and to certain Victorian schools. The advisers will engage in a number of tasks including examining all issues of copyright relating to online interactive media from technical, legal and industry perspectives. Guidelines will also be produced for the negotiating of digital copyright agreements, for the guidance of performing arts and multimedia industries.
3. Monash University
4. The Department has provided $92,000.00 to Monash University.
Cultural DevelopmentâNew Media
1. New Media Section had the following qualitative/quantitative research conducted since 3 March 1996:
. Two research projects conducted from 21 March to 30 June 1997 relating to the PAML.
. One session of focus group testing on 10 September 1997 relating to the development of Australia's Cultural Network website.

2. (a) The PAML Marketing Study was conducted to provide a comparative assessment of a variety of electronic products and distribution mechanisms which the Department of communications and the Arts (DCA) and performing arts organisations might consider in making PAML recordings accessible via Australia's Cultural Network (ACN) and other electronic environments. The PAML Universal Resource Locator (URL) from which the Report can be downloaded is being publicised to performance arts companies and administrators with related responsibilities: http://www.dca.gov.au/ahnbd/paml.html

(b) The PAML research project on intellectual property issues was conducted to identify such issues in relation to the delivery of recorded performances by means of on-line technologies; and research holdings of recordings of significant Australian performances by Commonwealth agencies. Apart from local and international research, the project included a program of interviews and assessment of responses to a ten-part questionnaire. The Researcher has provided some material from interviewees on an `in- confidence' basis to the Department of Communications and the Arts. The rest of the report and its recommendations have been made available to the PAML Steering Committee and officers with relevant duties within DCA.

(c) Australia's Cultural Network (ACN) focus group assessment of the website prototype was conducted to test the proposed look, feel, and functionality of the Website prototype for Australia's Cultural Network. Thirty six people participated in four focus group sessions answering 50 questions. An evaluation of the results was prepared for the New Media Section of the Department which has responsibility for the development of the ACN website.
3. (a) Stephen Hall and Associates, 4 Mair Place, Curtin ACT 2605
(b) Globalink Communications Pty Ltd, 8/2-6 Lugar Street, Waverley NSW 2024
(c) Deborah Wilson Consulting Services Pty. Ltd., Level 7, 10 Felix Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000.
Cultural Industry Development

1. The Department has commissioned from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) since 3 March 1996 a number of statistical research projects on cultural matters. Those which have reached fruition are:
(a) A census of businesses which employed staff and which were predominantly engaged in book publishing in 1995-96.

(b) A census of businesses mainly involved in selected music activities (record companies and distributors, manufacturers of recorded music, music publishers, sound recording studios) in respect of the financial year 1995-96.

2. In relation to the research referred to at 1(a), 214 businesses were surveyed, the questionnaire comprising 36 questions. The research was made available to the public. In relation to the research referred to at 1(b), a total of 541 businesses were surveyed of whom 249 received a questionnaire comprising 65 questions and the remaining 292, which were sound recording studios, a questionnaire comprising 48 questions. To date, the research has been made available to the public in summary form.
3. None.

4. The research referred to at 1(a) cost $100,000. The research referred to at 1(b) cost a total of $400,000. The project was initially contracted before 3 March 1996 at a cost of $200,000. An expansion of the project at a cost of a further $200,000 was decided on after that date.
ArtsInfo

1. In connection with the implementation of the Government's initiative, the ArtsInfo telephone information and referral service and website, which provides a single access point to the full range of opportunities and assistance available to the cultural sector, the Department commissioned the following research:
(a) initial market research
(b) concept testing and a benchmark study of potential users
(c) focus group testing of the prototype website design and data-base structure and subsequently of website.

2. In relation to 1(a) the research combined qualitative research based on interviews with 57 members of the cultural sector, including cultural organisations, grant applicants and service providers, together with quantitative research based on 293 interviews with members of the same population. The qualitative interviews were loosely structured and lasted from 3/4 to 1 and a half hours. The quantitative interviews used a fully structured questionnaire and lasted on average 12-15 minutes. The research results were made available to the Department. In relation to 1(b) the sample was 324 cultural sector workers, peak body advisers and service providers. They were interviewed by telephone using a questionnaire which differed for each of the three types of respondent. The research results were made available to the Department. In relation to 1(c), the earlier testing involved a total of 83 emerging and established artists in eight focus groups lasting 90 minutes each. The later testing involved four focus groups comprising some of the artists involved in the earlier groups. These later focus groups involved between 6 and 10 participants and sessions lasted 90 minutes. The research results were made available to the Department.

3. In relation to 1(a) the firm engaged to undertake the work was Artcraft Research. In relation to 1(b), the firm engaged to undertake the work was Worthington Di Marzio. In relation to 1(c), the firm engaged was Deborah Wilson Consulting Services Pty Ltd.
4. In relation to 1(a), the cost was $30,000. In relation to 1(b) the cost was $39,900. In relation to 1(c), the cost was $12,239.
National Gallery Of Australia
1. The National Gallery of Australia conducts continuous weekly Visitor Surveys to measure visitor satisfaction and obtain quantitative data regarding usage of National Gallery products and services.
2. Weekly Visitor Surveys were conducted resulting in 150 completed questionnaires per week (A4 sheet double-sided). The results were used internally and to advise Canberra tourism industry.
3. Market Attitude Research Services Pty Ltd.
Reader Survey
1. Two-week pilot study of questionnaire.
2. To determine user satisfaction with Reading Room services. Carried out over two weeks in December 1996 for internal use only. Full length survey not yet carried out.
3. No outside firm used.
4. Not costedâmet from internal resources.
National Portrait Gallery Evaluation
1. One visitor survey and four stakeholder surveys.

2. To determine effectiveness of NPG in meeting its objectives. Conducted from January-March 1997. National Portrait Gallery Evaluation Draft Report issued March 1997 for the information of NPG Advisory Committee, Library Corporate Management Group.
3. No outside firm used.
4. Not formally costedâmet from internal resources. Staff seconded: 1 x PO-1,
7 weeks; 1 x ASO6, 12 weeks. Steering Committee included a representative from DCA.
Customer Service Charter Survey
1. 6,000 printed questionnaires distributed in October 1997.

2. To gauge staff, user and stakeholder response to draft Customer Service Charter. Questionnaire also made available on Library WWW server. Comments to be incorporated into final version, to be issued in 1998.
3. No outside firm used.
4. Not formally costedâmet from internal resources. Staff seconded: 1 x SOGC, 12 weeks.

para.inline: QUESTACONâThe National Science And Technology Centre

answer.para: Evaluation of advertising concepts for the BHP WildScience exhibition

1. This research was done in April-May 1996 to explore target audience reactions to three different advertising concepts developed for possible use in the marketing of the BHP WildScience exhibition (a hands-on science and technology exhibition developed by Questacon in collaboration with other science centres and museums around Australia)

2. The research involved fewer than 100 people, with each of the 12 group sessions (spread over Sydney and Newcastle) lasting between half an hour and an hour. The results of the research, in broad outline, were available to the marketing/public affairs officers of the science centres and museums participating in the project, and to the relevant BHP representative. The results were used as part of the process of selecting an advertising agency for the project, and the detailed research report was used by Questacon in framing the brief for development of advertising materials for the exhibition. Feedback relating to individual advertising concepts was also passed to the companies responsible for the development of each concept.
3. Environmetrics Pty Ltd
Development of an evaluation package for the BHP WildScience exhibition

1. To enable comparison of the success of the BHP WildScience exhibition in relation to its educational objectives at the ten different venues on its 1996-2000 itinerary, an evaluation package comprising two visitor surveys was developed in late 1996-early 1997. The development of this package included testing of the evaluation tools with Questacon visitors.

2. 122 Questacon visitors were surveyed, with data collectors filling in answers to a standard set of questions (a mix of closed and open ended questions), taking between 5 and 10 minutes per interview. A modified version of the questionnaire was provided to 26 teachers who had brought class groups to visit the exhibition. The results of the research were available to Questacon, BHP, and other science centres/museums involved in the project. The same evaluation materials are being provided to other venues hosting the exhibition.
3. Interactive Consultants Pty Ltd
Promotional study of the BHP WildScience exhibition

1. This was a study carried out over the period September 1996-February 1997 to gain a profile of exhibition visitors, explore factors involved in awareness issues to assist communications strategy planning, and to evaluate visitor satisfaction with the BHP WildScience exhibition.

2. The first part of the study, with seventy interviews, was part of ongoing research for the Canberra Visitors Study and involved special questions on BHP WildScience being added to a standard questionnaire. A further 128 interviews were conducted with exhibition visitors to provide a larger sample specifically focused on this exhibition. The research results were made available to Questacon, with the general data also available to Canberra Tourism and the other Canberra attractions that took part in the Canberra Visitors Study.
3. Frank Small and Associates.
Evaluation of NRMA Tomorrow's Drivers exhibition

1. This research, being carried out in September-November 1997, is assessing visitor reactions to the Tomorrow's Drivers exhibition, and also exploring the needs of a key target group (teachers and school students) to assist in planning a possible upgrade of the exhibition.

2. The research has involved focus groups, paired face-to-face interviews and telephone interviews. The target audience includes teachers, students, parents, curriculum advisers, road safety educators and media representatives. A total of 100-150 people will be involved, in five locations (Sydney, Geelong, Tamworth, Nowra, Brisbane), covering the locations where the exhibition has been seen in the last eighteen months. The results of the research will be used by Questacon and NRMA in joint planning of the future of the Tomorrow's Drivers program.
3. Environmetrics Pty Ltd.
Promotional evaluation of Off the Planet, K'nexhibition and Terrorsaurus

1. This study is to provide feedback to assist in finetuning the communication strategies for the exhibitions and to evaluate visitor satisfaction with each of the three exhibitions. The study is being undertaken in four partsâ(i) evaluating the Off the Planet and K'nexhibition exhibitions during July 1997; (ii) evaluating the Terrorsaurus exhibition during September 1997; (iii) indepth interviews with visitors in October 1997; and (iv) evaluating the Terrorsaurus exhibition during January 1998.

2. Phases (i), (ii) and (iv) of the study involve interviewing of the order of 100 visitors to each of the exhibitions. Phase (iii) of the study involves indepth interviews with ten visitors to Terrorsaurus. The results of the research will be used internally by Questacon.
3. Frank Small and Associates.

1. Since 3 March 1996, the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has undertaken qualitative and quantitative research into a number of broadcasting issues in accordance with its primary function as specified in s.158(g) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992: `to conduct or commission research into community attitudes on issues relating to programs'.
ABA attitudinal research conducted since 3 March 1996 has consisted of the following projects:
A. monitoring industry codes of practice;
B. young families and television;
C. young Australians and music; and
D. media usage by migrants to Australia.
In addition to the above, the ABA has released three research monographs since 3 March 1996 based on research conducted prior to that date:
. Families and electronic entertainment, June 1996;
. Music, new music and all that: Teenage radio in the 90s, June 1996;
. Kids talk TV: `super wickid' or `dum', September 1996.
As the research for these monographs was conducted prior to the specified date, no further details are provided in relation to parts 2, 3 and 4 of the question.
A. Monitoring Industry Codes of Practice
2. Nature of Research and Provision of Results

In September 1996, as part of its ongoing role to monitor the effectiveness of the commercial television industry code of practice, the ABA conducted a third national survey on people's concerns about material they had seen on television. The survey was conducted with a sample of 1157 people representative of the population 14 years of age and over. The survey consisted of 35 questions administered face-to-face as part of an omnibus survey.

The research measured awareness of television classifications, in particular the M and MA classifications, and the perceived suitability of movies on commercial television starting at 8.30 pm. The suitability of the movies was gauged in relation to the use of swearing, and the presentation of sex scenes, nudity and violence.

Preliminary results were provided to the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS) in December 1996. The results were provided to enable FACTS to consider any implications during its review of the commercial television industry code of practice.
The results were published in August 1997 as part of the ABA's Trends and Issues series: Views on viewing: community views about commercial television, 1994-1996.

In October 1997, some of the questions on concerns about television material are being repeated in a fourth national survey aimed at monitoring industry codes of practice. The 1997 survey also includes questions on concerns about material heard on radio. The sample for the 1997 survey is slightly smallerâapproximately 1000 peopleâbut again representative of the population aged 14 years and over. The 1997 survey consists of 26 questions and as in 1996, is being administered face-to-face as part of an omnibus survey.

Results of the 1997 survey will be provided to FACTS and to the Federation Australian Radio Broadcasters (FARB). They will also made publicly available in an ABA publication in the first half of 1998.
3. Firms Engaged
Roy Morgan Research Centre was commissioned to conduct the 1996 survey. The 1997 survey is being conducted by AC Nielsen McNair.
4. Cost
The 1996 survey cost $36,000, while the 1997 survey will cost $24,580.
B. Young Families and Television
2. Nature of Research and Provision of Results

The ABA is conducting an analysis of data on the amount and type of television watched by preschool-aged children. The research is also looking at parents' attitudes, and their behaviour, towards their child's viewing. The data was collected as part of a larger study conducted by Dr Brent Waters, formerly the Director of Psychiatric Services at St Vincent's Hospital, and Dr Judy Ungerer of Macquarie University.

The sample for the research was 157 couples and their first-born child in the Sydney metropolitan area. Two methods were used to collect data from the sample at each of four assessment points: prior to the child's birth, when the child was four months of age, when the child was 12 months of age, and when the child was 30 months of age.

The first method of data collection was a questionnaire which varied in length at each of the four assessment points and increased in length as the child got older. The second was a viewing diary in which each family was asked to record their television and video viewing over a seven-day period. Data collection started in April 1988 and finished in August 1994.
The ABA is preparing a publication which will report the results of the research. It is expected that this will be publicly available by the end of this year.
3. Firms Engaged
In March 1995, the ABA funded Dr Waters and Dr Ungerer to sub-contract a research assistant to enter, code and begin analysing data from the questionnaires.
4. Cost
The funding was for a total of $10,000.
C. Young Australians and Music
2. Nature of Research and Provision of Results

Young people and music are the focus of a joint research project being undertaken by the ABA in conjunction with the Australia Council and the Australian Recording Industry Association. Information is being gathered about the role of music in the lives of young people (12 to 24 years of age) and their attitudes to the music currently available to them. It is considering music delivery through radio, television, CDs and newer delivery mechanisms such as the Internet. Live performances and the participation of young people in music are also being considered.
The research consists of the following stages: a literature review, consultative stage, and qualitative and quantitative data collection.
The ABA commissioned a comprehensive literature review as the first stage of the project. The review was released as a monograph, Youth and music in Australia: a review, in June 1997.

The consultative stage involved ABA staff conducting interviews with key stakeholders in music and youth related organisations. The interviews identified key issues for discussion in the qualitative stage and are helping to shape the quantitative stage.

The qualitative stage consisted of focus group discussions with young people in the target age range. Fourteen groups were conducted in April and May 1997 in a range of locations: Sydney, Darwin, Warwick and Melbourne.

The first three stages are feeding into the development of the quantitative stage. This final stage will obtain measures from a representative sample of Australian youth on the place of music in their lives and their attitudes to music access, consumption and participation issues. The methodology for the quantitative stage is currently being considered with field work scheduled for November 1997. Results will be made publicly available in a research monograph in 1998.
3. Firms Engaged
The ABA commissioned Juliet London Research and Consultancy to conduct the literature review.
While ABA staff facilitated the focus group discussions, various firms were engaged to recruit participants and provide venues for some of the groups.
Quadrant Research Services has been engaged to conduct the quantitative stage of the research.
4. Cost
The literature review cost $5,000.
The total amount paid to firms for focus group recruitment and venues was $1,598.
$50,000 has been budgeted for the quantitative stage.
D. Media Usage by Migrants to Australia
2. Nature of Research and Provision of Results

In February 1997, the ABA finalised arrangements with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) to include four questions on the third wave of Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants (LSIA) being conducted by DIMA during 1997 and 1998. The third wave of LSIA surveys approximately 5000 people who have migrated to Australia in the last few years.

The questions developed by the ABA seek information about media usage and perceptions of the portrayal of ethnic groups on commercial television. Questions about media usage ask about the frequency of use of radio, television, videos, newspapers and the Internet, as well as the media used most often for various news, information and entertainment services.
Due to the large sample for the survey, the data collection phase of LSIA occurs over an extended period of time. Preliminary results will therefore not be available until the second half of 1998.
3. Firms Engaged
DIMA has responsibility for the LSIA and is running the media usage questions on the ABA's behalf.
4. Cost
DIMA has charged the ABA a total of $20,000 to administer the questions and tabulate the results.
International Visitors and Aboriginal arts
1. International Visitors and Aboriginal arts.

2. Survey of international visitors: additional questions added to the regular survey by the Bureau of Tourism Research; the survey asked questions of international visitors to Australia about their purchases of Indigenous arts and crafts; Report to be published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. Bureau of Tourism Research
4. Total cost: $20,625
Preliminary Research on Indigenous artists
1. Preliminary Research on Indigenous artists
2. an exploratory research project to assess the extent of Indigenous arts practice in Australia;
Available to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board, the Australia Council and to interested researchers and members of the public on request
3. carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics
4. Total cost: $50,000
Economic Impact of the Arts in Australia
1. Economic Impact of the Arts in Australia

2. a national study of the economic impact of the arts in Australia using a statistical analysis of existing economic data relating to the arts; Report to be published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. project in progress: being carried out by Economic Strategies Pty Ltd
4. Total cost: $32,000
Music and Theatre Audience Research
1. Music and Theatre Audiences Research
2. a study of music and theatre audiences and potential audiences: qualitative and survey research; including a survey of 1000 people throughout Australia;
Report to be published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. project in progress: being carried out by Woolcott Research Pty Ltd
4. Total cost: $60,000
Arts Marketing Research Study
1. Arts Marketing Research Study
2. a study of the current marketing and audience development practices of arts organisations in Australia; Report published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. Biztrac and Donovan Research
4. Total cost: $60,000
Study of Consumers of Visual Arts and Crafts
1. Study of Consumers of Visual Arts and Crafts
2. a study of consumers and potential consumers of visual arts and crafts; Report published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. Quadrant Research Services Pty Ltd
4. Total cost: $42,900
Corporate Support for the Arts
1. Corporate Support for the Arts
2. the fourth in a series of statistical surveys of corporate support for the arts; Report published, widely distributed and freely available on request
3. Yann, Campbell, Hoare, Wheeler
4. Total cost: $24,500
Taxation and the Arts Research
1. Taxation and the Arts Research
2. analysis of various options for taxation reform and their impact on the arts; For information and advice to the Australia Council
3. project in progress; work being carried out by KPMG
4. Total cost: $25,000
Young Australians and Music
1. Young Australians and Music

2. joint research project with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) and the Australian Record Industry Association (ARIA) exploring the role of music in the lives of young Australians; Literature review published and widely distributed; further report to be published, widely distributed and freely available on request.
3. project in progress; work being carried out by the ABA and Quadrant Research Services Pty Ltd

1. In June 1996, the NTA conducted market research designed to evaluate viewers' perception of TV reception quality in the Sydney area. This research was intended to survey viewers' perceptions of their television reception in areas throughout Sydney, in order to alert NTA planners to any possible problems that might need to be addressed in regard to transmission of ABC and SBS services.

2. A two-page questionnaire was completed by approximately 100 households chosen at random in ten Sydney suburbs, and an additional 500 households were interviewed over the phone to obtain data. The results were collated by Quadrant Research Services, and evaluated by the Agency's Transmission Planning Unit and E D Field Engineering, who conducted follow-up work in the areas surveyed. The survey results were not publicised outside the NTA.
3. Quadrant Research Services Pty Ltd were engaged to conduct this market research.

1. The research undertaken by SBS is, essentially, audience research. Most of this is the kind undertaken by all free-to-air television stationsâthe daily A.C. Nielsen audience measurement, and more detailed audience response surveys by News-
poll. SBS has commissioned one additional Newspoll survey in the period since 3/3/96.

In addition, SBS has commissioned language group surveys to assess ethnic community trends in listening and viewing. The last form of surveying has been commissioned over the past 14 months from Quadrant and is ongoing.

2. A.C. Nielsen: quantitative, measured by electronic People Meter technology in-home installation. Sample sizes are approximately 500 in both Sydney and Melbourne and 400 in the other State capitals. Major aggregated regional television markets are also metered in this way with a sample size comparable to Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth. The results are circulated to management, programming and production staff for performance monitoring purposes.

Newspoll: quantitative and qualitative. Specific SBS-related questions, at roughly six-monthly intervals, to the regular Newspoll national omnibus survey gauge quantity of SBS programs viewed per household per week, public perceptions, value assessments, program regard and reception capability. Regular tracking results are provided to TV management, while special survey results are provided to SBS management and the Board.
Quadrant: quantitative, gauging audience levels for SBS Radio language programs and for SBS Television based on language groups. The sample sizes are as follows:
Arabic, Cantonese, Mandarin, Khmer, Polish 400 per survey
Vietnamese, Greek, Italian, Spanish 800 per survey
The results are circulated to relevant SBS Radio and marketing staff, management and the Board.
3. A.C.Nielsen, Newspoll, Quadrant
4. The cost of A.C. Nielsen audience research is commercial confidential.
A.C. Nielsen treats as commercial in confidence all fees paid by its clients.
The cost of Newspoll audience research was $39,294 since 1/3/96.
The cost of Quadrant research into language groups was $152,560.00.
For information relating to the Telecommunications Industry Division (TID), the Australian Communications Authority (ACA), Australia Post and Telstra, please refer to the following table:

entry.para: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.
(ECONTECH consultancy (14 June 1996 to 19 June 1996)reported on Telstra's labour and capital efficiency.

ECONTECH was engaged to use its proprietary economic modelling system to assess projected Telstra labour and capital efficiencies. The resultant data was used in the Departmental submission to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee inquiry into Telstra. The consultancy was limited to the processing and analysis of labour and capital efficiency. It did not involve making recommendations on the Department's submission to the Senate Inquiry.

On 7 July 1996, the Minister for Communications and the Arts established the Standard Telephone Service Review Group with the objective "to determine whether recent and emerging development in telecommunications technology, or increased demand for more advanced telecommunications services in the Australian community warranted a change in the level of service mandated under the Universal Service Obligation."

The review was undertaken by the Group consisting of ten members, including the Chair from the Communications Law Centre. Membership was drawn from organisations representing a range of consumer interests and industry representation. The Group held 13 meetingsâa combination of in-person meetings, tele-conferences and a video conference. Several organisations were invited to make presentations to Group meetings. The Review Group reported to the Minister in December 1996. The Report was made publicly available on request from the Department of Communications and the Arts and on the Department's Internet Homepage.
A consulting fee was paid to the Communications Law Centre (CLC).

The cost of the review was $37,570. This amount includes the $10,000 consulting fee paid to CLC; incidental expenses including report printing; travel and related expenses for the Chair, two other Group members, and the Departmental Secretariat. To minimise the travel expenses involved the meetings were held in Sydney where the majority of consumer representatives were located and no funding was provided to carrier representatives.

On 8 September 1997 the Department of Communications and the Arts invited proposals for consultancy services to provide the assistance of an accountant experienced in the telecommunications industry to assist in defining "eligible revenue" and ensure that, as far as practicable, the definition is linked to established accounting standards and practices. The aim is to develop a definition which is transparent, simple to apply and administer.
The approach falls into three stages:
The total cost payable under this Contract shall not exceed $17,000, unless written approval has first been obtained from the Department.

(a) Position Paper Critiqueâliaising by phone with Department, consultant to provide initial critique and comment on the draft position paper prepared by the Department of Communications and the Arts
(b) Workshop Attendanceâconsultant to fly to Melbourne the day before the workshop to meet with Departmental officers in preparation for participating in the workshop on an advisory capacity.
(c) Post Workshopâconsultant to work with Departmental officers in finalising the paper which specifies the new regime.

On 15 August, the Department of Communications and the Arts engaged two consultants, International Consulting Services and CommStrategies International, to investigate and report on the current billing practices between Telstra and other service providers.

Together with Telstra, four service providers agreed to take part in the study. The consultants investigated the current situation, including sample testing and collection of statistics and assessment of service levels. The report has been given to the Minister for consideration of the recommendations.
International Consulting Services and CommStrategies International.
The Department has incurred no costs in relation to this consulting study, as all costs were borne by Telstra.
AGB McNair was commissioned in July 1996 to conduct a qualitative and quantitative survey.
The survey was conducted in two parts:
The cost of the work undertaken was $27,500
The nature of the work was to conduct market research on the extent of awareness within the community of possible health issues associated with electromagnetic energy.
-a quantitative phone survey of a random nationwide sample of the Australian population; and
-a qualitative survey comprising in person in-depth interviews with concerned individuals and groups identified from ministerial and other representations.
The results of the survey were announced in a joint media relass from Senator Alston and Dr Wooldridge MP.

A consultancy was undertaken to assist the States and Territories with the transition to the new regime for regulating telecommunications infrastructure post 1 July 1997. The consultancy was overseen by a steering committee comprising representatives of each State and Territory and Federal Government.

The work involved consultations with carriers and representatives of the States and Territories. The final report was provided to the carriers, each State and Territory and made available via the Department's web site. Most States and Territories have circulated the report to groups representing local government.
Purdon Associates (Canberra) in association with Ratio Consultants (Melbourne) and Clayton Utz, Solicitors.
$109,850. Funds were provided by the carriersâTelstra, Optus and Vodafoneâon a proportional basis. The Department provided assistance with project management.

The Department is providing a secretariat for the Working Group on Putting Cables Underground ("the PCUWG"). The Departmental secretariat has, on behalf of that Working Group, engaged consultants to provide research on a number of issues in relation to putting cables underground. The funding for the PCUWG has been provided by industry and is held in a trust fund administered by the Department.
Develop principles to assist the PCUWG in identifying the appropriate role of governments, utilities, local councils, property owners and others in funding any program for putting cables underground.
$29,900, paid out of the industry money held by the Department on trust for the PCUWG.
Provide the PCUWG with methodologies for assessing the economic, equity, public finance and other impacts of options for funding any program for putting cables underground.
$55,000, paid out of the industry money held by the Department on trust for the PCUWG.

Prepare a report for the PCUWG on technical options and recommendations developed by an expert group in relation to the technical and service aspects of putting telecommunications and electricity cables underground.
$29,100, paid out of the industry money held by the Department on trust for the PCUWG.
Produce a background paper which addressed legal, regulatory and industry structure issues which may arise from regulatory options for putting cables underground which the PCUWG is examining.
$87,000, paid out of the industry money held by the Department on trust for the PCUWG.

Provide research and specialist advice to the PCUWG on: (a) Existing literature and research on putting cables underground; (b) The likely kinds of benefits and costs arising from putting cables underground; (c) Development of models for estimating the aggregate cost and benefits of putting cables underground at both a national and a local level.
Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics
$138,066, paid out of the industry money held by the Department on trust for the PCUWG.

The answer incorporates information in respect of research commissioned externally by the Australian Communications Authority, the former Spectrum Management Agency and those elements of the former AUSTEL which now form part of the Australian Communications Authority.
Research Commissioned by the Australian Communications Authority
In July 1997, a quantitative report was commissioned on business and domestic consumers' understanding of the implications of common or no area codes on long-distance call charges.

606 businesses and households were asked 10 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The consultant for this survey was Brian Sweeney & Associates.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $30,508.
Research Commissioned by the Spectrum Management Agency
In March 1996, the SMA undertook research on service delivery by way of a series of surveys of the Agency's external clients. The objectives of the surveys were to:
The surveys were directed at three separate areas of the Agency's activities:
The cost of the research was $27,750
determine how the Agency's clients perceived service from its offices around Australia;
Apparatus Licence clients with a sample size of 1498 "Australia wide";
determine clients' preferences on dealing with the Agency in the future with respect to financial transactions and method of contact; and
clients reporting radio and television interference complaints with a sample size of 200 "Australia wide"; and
establish a benchmark for measuring changes in the quality of service delivery.
clients who apply for radiocommunications operator qualifications with a sample size of 200 "Australia wide".
Two data collection mechanisms were used in the surveys:
written self-completion questionnaires administered by mail; licensing clients, 72 questions; television and radio interference complaints, 45 questions; and operator qualifications, 45 questions.
in-depth one-on-one telephone interviews to obtain qualitative data with a sample of 200 clients, 20 questions.

The analysis and report was for internal use by the Agency. A copy of the report was also provided to the Australian National Audit Office to assist with an audit of service delivery in radio and telecommunications.
Study to evaluate the introduction of regulations enhancing the electro-magnetic compatibility of electronic and electrical goods offered for sale in Australia.

The study commenced in 1995 and consists of an annual survey of 1,000 to 1,500 suppliers of electrical and electronic products to the Australian market. In May/June 1996, suppliers were asked to complete a questionnaire outlining their expectations for the forthcoming regulations. In June 1997, after the introduction of regulations, suppliers were asked their opinion of the effectiveness of the SMA/ACA method of introduction and the effect of the regulations on their services. A concluding survey is scheduled for 1998. The results are available to the public on request.
A consortium led by Hi-Tech Marketing Services (including the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research).
In 1996 the cost of the survey and reporting was $39,850. In 1997 the cost was $51,975.
Review of Issues concerning International Satellite Network Coordination and Planning
Research in preparation for a review of the International Telecommunications Unions' frequency coordination and planning framework for satellite networks.
The research involved a review and revision of documents. The results of the research were made available to the Spectrum Management Agency.
Mr Gary C Brooks, Ontario, Canada.
The cost of the consultancy was $14,850.00.

A qualitative research study was undertaken in February 1997 to assist with questionnaire design and to provide a basis for the interpretation of survey results for a quantitative study to be undertaken in May 1997. The aim of the survey was to assess the understanding and awareness of mobile phone users regarding the closure of the analogue mobile phone network on 1 January, 2000.

Four discussion groups were conducted in February 1997. These groups comprised two groups in Melbourne (comprising one group of Small Business users and one group of 18 to 30 year old domestic users) and two groups in Horsham (comprising one group of Small Business users and one group of 30-50 year old domestic users). The results of the research were made available to the members of the Analogue Closure Public Education Campaign Advisory Committee including the mobile phone carriers, industry and consumer groups.
The firms engaged to undertake research were Grey Advertising, subcontracting to Brian Sweeney and Associates.
The cost of the research was met by the telecommunications carriers and was $14,343.65.

A quantitative research study was conducted in May/June 1997 to gain an understanding of levels of awareness and comprehension of, and attitudes towards, the closure of the analogue mobile phone network.

The research involved a telephone survey of 947 business and domestic respondents. The survey covered respondents in capital cities, large provincial cities and rural areas in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia:â
Firms engaged to undertake research were Grey Advertising, subcontracting to Brian Sweeney and Associates.
The cost of the research was $20,000 and was met by the telecommunications carriers.
411 from capital cities; 251 from larger Provincial cities; and 285 from rural areas.
The telephone survey involved 17 questions for domestic respondents and 15 questions for business respondents.

These survey results were published in a Media Releaseâ"ACA Announces Analogue Closure Awareness Research Results". Results were made available to the media and members of the Analogue Closure Public Education Campaign Advisory Committee, which includes the mobile phone carriers, industry and consumer groups.

The purpose of the research was to measure Telstra's performance against the requirements of the Universal Service Obligation and was specifically focussed on telephone ownership, usage and customers' opinions on service.
The research involved face-to-face interviews based on a questionnaire of 25 questions. The results of this research were not made available externally.
The cost of the consultancy was $46,550.
Telephone Connection Survey ReportâPopulation Survey Monitor (September and November 1996)

The surveys provided nation-wide statistics on the number of households with a telephone connected. The surveys also asked those respondents without a telephone connection for the main reason why there was no telephone in place.

4,101 households were visited for the surveys, from which 3,211 completed questionnaires were obtained. The surveys included questions on personal, household, dwelling and geographic characteristics of respondents. The results of the surveys were not made available externally.
The cost of the consultancy was $12,450.
In April 1997, a quantitative report was conducted on business and domestic awareness and understanding of the numbering change in Western Australia.

403 businesses and households were asked 11 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $22,881.38.

In September 1996, a quantitative report was conducted to understand why uptake of the new eight-digit telephone numbers in the Northern Territory was so low, and whether any weakness existed in awareness and comprehension of the numbering change.

205 people (105 domestic, 100 business) were asked 10 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $7,847.03.
In September 1996, a quantitative report was conducted on business and domestic awareness and understanding of the numbering change in Tasmania.

304 people (154 domestic; 150 business) were asked 12 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $14,512.50.

In July 1996, a quantitative advertisement concept test was conducted in Tasmania to gauge the clarity of `message delivery' in a proposed advertising concept for the Tasmanian number change. The research also examined expectations and attitudes with respect to the need to dial the area code in intra-area calls in Tasmania.

A sample size of 200 adults interviewed in Tasmanian shopping centres were asked 11 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $10,750.
Numbering Public Education ProgramâSydney Numbering Change Wave 3
In May 1996, a quantitative survey titled "Sydney Numbering Change Wave 3" was conducted to measure consumer understanding of the Sydney telephone number changes.

300 people (150 domestic; 150 business) were asked 11 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $14,334.05.
Numbering Public Education ProgramâNumbering Change Follow-Up Study
In April 1996, a quantitative survey was conducted to measure consumer understanding of the Sydney telephone number changes.

500 people were asked 14 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $23,888.65.
Numbering Public Education ProgramâSydney Phase 3 Advertising Execution Test
In April 1996, a quantitative survey was conducted to evaluate two draft advertising concepts for Phase 3 Sydney telephone number changes.

100 people were asked 9 questions. The results of the research were made available to the Numbering Public Education Program Committee including representatives of Telstra, Optus, the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Department of Communications and the Arts, Community Information and Referral Service and the Citizens Advice Bureau.
The cost of the consultancy, which was met by telecommunications carriers, was $12,518.38.

As a GBE operating in a highly competitive commercial environment, Australia Post in the normal course undertakes a wide range of market research, principally in relation to product/service enhancement or development.
In Australia Post's case, therefore, much of the information sought by the question would be competitively sensitive and its public availability contrary to our commercial interests.
In addition, the information sought is not centrally located and its collation would likely take some considerable time and require significant resource commitment.

(1) & (2) Telstra undertakes research and development on specific business projects in many of its Business Units throughout the organisation with more exploratory research and development being undertaken at the Telstra Research Laboratories. Such research includes Services for Business Enterprises, Mobility Services and Systems, Consumer Services Infrastructure and Customer Care.

See answer to (2). Telstra regards additional information on its contractors as commercial-in-confidence. Research results are also regarded as commercial in confidence, although edited results may be published in technical journals where appropriate.

Telstra' total research and development expenditure between 1992 and 1997 totalled $1 billion. Over the next three year period, Telstra expects to invest about $500 million on research and development.
Telstra is also involved in external research through contracts with universities and other research providers throughout Australia.

Continuing support is also provided through the Cooperative Research Centres Scheme to the Australian Photonic Research Centre, the Distributed Systems Technology Centre, and the Research Data Networks Cooperative Research Centre.
In addition there are ongoing research contracts with the Institute for Telecommunications Research at the University of Wollongong, and the Teletraffic Research Centre at the University of Adelaide.
Telstra is required to operate as a commercial business operation, and consequently details of its market research must be regarded as commercial in confidence.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 909)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

question.para: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Only completed research undertaken externally by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AusAID has been included in this response.
This response does not cover research activity undertaken by institutions funded through DFAT or AusAID contributions or grants.

entry.para: Evaluation of benefits/results of 1996 Integrated Promotion in India, New Horizons

Survey of corporate participants. The results were made available to relevant policy and trade promotions areas within DFAT, Austrade, stakeholders in the business community, the media and other interested parties
Evaluation of the benefits/results of the 1994 Integrated Promotion in Indonesia, Australia Today Indonesia `94

Evaluation by extensive survey of participants and econometric modelling to interpret and project the economic benefits derived from the promotion for Australia. The results were made available to relevant areas of DFAT and Austrade.

The study involved comprehensive economic modelling of three separate scenariosâAFTA-CER only, APEC only and AFTA/CER and APECâand a baseline assessment using APG-cubed model (a multi country, multisector dynamic general equilibrium model). It was also necessary to build New Zealand into the model. The study was the first economic analysis to include economic modelling into a cost/benefit analysis of an AFTA-CER free-trade arrangement. The results were released publicly at the conference on The AFTA-CER Linkage: The Way Forward in Singapore on 5-6 September 1997. Copies of the study are available publicly from the MTIA or the Centre for International Economics.
The MTIA engaged the Centre for International Economics (Canberra) to undertaken the economic modelling and analysis.
The total cost of the study was $55,000. DFAT contributed $30,500. Further contributions were made by New Zealand MFAT $16,000, the MTIA $5,000 and the Australian Food Council $3,500.

Research conducted in 2 states with survey of about 100 small,medium and large firms for different sectors with further survey of the top 30 companies. Report distributed widely to processed food companies and on request to libraries, government departments (state and federal), media, overseas posts and consultants.
International Trade Strategies Pty Ltd, Four Design Group Pty Ltd and National Capital Printing (IMSEP Pty Ltd).

Independent analysis of historical trends and future projects of factors affecting food security. Reports distributed to all APEC contacts involved in Food Security Task Force, FAO, industry associations and, on request, other organisations and individualsâare public documents.
Food Security and Trade: a Future Perspective

Independent analysis of historical trends and future projections of factors affecting food security. Reports distributed to all APEC contacts involved in Food Security Task Force, FAO, industry associations and, on request, other organisationsâare public documents.
East Asia Analytical Unit (EAAU)- a wide range of research has been undertaken for utilisation in EAAU publications.

EAAU reports: The New ASEANS: Vietnam, Burma, Cambodia and Laos, June 1997; A New Japan?âChanges in Asia's Megamarket, June 1997; China Embraces the Market: Achievements, Constraints and Opportunities, April 1997; Asia's Global Powers: China-Japan Relations in the 21st Century, April 1996; Pacific Russia: Risks and Rewards, April 1996. All reports are publicly available and were tabled in parliament at the time of release. Working papers released in August 1997: China's Transitional EconomyâBetween Plan and Market; China's Infrastructure: Sectoral Plans and Reforms, and Financing Policies; China's State Enterprise ReformsâNine Case Studies.
China: regional and global trade model
China: regional and global trade modelâadditional simulations
Community Health Insurance Schemes in Thailand, Vietnam and Fiji
Unpublished research report can be made available on request, in full or in part.
Urbanisation in Asia: Lessons Learned and Innovative Responses
Research report is being published and will be made available free of charge to interested parties.
Advances in Information TechnologyâIssues for Development in Asia/Pacific
