Parts of the research findings have been published in various academic publications.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 913)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

question.para: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION

entry.para: Analysis of the Canberra Office Market.
To assist in the preparation of a report to the Commonwealth Property Committee.
Qualitative research as part of a review of Commonwealth fire safety policy.
Research into fire safety policies and practices. Results made available to relevant Commonwealth agencies.
(1) Effectiveness of a trial outposting of staff in the Albury/Wagga area.
(2) Effectiveness of arrangements to move the households of Government employees overseas.
External qualitative and quantitative research of service delivery.

(3) On-going effectiveness of service delivery for some 27,000 household relocations within Australia (November 1996 to October 1997). (The amount in column 4 represents the total amount, which comprised $7,000 set-up costs, $11,274 per month and $6,000 for additional analysis in each 6 monthly report.) All results made available to removals industry representatives.
Electronic Commerce Capability of Suppliers to Australian Government agencies.
Questionnaires consisting of 66 simple multiple choice questions and 12 short answer questions were distributed. The report was available on the former Purchasing Australia's World Wide Web site.
Roger Clarke and Kevin Jeffrey, Electronic Trading Concepts Pty Ltd
Implementation and effectiveness of the 1994 Purchasing Reforms

Surveys of Commonwealth agencies commenced in 1995 and continued throughout 1996. 7 agencies were resurveyed in August 1996 to determine any change in implementation progress compared to survey of 15 agencies in Oct 95. The results were compiled in a report to Government.
Customer survey into the requirements of the IT buyers guide
Sample size was 200 government buyers. Survey undertaken by telephone and consisted of approximately 20 questions. Research outcomes were distributed internally only.
Research into the outcomes of Meet the Buyers 1996

Survey of business attendees of Meet the Buyers Adelaide 1996. Sample size was 60 businesses. Survey was by telephone and consisted of approximately 50 questions. Research outcomes were distributed internally only.
The needs of small and medium enterprise under electronic commerce

Research into the needs of small and medium enterprises in doing business with government. 2197 surveys were posted and 493 companies responded. Survey consisted of 17 questions. Research outcomes were distributed internally only.
Business Opportunities from the 1997 Federal Budget
Analysis of portfolio program funding of departments and agencies for business opportunities. Research is being distributed to businesses attending functions within the Supplier Information Program.
Review of charging practices used by the former Purchasing Australia in its revenue raising activities.
Evaluation of the charging regime provided to the former Purchasing Australia.
Publications Audit of the former Purchasing Australia.
Evaluation of the effectiveness of the former Purchasing Australia's publication program in terms of target audience, distribution channels and resources for internal use.

To identify ways of simplifying procurement process for government buyers and for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) as prospective suppliers. 18 interviews conducted covering 31 staff in Commonwealth agencies. Results were made available to the National Procurement Board (NPB).
Joint NPB/Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry (QCCI) Supply Study

Study of the experiences and perceptions of Queensland suppliers in dealing with the three tiers of government. A 31 question questionnaire was distributed to 6,200 Queensland firms, and 934 responses were received. Analysis of the results is awaiting publication.
(d) OFFICE OF GOVERNMENT INFORMATION AND ADVERTISING (OGIA)
A quantitative mid-term assessment of client satisfaction in relation to aspects of the service provided by TMP Worldwide Advertising for non campaign advertising.

409 of TMP's Commonwealth Government clients were interviewed by telephone. The sample was representative across States, Portfolios and client size (based on frequency of use). Research was commissioned for contract administration purposes only. Outside OGIA, results of the research was made available to TMP.
An evaluation of the service provided by AIS Media (master agency for the placement of campaign advertising) to the Federal government.

Group discussions with OGIA and AIS Media. Face to face interviews with Commonwealth agencies and the Industry. Semi-structured telephone interviews were held with personnel from government and creative agencies. Research was commissioned for contract administration purposes only. Outside OGIA, results of the research were made available to AIS Media.

answer.para: PORTFOLIO AGENCIES

entry.para: 1,200 people were asked 24 questions in telephone interviews about their experience of voting. Research has been made available externally upon request.
89 journalists interviewed by telephone about the quality of service received. Research has been made available externally upon request.
14,454 people was asked two questions about citizenship and enrolment. Research has been made available externally upon request.
1,200 people were asked how recently they had visited an AEC office. The research has been made available externally upon request.
Constitutional Convention Election: Advertising Concept Testing

5 focus group interviews were conducted to ascertain the effectiveness of the explanation phase of advertising for the Constitutional Convention election. The research has been made available externally upon request.
Constitutional Convention Election: Benchmark Survey and Tracking Research
1,200 people interviewed to determine levels of understanding of the Constitutional Convention Election and the information campaign. The research can be made available externally upon request.
AEC Information Technology Client Services Unit: Client Survey
Clients were surveyed to determine the perceived quality of service provided by the Unit. The research results will be presented to the Australian Joint Roll Council and the AEC's Management Board.
Provision of advice on the valuation of land in each state.
Expert valuation advice and data prepared on the value of land in each state. Results of the research were made available to State Valuers' General.
Provision of advice on Statistical Procedures.

Advice on the application of statistical procedures to police services data. Results were included in the Commission's Reports on Research in Progress 1996 and are now being debated by the States and Territories.

Supply of statistical and geographic factors impacting on States and Territories road maintenance. Results were included in the Commission's Reports on Research in Progress 1996 and distributed to States.
National Resource Information Centre (NRIC), Department of Primary Industry and Energy.
Commonwealth's sale of its remaining interest in the Commonwealth Bank

March 1996âqualitative research as part of the advertising selection process. April 1996âqualitative research and in-depth interviews were conducted of investment advisers' needs and attitudes in CBA. Results passed to the Commonwealth's communications consultant, financial adviser, Global Co-ordinator, Joint Lead Managers and OGIA.
Commonwealth's sale of its remaining interest in the Commonwealth Bank

March 1996âquantitative research to evaluate specific groups of potential investors. The sample size was 2,000 CBA shareholders, other shareholders and non-shareholders. The objective was to establish awareness of the offer and likely demand from each group.
Commonwealth's sale of its remaining interest in the Commonwealth Bank
Continuous tracking research to track the effects of the retail communications campaign. The research was conducted over 4 weeks during the advertising campaign.
Commonwealth's sale of its remaining interest in the Commonwealth Bank

July and August 1996âpost sale research to evaluate the reasons for investment/non-investment, factors influencing the decision, impact of the complexity of the offer, effectiveness of communications and public offer document.
Commonwealth's sale of up to one third of its equity in Telstra

May 1997âqualitative and quantitative research to feed into the development of a communications plan. The research objective was to understand attitudes to Telstra as an investment, components of a share offer that are most appealing, estimated number of prospectuses required, estimated number of investors and likely retail demand. The methodology for the qualitative research was group discussions (2 with current shareholders and 2 with non-shareholders).
Quantitative: DBM Consultants Pty Ltd Qualitative: Open Mind Research Group (subcontracted by DBM Consultants)
Commonwealth's sale of up to one third of its equity in Telstra
June 1997âresearch to test creative concepts developed by advertising agencies to allow the target market for shares to identify which concepts provide the most positive response to the offer.
Open Mind Research Group (subcontracted by DBM Consultants)
Commonwealth's sale of up to one third of its equity in Telstra

August 1997âquantitative research was conducted to provide benchmark information on awareness of the float, attitudes to the offer, awareness of advertising. From August to November 1997 continuous tracking research was conducted on changes in the retail market against the benchmark to assess the impact of advertising and to further refine key demand estimates. The results were presented over 9 waves from August to November 1997. The sample size was 460 per wave. As part of the tracking research, additional quantitative research was conducted in September and October 1997 on pre registration (two waves of 300 each), high value investors (one wave of 600) and applicants' awareness of various features of the Telstra Share Offer (one wave of 300).
Commonwealth Department of Administrative Services (DAS): Business Units

May 1997âqualitative and quantitative research as part of the sale process for DAS business units. The purpose of the research was to generate information on the level of interest within each business unit in working for a new owner. A report on the results was prepared for each business and these were made available to prospective purchasers. Reports were provided to the Office of Asset Sales, its business and legal advisers, and senior management in the former DAS. A summary of the results was provided to the staff in each business.
Survey of client satisfaction with ComSuper's services over a 12 month period

This survey is current. Single quantitative and qualitative survey consisting of a set of questionnaires to be issued to ComSuper's three principal client groups, contributors, preserved benefit members and pensioners, and a single questionnaire to employers, in the course of the 1997-98 financial year. Survey results will, in the first instance, be used by ComSuper management as a means of further improving service delivery. Results will be made available to the CSS, PSS and MSBS Boards of Trustees.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and regional Development: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 915)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

question.para: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: The following table lists qualitative and quantitative research conducted by consultants for the Department, including sub-programs which are sometimes seen as departmental agencies, such as the Federal Office of Road Safety and the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (where relevant to transport and regional development portfolio responsibilities).
ATTACHMENT A

para.inline: RESEARCH UNDERTAKEN BY THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT SINCE 3 MARCH 1996

entry.para: Research Project and Availability of Results

To assess the network of major roads comprising the National Highway System plus a number of other major roads on which data have been supplied by State road authorities and convert data on the condition of major non-urban roads to a new database. The data base was required for the Bureau of Transport and Communication Economics (BTCE) assessment of the adequacy of non-urban road infrastructure for submission to the House of Representatives Inquiry into Federal Road Funding (Neville Report).

To conduct an assessment of the life-expectancy and potential cost of replacement of bridges on some major non-urban roads under various scenarios for traffic growth and increased vehicle masses. The assessment was required for submission to the House of Representatives Inquiry into Federal Road Funding (Neville Report).

To develop an algorithm to predict the effect of passing lanes on vehicle speeds for different passing lane frequencies, traffic volumes, vehicle mixes and terrains, to use in a BTCE computer model which predicts future road investment needs. The assessment was required for the BTCE submission to the House of Representatives Inquiry into Federal Road Funding (Neville Report).
Establishment of the Australian Pavement Studies and Research Centre (APSARC). Generally available.
PPK Environment and Infrastructure Pty Ltd

Preparation of the draft Environmental Impact Statement on the development of a second major airport for Sydney. Draft EIS addresses a range of planning, physical environmental and biological, and social and economic impacts of developing a second major airport for Sydney. The draft EIS will be released to the public, as will relevant technical papers.

Logistics Mapping Case Study. This study maps out the transport and logistics chain for exporting fruit to Indonesia. The study will assist Australian exporters in developing an efficient and cost effective transport and logistics chain for exporting their goods. This study is still in progress.

Empty Shipping Container Repositioning Study. This study looks at the extent and cost of empty shipping container repositioning between Australia and our three major Asian trade routes and possible solutions to address the imbalance. A formal evaluation has not been undertaken at this stage. The report has been distributed to the Supermarket to Asia Council's Transport and Logistics Working Group and to the participating port authorities. The report is available to the public on request.

Research was conducted into how best to sell off the assets of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation (AWDC). The research commenced in December 1995 and the report was handed to the Department on 16 June 1996. Project was undertaken through: community consultations; release of an issues paper; public workshops and discussions; interviews with key business people and community representatives; and inviting written submissions from the public. The Study was presented to the 45th Albury-Wodonga Ministerial Council Meeting in February 1997. After Ministerial Council meeting, results of study released to the public.
To research and advise on regional freight flows and to verify priority corridors for freight in regional areas. Generally available.
Developing a national research strategy for local governmentâpreparation of issues paper for the National Office of Local Government (NOLG) as well as academic and local government organisations.

Review of recent Australian research into Local Governmentâpreparation of a background paper for the Local Government Research Workshop for NOLG as well as academic and local government organisations.

Comparison of Grants Commission methodologiesâpreparation of papers for discussionâkey information published in the second Local Government National Report to be tabled in Parliament and to be distributed to all local government bodies in Australia.
To perform a collection and analysis of yabbie, sediment and water samples from inflow streams in the Jervis Bay Territory. Results made available to Jervis Bay Territory Environment Committee.

To undertake a human health risk assessment of possible contamination of Mary Creek in the Jervis Bay Territory. To determine possible risks due to the known chemicals of potential concern, and to determine whether any immediate actions are necessary in order to eliminate or control those sources of contamination contributing to health risk and determine whether there are any grounds for further risk assessment. Results were made available to the Jervis Bay Territory Environment Committee.

Independent assessment and advice on whether an applicant is reasonably capable in terms of the viability of its business plan of implementing international air services on the proposed routes from Australia for the purposes of Para. 4.1(ii) of the Minister's Policy Statement. Information only made available to Commissioners of the International Air Services Commission.

answer.para: The Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) research reports are distributed through a wide mailing list to State and Territory Road Authorities, relevant industry groups, researchers, international road safety and transport organisations and are made available to the general public on request. Research reports are available free of charge and abstracts and publication details are published on the internet.
The following list includes research commissioned before 3 March 1996, but still in progress at that date. "Total cost" includes cost of work on these projects prior to 3 March 1996.

entry.para: Research Project and Availability of Results

Conduct a program of research to identify the most effective and efficient methods for implementing random breath testing in a range of settings and conditions which will enable the impact of random breath testing to be optimised.

Develop a code of practice for the use of digital imaging technology in the policing of traffic offences. The project involved a review, in conjunction with senior traffic police, of the technological, legal and operational issues involved with the implementation of digital imaging technology in enforcement.

Undertake a study and benefits analysis of a hybrid dynamic side impact standard, based on the current US and European regulations to determine the potential reduction in Harm for Australia. Study will also consist of an injury reduction assessment, followed by benefit computations.

Undertake a case-control study comparing a group of crash-involved motorcycle riders with a group of riders not involved in crashes. The aim of the study was to identify and assess the contribution of modifiable risk factors associated with serious injury and fatal motorcycle crashes. The research involved crash site and vehicle inspections, rider interviews and roadside observation surveys to gather detailed information on 222 crashes and 1195 controls.
National Health and Medical Research CouncilâRoad Accident Research Unit

Undertake a research project to quantify the relationship between the travelling speed of a car and the risk of involvement in a serious crash in urban areas. The results of this project will provide essential input into the development of speed management programs in Australian jurisdictions. The central component of the research involves the detailed investigation and reconstruction of 154 crashed vehicles; control information was collected for 604 vehicles.
National Health and Medical Research CouncilâRoad Accident Research Unit

Assess the potential for reducing head injuries among car occupants through the application of improved interior padding measures. The study incorporated a literature review, an analysis of occupant head injury data (including a harm mitigation analysis) and an assessment of relevant energy absorption treatments.
Conduct a longer term evaluation of the Queensland "Under the Limit" drink driving rehabilitation program.
Road Accident Prevention Research Unit, University of Western Australia
Undertake research to investigate the characteristics of recidivist drink drivers in an Australian jurisdiction, as part of the preparation for a seminar on Recidivist and Hard Core Drink Drivers.

The collection and coding of fatal crash data for 1994 from coroners' reports. These reports are a primary source of information on fatal road crashes which directs research and public education initiatives. Sample size: 1822 fatal crashes and 2017 fatalities.
Conduct truck rear under-run project to develop an energy absorbing underrun barrier.

Conduct a crash test research program involving frontal, side impact and off-set frontal tests. This is a period contract which provides set rates for each crash test type. The Federal Office of Road Safety research program provides for the following projects under this contract:
Total Project cost *includes cost of cars, printing, transport etc.
Crash analysis costs paid to Autoliv since 3 March 1996

. Conduct a series of crashes involving vehicles with and without airbags using the same crash test methodology. The purpose of this stand-alone consumer information program was to compare the injury outcome of vehicles tested and provide consumer education on the benefits of airbags.
. Conduct a series of crashes to validate proposed off-set frontal crash regulations.
. Conduct a series of crashes to develop regulations for dynamic side-impact crashes.

. Conduct a truck rear under-run crash test using a prototype under-run barrier developed by Monash University Accident Research Centre. This will assist in developing an energy absorbing underrun barrier designed to reduce the severity of truck rear under-run crashes.

. Conduct a series of 6 airbag deployments using out-of-position child and small adult instrumented crash test dummies, and one unrestrained full frontal barrier test. (Commissioned on behalf of US NHTSA).

Determine the cost effectiveness of Australian periodic motor vehicle inspection practices in Australia. Arrangements vary widely from compulsory government administered schemes (ACT), and privately administered schemes (NSW) to no inspection requirements (SA).
Prepare a summary report that consolidates the findings of prior research into strategies to combat fatigue in the long distance road transport industry.
National Health and Medical Research CouncilâRoad Accident Research Unit

Conduct a review of the evolution of the understanding of the nature and severity of injuries to a pedestrian when struck by a vehicle. Carry out a review of the research activities which have led to the development of vehicle test procedures to optimise the protection afforded to a pedestrian in the event of a collision.
Sled tests of child crash test dummies in adult seat belts and child harnesses to compare the outcome.
Develop a method for measuring spray from heavy vehicles and investigate aerodynamic methods for spray reduction.
Conduct a study examining the feasibility of establishing a National Highway Geographical Information System (GIS).

Evaluate pilot Drink Drive campaign. This was a quantitative phone survey, the results of which are available to the Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) and all jurisdictions. The questionnaire comprised 17 initial questions and 34 follow up questions. 20 individual interviews were conducted with 250 pre-phone interviews and 350 post interviews with 17 pre-interview questions and 34 post questions.
Test advertising concept Speed campaign. This was a qualitative survey involving focus groups, the results of which are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.

Evaluate Motorcycle campaign. This was a qualitative evaluation involving focus groups and interviews, the results of which are available to FORS and all jurisdictions. The questionnaire comprised 31 initial questions and 30 follow up questions. 1200 individual pre-interviews were conducted with 1200 individual post-interviews.
Test Motorcycle concepts. This is a qualitative evaluation involving focus groups and interviews, the results of which are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.

Market research Rural Safety campaign. This was a qualitative survey involving 20 focus groups and 27 individual interviews, with each interview having 9 questions. Results are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.

Market research results from the National Safe Travel to School Awards campaign. This was a quantitative phone survey, involving 66 primary schools with 32 questions being asked of each school. The results of the survey are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.

answer.para: Two organisations were engaged by FORS to conduct the preliminary testing and analysis phase of the Diesel Vehicle In-service Emissions Study. The data from this phase is being used internally to develop the final stage of the project. The final report of the study will be released to the public.

entry.para: Provide specialist equipment and personnel to collect and analyse gaseous and smoke emissions from the 17 vehicles tested in the program.
Provide specialist equipment and personnel to collect and analyse particulate emissions from the 17 vehicles tested in the program.

answer.para: Research commissioned since 3 March 1996:

entry.para: Research Project and Availability of Results
Prepare proposed methodology for safety risk assessment of horizontal curves for unsealed roads.

Provide a final report for a study to assess priorities for rural road shoulder treatments. The consultants were required to undertake technical research to obtain details of treated sites, consult with the relevant authorities on current methods of treatment and analyse crash statistics before and after treatment. The study included a review of information available within Australia and overseas regarding the use and effectiveness of road shoulder treatments in reducing crashes, methods used to assess site priorities for treatment and current procedures for road shoulder treatments. The review identified the benefits and costs involved in sealing shoulders on rural roads.

Administer a fleet safety award, which involved disseminating information to fleet managers, inviting nominations, evaluating the merits of nominated fleet safety programs, designing an appropriate trophy, staging the presentation event and producing a report on the outcome.

Undertake a project to develop a table to identify possible road treatments as countermeasures for particular crash types. It is expected that the project will contribute to greater efficiency and effectiveness in black spot treatment.
Ad hoc analysis of road safety data. Provide in-depth statistical analysis of road crash data in response to requests from the Parliament, State Authorities, industry and the public.

Validate the use of the Victorian Transport Accident Commission's driving simulator as a means of testing and developing a range of visual road treatments designed to reduce vehicle speeds. Several treatments were used in both on-road and simulator trials; correlation analyses were carried out on the pattern of responses of the simulator method. This project follows recommendations from an earlier study on the development of perceptual road treatments.

Undertake a pilot study of crashed vehicles with airbags and similar vehicles without airbags to examine airbag effectiveness and identify any problems associated with their introduction in conjunction with Australian Design Rule 69. The pilot involved the identification and inspection of 60 crashed vehicles.

Provide a literature review and discussion paper on national and international Research relating to female drivers. The literature review is part of a larger project involving statistical analysis of existing road crash databases and the conduct of an independent research study of female drivers. The project will provide a better understanding of the factors related to female driver involvement in serious crashes and contribute to policy formulation on this issue.

Collection and coding of fatal crash data for 1996/97 from coroners' reports. These reports are a primary source of information on fatal road crashes, which directs research and public education initiatives. Sample size is around 2,000.
Institute for Gender and Health, University of Newcastle

Investigation of factors associated with female drivers' involvement in serious crashes. (Female drivers are known to have relatively high risk of involvement in crashes resulting in serious injury, but not fatality.) 5,000 women were surveyed to identify socio-economic, mental health and physical health factors related to risk. Results will contribute towards Departmental policy on female drivers. The questionnaire comprised 30 questions.

Undertake laboratory and on-road studies involving long distance truck drivers to develop performance indicators for fatigue management in road transport, and evaluation tools for road transport operators to determine effectiveness of fatigue management strategies. The study is part of the pilot project for Fatigue Management Programs being run in Queensland and involving State and Commonwealth governments, the Road Transport Forum and road transport operators.

Undertake a series of national surveys of community attitudes to road safety issues. Information from these surveys contributes to the formation and review of road safety policy and public education programs. The current survey involves telephone interviews with a nationally representative sample of some 1250 Australian residents. On average, each interview lasted about 13 minutes.
Adelaide University Road Accident Research Unit (Luminis Pty Ltd)
Conduct headform impact tests to EEVC standard on top 10 selling vehicles in Australia as part of pedestrian safety research program.

Investigate and analyse the pattern of travel speeds and trip times for vehicles engaged in a range of typical urban journeys and develop a method for estimating the potential effects of speed limits and speed enforcement on travel times, travel speeds, traffic flows, congestion and travel demand characteristics in urban environments.
Road Transport Forum TruckSafe research funding

The Department provided $50,000 in June 1996 to the Road Transport Forum for the development of an alternative compliance industry accreditation program. This funding was provided specifically for the purpose of developing an audit framework for this scheme and aligning the industry program with the National Heavy Vehicle Accreditation Scheme with is being developed by governments in parallel with the development of national road transport law. It is vital for the success of these schemes that they have consistent standards in order to maximise the participation rate by operators. These funds came from the research allocation under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988. The Road Transport Forum is an approved research organisation for the purpose of this Act.
Develop general audit principles and practices module under the national alternative compliance scheme.
Establish an Intelligent Transport System (ITS) interaction website on the Internet designed to stimulate industry and promote service with potential users.

Evaluate the Speed campaign. This was a quantitative phone survey, the results of which are available to FORS and all jurisdictions. Questionnaire comprised 14 initial questions and 16 follow-up questions. Comprising 812 pre-phone interviews and 814 post-phone interviews.

Evaluate Young Driver campaign. This was a quantitative and qualitative survey involving 7 focus groups, the questionnaire contained 102 questions and there were 304 pre-benchmark phone interviews conducted followed by 350 post-phone interviews. The results of which are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.
Test creative concept Rural Speed campaign. This was a qualitative survey involving 9 focus groups, with reactions to 10 concepts. The results are available to FORS and all jurisdictions.

Evaluate FORS Rural Speed campaign. This was a quantitative phone survey, with a questionnaire containing 32 questions. 500 pre-phone interviews were conducted followed by 500 post-phone interviews. The results are available to the Federal Office of Road Safety and all jurisdictions.

Survey of all staff, May 1997 (2 pages with additional 3 pages for managers) as part of a diagnostic report to assist the Department to achieve accreditation as an Investor in People. Results to all staff included in a Minute from the Department's Deputy Secretary.

Survey of Staff Attitudes in Department, October 1996. 602 respondents (80% return rate). Questionnaire of 15 pages, including benchmarking questions. Results available to all staff in the form of the complete report in Departmental library, presentations to each Sub-program by Secretary and summary on Departmental electronic Bulletin Board.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Awarding of Consultancies of Contracts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 930)

talk.start.para: asked the Ministers listed below, upon notice, on 22 October 1997:

question.para: Minister representing the Prime Minister; Minister representing the Minister for Trade; Minister representing the Treasurer; Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; Minister for the Environment; Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts; Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business; Minister for Social Security; Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs; Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism; Minister representing the Minister for Defence; Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services; Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration; Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister representing the Attorney-General; Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development; Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs; Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

Has the Minister or the Minister's office ever overturned a departmental recommendation in relation to the awarding of a consultancy or other contract; if so: (a) when was the action taken; (b) what was the nature of the consultancy or contract involved (these may be specified in general terms if there are problems of commercial confidentiality); (c) what amounts of money were involved; and (d) what was the reason for taking such action.

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer, on behalf of those ministers, to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The awarding of consultancy and other contracts is a regular feature of the work of most departments, and the task of examining advice on each contract since March 1996 would involve a workload I am not prepared to authorise. To the extent that Ministers receive advice and make decisions on whether or not to accept it, I regard that deliberative process, in the normal course of events, to be confidential to government.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society: Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 963)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) What funding was provided, and, if any, what was the amount provided to the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) in the 1996-97 financial year by the department.
(2) What funding was provided, and, if any, what was the amount provided to the Wilderness Society in the 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years by the department.

talk.start.para: âAs indicated above, the honourable senator has asked identical questions of both ministers. The following answer has been provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on behalf of both ministers:

answer.para: (1) Neither the Department of Foreign Affairs nor Austrade provided any funding to the Australian Conservation Foundation in the 1996-97 financial year. AusAID provided $37,860 in 1996-97.
(2) No funding was provided to the Wilderness Society by the Department of Foreign Affairs, Austrade or AusAID in the 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: With reference to the answers to questions on notice nos 495 (Official Senate Hansard , 7 May 1997, p.2999), 698 (Official Senate Hansard , 27 August 1997, p.5885) and 859 (Official Senate Hansard , 22 October 1997, p.7794) regarding Telstra's offer to fund parliamentarians to the Atlanta Olympics.
(1) Can a copy of the Telstra Employee Code of Conduct which sets out guidelines for the expected behaviour of employees in their dealings with customers and suppliers be provided

(2) Without disclosing business or individual names, what is the value of equipment and services purchased over the past 2 years from Telstra by each of the companies represented by the 10 business guests of Telstra to the Atlanta Games
(3) Were all States and Territories canvassed seeking expressions of interest to attend the Atlanta Games

(4) Did the Northern Territory Government indicate to Telstra at any stage that it proposed to make a bid for the 2006 Commonwealth Games; if so, was such a proposal discussed in the Northern Territory Parliament or in any other way made public.
(5) Why were the cost of trips taken by the Victorian Minister for Education (Mr Gude) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory (Mr Stone) not met by their respective governments.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A copy of the Telstra Employee Code of Conduct is attached.*

(2) Telstra has informed me that it is not in a position to calculate the sum the Senator is seeking. Telstra has advise that this is because each of the customers has varying expenditure levels of Telstra services and each is a heavy user of telecommunications services. Telstra considers "value" lies in the customer relationship, providing Telstra with an opportunity to work with the customer to better understand their business and their business needs.

(3) Telstra has advised that it examined its customer list and made choices about which customers it would invite as its guests at the Atlanta Olympics. In assessing which customers were to be approached to attend Atlanta as Telstra guests, many factors were taken into consideration. Telstra has advised each State and Territory government was assumed to be a potential bidder for future Commonwealth Games, including the 2006 Games. Telstra has further advised that the overarching basis for approaching government was the status of the business relationship between the customer and Telstra. Because of this criterion Telstra has indicated that not all state governments were approached.

(4) As Telstra has previously indicated in response to question on notice 495, the offer was taken up by the Northern Territory government as an opportunity to gain first hand knowledge of the Olympic Games to enhance possible future bids for the Commonwealth Games. Telstra has further advised that it is not aware of any proposals discussed by the Northern Territory Parliament.
(5) Telstra has advised each customer was accommodated as a business guest of Telstra, including the government customers.
* Copies of the Telstra Employee Code of Conduct is available from the Senate Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Following the cut backs made to funding for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs' On Arrival Accommodation program and the narrowing of the scope of eligibility, what sort of provisions for housing are currently available for newly arrived migrants.
(2) How much funding is allocated and to which programs.

(3) Given that many migrants acquire information about the public housing application procedure through word of mouth or informal networks, how does the department propose to address the problems encountered by these migrants in gaining access to clear and accurate information pertaining to eligibility criteria and housing services provided, particularly in the light of the fact that many are illiterate or unable to comprehend written English.

(4) Given that there is presently great disparity between the States concerning the extent to which preference is given to refugees allowing them greater access to public housing: what measures, if any, have been taken by the Federal Government to ensure uniformity between the States' categories for special consideration with regards to humanitarian entrants.
(5) Does the Government propose to amend the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in the future to allow refugee status to be a primary factor in the allocation of public housing.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs informs me that there has been no cut back to OAA funding this financial year for Humanitarian Program entrants. The eligibility criteria for Humanitarian Program entrants also have not been changed recently. In the past migrants who were in need of emergency accommodation because their on-arrival arrangements had broken down were eligible to be accommodated in migrant hostels for up to four weeks. This practice was scaled down following the disposal of migrant hostels by the former Government.

(2) The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has advised me that expected expenditure on OAA in 1997/98 will be around $3.6m which was the level of expenditure in 1996/97. These funds form part of the Humanitarian Settlement Sub Program which has an annual appropriation of $11.224m for 1997/98. An additional $5.08m was allocated to this item this financial year to fund the introduction of the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy.

(3) The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs informs me that his Department distributes a settlement information kit to newly arrived migrants which contains contact and referral information about public housing services in the relevant State/Territory. The kit is translated into a number of different languages. Assistance is also available from the Translating and Interpreting Service to assist non English speaking newly arrived migrants and Humanitarian Program entrants to access settlement services. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs also provides up to 510 hours of English tuition to these NESB entrants through its Adult Migrant English Program.

(4) Allocation to public housing is the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. Refugees are able to access the full range of public housing options available to low income applicants. Priority public housing allocation is made available to people who meet priority criteria such as demonstrating an urgent housing need or having no other housing options.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that (a) for the 1996-97 financial year, $728 million was allocated for expenditure on housing in Victoria but that only $361.3 million was actually used for this purpose; and (b) the reason quoted by the Victorian State Government for this `under use' of funds was the uncertainty created by the Commonwealth Government over the future of funding provision under the present Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA).

(2) Are there any mechanisms in place under the CSHA to ensure that funds allocated for housing are actually used for that purpose, and within a set time frame; if so, what are these specifications; if not, what is the justification for the absence of any such mechanisms.

(3) Given that the Victorian Government's under use of housing funds has come at a time when waiting lists in the State are long, rental markets are tight and characterised by very low vacancy rate, homelessness is on the increase and public housing is being sold off: Does the department perceive the need for the Federal Government to place binding conditions upon these grants on order to compel the State Governments to uphold their side of the bargain by actively spending the allocated funds to improve State housing programs.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The figures quoted in the question ($728 million allocated to expenditure on housing and $363.1 million actually used for this purpose) do not relate specifically to housing. I am advised the figures represent the budgeted and actual expenditure on Housing and Community Amenities, a Government Purpose Classification (GPC) which includes expenditure by some 20 agencies, including the Office of Housing, Melbourne Water and non metropolitan water and sewerage authorities.

The Commonwealth CSHA grant for 1996-97 was approximately $243 million. Victoria's State matching requirement was approximately $105 million. CSHA funds carried over by Victoria from 1996/97 to 1997/98 were $118.8 million.

(b) The Victorian Minister for Housing sought the agreement of the Commonwealth to carry over unexpended capital funds for 1996/97 to 1997/98. In September 1996, I advised the Victorian Minister that unexpended funds could be carried over.

Funding certainty for the final two years of the current CSHA was provided by the Prime Minister in May 1997 when he made a commitment to States and Territories that funding would be guaranteed through to 30 June 1999.

(2) Yes. The 1996 CSHA provides that available funds, for the period of an approved Strategic Plan, can only be used for specified housing assistance purposes. The 1996 CSHA further stipulates that where funds have not been used for allowable uses a Strategic Plan can be suspended and consequently further Commonwealth funding is withheld.
(3) See the answer to Part (2).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1997:

question.para: (1) How will the Youth Allowance impact on postgraduate students, will they be able to access Youth Allowance.
(2) Will postgraduate studies be recognised as a `legitimate activity' for the purpose of Youth Allowance assessment.
(3) What will be the access afforded postgraduate students to health care cards.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Austudy guidelines applying to post-graduate students will broadly be incorporated into Youth Allowance.
A student will be able to get Youth Allowance for one graduate or post-graduate course.
(2) Post-graduate study will be recognised as a `legitimate activity' for the purpose of Youth Allowance assessment.
(3) As now, post-graduate students will be eligible for a health care card if their income is below the appropriate limit.

subdebateinfo.title: Second World War: Australian Servicemen Killed and Buried in Indonesia
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1007)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1997:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question no. 293 (Senate Hansard, 4 December 1996, p.6725):

(1) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `The Department organised, in conjunction with the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Royal Navy, the identification and burial of two members of Operation Rimau at Kanji War Cemetery Singapore on 27th of August 1994': (a) can details be provided of what action the department took in conjunction with the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Royal Australian Navy in identifying the remains of the two members; (b) can it be confirmed that an identification of Sargeant Cameron's remains was conducted by a doctor at the Sydney Coroner's office in conjunction with a colleague at the Adelaide Coroner's office; (c) can it be confirmed that a letter dated 18 January 1993 from Director of Personnel Services, Department of Defence, to Major Tom Hall RFD ED advised that the Australian Defence Force head quarters is responsible for the identification of the remains of service personnel and the removal of those remains to an appropriate place of burial; (d) can it be confirmed that in a letter dated 12 March 1993 from the Director of Personnel Services, Department of Defence, the Surgeon General ADF had been requested to obtain Sargeant Cameron's medical file and to arrange for military forensic experts to be available to examine the remains held by the New South Wales Coroner's office; (e) did this examination take place; if so, what was the date of this examination; (f) can it be confirmed that Sub Lt JGM Riggs RNVR's remains were exhumed by the Indonesian Navy, and that his remains where entrusted to the British High Commissioner in Jakarta up until the time of his burial in the Kanji War Memorial Cemetery in August 1994; and (g) did a forensic examination of these remains take place; if so, who conducted the examination and when.

(2) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `The Department has also provided legal advice regarding current legislation and Military Law relating to alleged War crimes': (a) can it be confirmed that this advice was provided in response to a letter from Major Hall, dated 11 February 1993, asking the Minister to investigate the actions of a particular Captain during the period of 1943 to 1945; (b) can it be confirmed that despite Major Hall's request for the advice from the department referred to by the Minister, it was only provided to Major Hall after he had requested it through the freedom of information section of the department; (c) is the Minister satisfied that the information received by Major Hall from the department was a satisfactory response to his specific request; and (d) is the Minister satisfied that the advice given to Major Hall that the statute of limitations now applied and there was nothing that could be done.

(3) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `The statement that Major Hall has provided documentary evidence to the Department of Defence since 1992 is not strictly correct. Correspondence from Major Hall to the Department of Defence commenced on this matter in mid February 1993': (a) can it be confirmed that a letter and map from Major Hall, outlining documentary information of the location of War graves, dated 30 January 1992 and addressed to the Records Officer of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission' was copied to both the Ministers for Defence and Veterans' Affairs; and (b) can it be confirmed that this correspondence is in the possession of the department as acknowledged by a letter to Major Hall from Chief of General Staff dated 6 March 1996.

(4) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `Major Hall provided a summary of his research to Army Headquarters in late January 1996 after a request from the office of the Minister for Defence to provide any further information he may have in this matter': (a) can it be confirmed that this request was made to Major Hall after he had informed the department that he believed the Army Attache (8-15 October 1995) had visited a site which was 2 000 metres north of the grave site and on the wrong side of the river; (b) can it be confirmed that the Army Attache was not provided with the Dili Map 1937 which Major Hall had provided in documentation to the department; if so, could an explanation be given as to why the Army Attache was not provided with this map.

(5) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `As a result of the information provided by Major Hall, the Army Attache in Jakarta undertook a visit to Dili, Timor in the period 8-15 October 1995, to search for the grave sites of Warrant Officer Second Class Jeffery Willersdorf and Lance Corporal Hugo Pace, as well as another Australian, Lieutenant Eric Liversidge': (a) can it be confirmed that the only information provided to the Army Attache in Jakarta was a copy of a letter sent by Major Hall addressed to the Commonwealth War Graves on 30 January 1992 (which did not include a copy of the Dili Map 1937) and a newspaper report and request from the President of the Returned and Services League of Australia in Victoria; and (b) why was none of the other information given to the department provided to the Army Attache.
(6) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `The invitation was extended in a letter to Major Hall dated 15 May 1996.

Major Hall has not replied to this invitation': (a) can it be confirmed that on 23 May 1996 Major Hall did reply to the letter dated 15 May 1996 stating the assurances he required before he could attend any meeting in Canberra and outlining the results of previous meetings he had attended in 1988 and 1995 with the Departments of Defence and Veterans' Affairs on the subject of Australian unmarked war graves.

(7) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `Departmental policy requires that "investigating authorities must assess the feasibility of successfully recovering any remains given the information provided, the size of the area to be searched, sensitivity to local issues. . . and the reliability of the informant"': (a) could details be provided of what size an area the department considers acceptable to search, and whether or not the area of the Dili Map 1937 provided by Major Hall with the grave sites marked is acceptable to the department; (b) could details be provided of what sensitive local issues exist in this particular case; (c) does the department consider the evidence provided by Major Hall to be reliable; and (d) is the Minister aware that most of the evidence provided to the department by Major Hall was collected by the Australian military forces between 1945 to 1951 and has been held by Australian Archives since 1981.

(8) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `In regard to marking the graves of Australian and Americans killed at Surabaya Java, Major Hall advised the Department that the area where he suspects the remains are located is in a restricted Indonesian Naval Base. To date, action has not started to progress this search of the naval base due to the sensitivity of the site and a lack of hard evidence to support an approach to the Indonesian Authorities': (a) is the Minister aware that on 26 February 1996 a representative from the Army History Directorate inspected part of the documents held by Major Hall, which provided evidence to support his information on the location of graves of Australian and Americans killed at Surabaya, Java, but did not return on 1 March 1996 as had been arranged with Major Hall to collect this information; and (b) is the Minister satisfied with the efforts made by the department to obtain the documents held by Major Hall RFD ED with respect to Surabaya, Java.

(9) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `No date had been set for the visit to Surabaya at this stage, but it is expected that a visit may be organised early 1997, subject to the approval of Indonesian Authorities': (a) has that visit to Surabaya taken place; if so, what were the findings of that visit; and (b) if that visit has not taken place when is it expected to, and what are the reasons for the delay.

(10) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that: `In the main, however, the Department has endeavoured to keep Major Hall advised of progress by telephone calls and by letter', can it be confirmed that an amount of the information collected by Major Hall from the department was given to him only after he invoked the Freedom of Information Act and paid the necessary fees.

(11) With reference to the answer, in which the Minister advised that Major Tom Hall had, `albeit unintentionally, contributed to the delay by having initiated correspondence with several different areas of the Department', can it be confirmed that the original correspondence from Major Hall was addressed only to the Ministers for Defence and Veterans' Affairs, and that it was the decision of their respective offices to direct this correspondence to others in their department and not Major Hall's decision.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (11) Major Hall's claims regarding the content of the response to Senate Question on Notice No. 293 placed on notice by you on 1 November 1996, and published in the Senate Hansard of 4 December 1996 on page 6725, would appear to be based on information of which at least some has not been seen by the Department of Defence. The initial response was prepared in good faith and contained the most accurate information available from departmental records.

To fully research your current question would require significant effort which would involve accessing Australian and International Archives. The Minister for Defence is not prepared to authorise the time and public expense required to obtain and collate the requested information.

An invitation was extended to Major Hall in May 1996 to discuss his research findings with Defence officials. This invitation remains open and details of a departmental contact officer have been forwarded separately to the honourable senator's office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 28 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management has scheduled approximately 600 hectares of clearfelling in Giblett block for 1998.
(2) Will this logging commence before or after the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement is signed.
(3) Has the Commonwealth agreed to the logging.
(4) How does the planned logging affect the outcomes of the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) During the Comprehensive Regional Assessment process all forest areas in Southern-west Western Australia will be assessed for their conservation values and the contribution they may make to the comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system.

Under the Deferred Forests Agreement (DFA) signed in July 1996, interim protection is provided to sufficient forest areas so as not to foreclose options for a CAR reserve system. In addition, under a voluntary undertakings by the Western Australian Government, all National Estate places were protected until the end of 1996, and selected National Estate places are protected to the end of 1997 or until the signing of a Regional Forest Agreement.

Under the DFA and voluntary agreement, almost two thirds of the 3,954 hectare Giblett block has been set aside from timber harvesting until the conclusion of the Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) process.

I understand that the WA government intends to allow timber harvesting in 460 hectares of the remaining portion of Giblett block. This is in accordance with the DFA and the undertakings of the WA Government.

(2) I understand that the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, the Hon Cheryl Edwardes, has announced that proposed logging in Giblett has now been rescheduled to the winter of 1998. This is after the scheduled signing of the Regional Forest Agreement.

(3) As the area currently proposed for logging is outside the areas set aside under the DFA, this matter is a decision for the Western Australian Government. Commonwealth agreement to the logging is not required and has not been sought.

(4) As any logging proposed within the Giblett forest block will now not take place until the winter of 1998, after the scheduled signing of the Regional Forest Agreement, the outcomes of the Regional Forest Agreement will not be affected.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 December 1997:

question.para: (1) Is the Federal Government aware of any positive effects resulting from breath testing machines in licensed premises.

(2) Is there any evidence to demonstrate that the presence of breath testing machines will reduce the number of drivers and riders who are killed and injured in road crashes whilst having a blood alcohol level exceeding 0.05.
(3) What has been the impact of public breath testing machines in States across Australia over the past 12 months.
(4) Has the Federal Government considered legislation which would make compulsory the establishment of public breath testing machines in establishments which serve alcohol.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

answer.para: (1) It is difficult to demonstrate a direct link between the presence of breath testing machines in licensed premises and reduction in alcohol-related road crashes.
Such reductions are achieved by applying an integrated package of drink driving countermeasures, which focus on high levels of random breath testing accompanied by appropriate public education.

Public breath testing may contribute to this process of public education. if these machines are used on a number of occasions and after consuming different numbers of drinks, people can build up a personal rule of thumb about how many drinks they might be able to safely manage and stay under 0.05.

(2) Research by the Monash University Accident Research Centre into the benefit-cost ratios (BCR) of public breath test machines concluded that a BCR of 5.8 might be achieved if machines were installed in a substantial number of licensed premises; if promotion of the machines occurred; and if at least 10% of drivers over the legal BAC limit of 0.05 used the machines. However it is not possible to quantify the actual effect of breath testing machines on road trauma.
(3) Unknown.

(4) No. The Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) and other road safety agencies encourage the voluntary installation and use of Australian Standard personal breath testers as a way of educating drivers about blood alcohol levels.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1997:

question.para: (1) Did Wana Ungkunytja Proprietary Limited approach the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in May 1994, in order to gain urgent financial support to purchase 10 per cent of the Ayers Rock Resort Company.

(2) Is it a fact that the Minister instructed ATSIC Commercial Branch, on 30 May 1997, to undertake a detailed financial analysis of the Company's business proposal after Wana Ungkunytja Proprietary Limited informed ATSIC in the same month that the Ayers Rock Resort was to be sold.
(3) Did it take ATSIC Commercial Branch more than 2 months to prepare a one-page brief instructing Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, Brisbane, to undertake the financial analysis.

(4) (a) Is it a fact that the Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu analysis was completed some 4 months later, on 14 October 1997; (b) how much did this cost; (c) was a report prepared; if so, can a copy be provided; if a copy cannot be provided, can it be confirmed that the report recommended ATSIC financially support the company in its bid to take up options in the Ayers Rock Resort as a matter of urgency.
(5) Is it a fact that the full commission approved financial support through ATSIC decision no. 1985.

(6) Given that the sale of the resort has gone ahead, has ATSIC honoured, or does it intend to honour, its decision to fund the company's bid to take up its full options in the general property trust before the December deadline; if so, what form will this financial assistance take; if not, why not.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. The Nyangatjatjara Aboriginal Corporation (Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd holds shares on behalf of the members of the Nyangatjatjara Aboriginal Corporation) approached ATSIC in 1994 regarding the purchase of shares in the Ayers Rock Resort Company Pty Ltd. However, a formal application was not lodged. A letter was sent to the Nyangatjatjara Aboriginal Corporation in August 1994 advising that the Commission's Business Funding Scheme (BFS) does not have the capacity to fund a single project of this size and that the project did not meet the then current BFS funding criteria. The letter suggested that the organisation may wish to approach the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. A previous approach had also been made to the Papunya Regional Council which did not support the funding decision.

(2) No. The Minister and ATSIC representatives met with representatives of Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd on 30 May 1997 to discuss the proposal. ATSIC representatives offered to fund the cost of an independent assessment. Subsequent to this meeting, ATSIC commissioned Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu to undertake a full commercial assessment of the proposal. The proposed sale of the Ayers Rock Resort Company (ARRC) would not impact on Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd's rights to access a 10% share.
(3) No. Following telephone negotiations during June, written instructions were sent to Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu on 3 July 1997

(4) (a) No. After finalisation of a quotation, Deloitte Touch Tomatsu wrote to Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd on 29 July 1997 requesting information to assist in the assessment. Negotiations for additional information were completed on 25 August 1997. The assessment was undertaken during September 1997. The Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu report was completed on 6 October 1997 and received by ATSIC on 14 October 1997.
(b)The total cost of the report was $18,110.25, which is less than 0.2 % of the sum applied for.

(c) The report is of a confidential nature. The report supported the original concept considered by the Commission whether to assist Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd to obtain up to a 10% share in the ARRC in order to secure a financial stake in a business operating in an area of high cultural significance. In addition, it was proposed that this investment would secure continuation of Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd's current level of involvement with ARRC. The original concept subsequently changed.

(5) No. The Commission provided support for the proposal but did not give unconditional approval. Commission Decision No. 1985 states that the Commission "Supported a grant/loan mix to allow Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd to purchase at least 5% of the shares and the option agreement" and "Agreed that, if a decision needs to be made on the grant before the next scheduled Board meeting, the Chief Executive Officer should make the decision under her existing delegation from the Commission". The Commission's support of a grant/loan mix did not constitute an approval.

(6) Not applicable. The Commission made no decision to approve funding the 10% equity. The Chief Executive Officer of ATSIC declined the application from Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd on 3 December 1997. The reasons for this decision can be summarised as follows:

. Developments emerged since the sale of ARRC to General Property Trust (GPT). GPT offered units to Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd to the value of $7.268 million at a rate of 2.5% below the current market value, providing that they agree to the terms of a proposed Deed. Under the draft Deed if Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd exercises its rights in respect of the 10% share in ARRC, the $7.268 million share offer would be withdrawn.

. The change in circumstances resulting from the sale of ARRC to GPT not only affects the cultural significance that was associated with the proposal (as ARRC will not be operated as a separate company), but the offer made by GPT ensures a solid financial base for Wana Ungkunytja Pty Ltd. It would not seem appropriate for ATSIC to provide additional funds over and above the offer by GPT.

. The Business Funding Scheme policy precludes the Commission from funding proposals that are viewed as being passive investments. The proposal which has been put forward by GPT and the terms of the purchase of the ARRC, removes the cultural significance of the proposed venture which formed part of the basis for consideration by the Board and is clearly of a passive nature.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Training or Seminars
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1016)

talk.start.para: as the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (a) What training or seminars for Canberra-based public servants employed by the department have occurred outside Canberra since March 1996; and (b) Where has the training taken place.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the senator's questions are as follows:

answer.para: (a) A total of 61 Canberra-based Austrade staff attended training courses or seminars provided or facilitated by Austrade outside Canberra, between 1 March 1996 and 31 December 1997, as detailed below. These courses/seminars were also attended by non Canberra-based Austrade staff.
(b) See below.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Treasury: Training or Seminars
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1017)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (a) What training or seminars for Canberra-based public servants employed by the Department have occurred outside Canberra since March 1996; and (b) where has the training taken place.

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Department of the Treasury advises me that it has organised no training or seminars outside Canberra for its staff since March 1996.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Primary Industries and Energy: Training or Seminars
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1018)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (a) What training or seminars for Canberra-based public servants employed by the department have occurred outside Canberra since March 1996: and (b) Where has the training taken place.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) does not maintain easily accessible records of training and seminars undertaken by Canberra-based staff by location and I am not willing to allocate resources to comprehensively answer this question.

However, a major training program which DPIE senior and middle management staff have attended is the DPIE/Monash Mt Eliza Leading People Program. The first program commenced in September 1996 and 420 officers have participated in the 21 programs already undertaken.
(b) The program is held at the Monash University, Mt Eliza Business School, in Victoria.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Environment: Training and Seminars
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1019)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (a) What training or seminars for Canberra-based public servants employed by the department have occurred outside Canberra since March 1996; and (b) where has the training taken place.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Since March 1996 the Department has organised one training workshop outside Canberra. It was held in July 1997 at Bungendore, NSW. This answer does not include training or seminars organised by other Departments or bodies which might have been attended by staff of this Department.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Communications and the Arts: Training or Seminars
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1020)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (a) What training or seminars for Canberra-based public servants employed by the department have occurred outside Canberra since march 1996; and (b) where has the training taken place.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) and (b) The Department's Human Resource Development Plan states that "individuals, teams and their managers or supervisors are responsible for identifying and managing internal and external learning opportunities".

Under this principle, decisions about participation in training, seminars or any other developmental opportunity are determined by individual managers on a case by case basis. As with any other decision involving resourcing matters, cost effectiveness is a prime consideration.

In accordance with these devolved arrangements, there is no central administration or recording of the participation of staff in training or attendance at seminars outside Canberra. There were no corporately organised training or seminars held outside Canberra since March 1996.

answer.para: (a) The department has not run any training courses for Canberra-based public servants outside Canberra since March 1996.
(b) N/A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice, on 27 October 1997 (Official Hansard page 8058):

question.para: Has your government assessed the impact on taxation on revenue of the Telstra float.

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The various financing schemes being marketed to potential purchasers of Telstra shares represent fairly standard opportunities available to any investor regardless of whether they are investing in a privatised Government Business Enterprise or a private corporation.

The overall impact on taxation revenue depends on the totality of investor behaviour both with respect to Telstra shares as well as other investments. It would not be possible to track with any degree of confidence all of the actions of private and institutional investors who may participate in the Telstra sale. For example, for some investors, investing in Telstra could involve liquidating other investments which would make them liable to capital gains tax. Therefore, it would be a gross simplification to portray any perceived cost to revenue from the Telstra float as an overall net loss to revenue.

talk.start.para: asked the then Minister representing the Attorney-General, a question without notice (Official Senate Hansard page No. 7481), on 2 October 1997:

question.para: The Minister took on notice that question and a supplementary question asked following the Minister's response to the original question.

The question related to the accuracy of testing by AQIS of cooked chicken meat imports for Newcastle disease and other bird viruses and the role of the Attorney-General and his department in assessing the risk of legal liability arising from that test.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am informed that no record has been able to be found in the Attorney-General's Department that nay officer of the department has checked AQIS reports on testing of cooked chicken imports to ensure that they are accurate.

(2) Generally, such a task would n to be done within the Attorney-General's Department unless the Commonwealth agency concerned asked the Attorney-General's Department (including the Australian Government Solicitor) to give legal advice on issues to which the question of the accuracy of such tests was relevant.

(3) While the Attorney-General is concerned to minimise any exposure of the Commonwealth and its agencies to any legal liability sounding in damages or other relief, it is not part of the normal functions of his department to check, without request, processes and procedures for which other departments and agencies are responsible, in an endeavour to minimise legal liability. It needs to be

borne in mind, in that connection, that since 1 July 1992 the provision of legal services by the Attorney-General's Department Legal Practice has operated on a user pays basis and, accordingly, it is properly a matter for the responsible agency to determine whether legal services are required.

(4) Should there be a request from the responsible Minister or agency, the Australian Government Solicitor is available to provide advice concerning potential liability that may be related to the testing of chicken meat imports.
